Light citrus tones and lots of hops (too much for me) characterize this beer. Overpowering scent of hops too. Paired with pepper bacon calms it down a bit.

Draft at the Haze.  Orange-tan caramel color.  Big frothy head.  Soft and creamy, with a solid hop bill.  Dry and sandy mouthfeel.  Middle of the road, but perfectly executed West Coast IPA.  Bitter orange peel aftertaste.
Bottle - pours a solid clear gold with a sustaining head and some lacing. Has more of a piney hop taste to it than citrus. Light body and mouthfeel. Decent but I’ve had better.

Pours pale gold with a white head. aroma is of oranges and grapefruit, with some interesting yeasty notes. The taste is fresh, bitter citrus and hops, somewhat subdued but very well balanced. Appropriate body and carbonation.
Excellent. It was phenominal.  I could drink this IPA all day it does everything well and nothing bothers my taste buds so I am really partial to this one.

On tap at the Dutch right now. Poured a lovely golden amber color capped by a slight off white head. Head has good retention and reduces to a solid lacing cap. Hint of pine in the nose. Caramel provides a nice backbone for pine and nice lemony and grapefruit citrus. Medium bodied. Yeah!

Rated via BeerBuddy

Bottle thanks to DLau. Pours a slightly hazy golden amber with dense cream coloured head. Aromas of biscuity malt and us hops. Nice and fresh. Flavours are intially medium sweet with a nice clean bitter finish. Slightly resiny after taste. Medium mouthfeel. Nice

From notes.  First reviewed 1/13/2010.  Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a copper color with a hint of burgundy. A soft, white head forms upon pouring, quickly dissipating to leave little more than a ring around the glass.

Not a strong nose at all; mild grapefruit hops with even milder bready malt.

Classic west coast IPA taste, soft semi-sweet malt presence up front, grapefruit/balanced citrus hops. Leaves a bitter aftertaste for about a second. Nothing exceptional or really different about this one.

A relaxed mouthfeel with below average carbonation. A bit thin.

This ended up not being a great pairing with the food I was eating, and to be honest, I cannot think of a meal for which I would go out of my way to grab this. Not undrinkable, but after having one I had the urge to grab a better IPA.
This is a good IPA, only this is I wished for more hoppy aroma.  Copper clear pour with a decent head.  Sweet and bitter taste, lightly hopped.  Overall not bad, but my taste likes more hops.

Bottle.  Pours clear copper with a one finger head, mild carbonation, and decent lacing.  Smells very fresh and crisp.  Aromas of pine, and some citrus.  Taste is medium bitter with a finish that lingers on the tongue.  Palate is medium full for a 6.2% IPA.  Very nice and enjoyed.

On tap- Served a dark copper color with a good head that fades to nice lacing. Aroma of pine, with some citrus and fresh grain with a hint of malt sweetness. taste of citrus, with some caramel sweetness and touch of honey. There is a nice bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body, crisp and refreshing. Nice balance. Easy drinker. A nice West Coast IPA.

Bottle. Pours golden with minimal head that disappears completely. Aroma is tangerine, oranges, slightly dank hop quality to it. Mouth-feel is OK although a little thin, carbonation is at a good level, not too much. Flavour is busting with tangerine juice, ruby grapefruit, with a pithy bitter crescendo. Sweet candied malt coming through at the back and a medium dry bitter finish. A decent IPA, but had better
Pours gold with a good white head. Aroma is of citrus fruits and pine resin. Flavour is typical West Coast IPA - lots of hop and grapefruit.  Liked it a lot.

Bottle. Aroma: Caramel, soft hoppiness, toffee, peach, pine. Appearance: Red-orange and cloudy with frothy, light tan head. Taste: Strong hops, notes of grapefruit, pine in the nose. Palate: Light-medium body, average carbonation, long bitter finish. Decent and drinkable, but aroma is a bit soft for an IPA, and taste is alright if not remarkable. A fairly average IPA.

[keg at BrewDog Edinburgh] Pours clearish gold with large white head. Very cold at first, as it warms, piney resinous hop aroma, along with pithy grapefruit. No idea it contained 43 different hops. Tastes like an above-average kegged US IPA, all the requisite fruity hop components, zesty on the finish, touch of pine. Decent stuff [01022012]
Sooo hoppy. Dry, slightly sweet. Pretty good, but not so remarkable that I could find much else to say about it.
Great ipa. Had on tap at the press club. Well balance smells of hops. Great hoppy taste. Awsome beer.
Bottle. Almost a fruity aroma. Caramel appearence. Equally Carmel taste with hoppy zest. Lasting smooth finish. Decent beer. One you start a night with.
Mild fruit aroma. Soft amber color. Mild bitterness with a subtle sweetness. Sourness lingers a little but the finish is otherwise clean. Refreshing and drinkable. I would drink this one again.
Slightly hazy deep golden color with a white head that rapidly disappears.  Aroma is of citric hops and floral perfume.  Bitter on the tounge.  Very dry finish.  Nice beer.
Gosh 3.4 for an IPA. Not usually a style I like. Light copper. Very nice floral aroma. Flavor doesn’t insult your taste buds like some of them.

Clear light amber pour with thin but long-lasting off white head. Pretty standard IPA aroma of grapefruit and citrus, just a touch of caramel too perhaps. Bitter citrus initial taste moderates just a bit to allow a little maltiness come though in a nice balance with the remaining bitter hoppiness. Moderate carbonation and medium to light mouthfeel. A hoppy but far from overbearing IPA with a nice balance that’s quite tasty.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass.

Appearance is a clear light copper with a thin 1/2 inch head which settles into a thin layer over the beer. Good lacing clinging to the glass.

Smells of citrusy hops along with some light caramel.

Tastes of citrusy hops first quickly followed by a light caramel maltiness. Moderate bitterness throughout lasting long after the other flavors have faded. Mouthfeel is pretty good for the abv.

Overall a decent run of the mill IPA. Nothing spectacular but it’s solid.
bottle. 43 different hops?....really? surprising it tastes this good with no real direction in hops. above average IPA. no surprise coming from Lagunitas.
Keg @ BrewDog Glasgow. Hoppy aroma. Amber colour, good head. Pine hop flavour, bitter aftertaste. A good IPA.

Pours a light golden amber with thin white head.  Aroma is citrus, pine, and resin with notes of grapefruit and peach.  Taste is a myriad of hop flavors, lots of fruit, pine, and resin with moderately assertive bitterness.  It’s good stuff.
Nice rich deep golden hue with a solid hop nose.  With the texture and sweetness I was wondering if it was an IIPA as it has hints of those characteristics more associated with them.

Not only can I individually taste the 43 different hops I can also detect the ph of the water but I don’t want to be a braggart and put that info out there. Poured out a standard if not a bit weak clear amber brew with a silty white cap of strength in lacing and resilience. Has a fragrant aroma that come from the hops - you can pay me later for that insider info. Lemon, rrgf, very floral but not powerful, caramel, light orange candy - pretty good stuff but nothing exceptional. I do like the flavour of this ipa but it’s not the crazy ass beer I was hoping for. That being said - this is a very good ipa with a lot of the characteristics I like in Lag beers with it’s thick sweetness. Stiff bitterness and thick everything and a very spicy finish sums this up. In fact the spicy hops are becoming the signature flavour in this brew. A bit resinous, rrgf, solid caramel, some orange things... overall this is a pretty simple ipa but simple with extra goodness. Medium bodied, good carbonation and a lasting spice finish. Bottle 6 of 6 and I’m still not impressed as much as I’d like to be.

A - pours clear golden color with medium off white head. Some lacing.

S - Aromas of citrus and piney hops. Pineapples and pine resin. Subtle yeasts, breads.

M - some carbonation, with light body, slightly oily feel.

T - predominant hops on the nose, pine pitch, citrus (grapefruit and pineapple). Light bready yeasts, malts, and oats on the palate as well.

O - good ipa drinkable, with well handled bitterness, well balanced.

5+/6-

On keg at BrewDog Edinburgh, NYE 2011. Pours a dark golden colour with a decent beige head. Aroma of resinous hops with pine, caramel, grass, bready yeast and alcohol. Flavours of pine, oats and pineapple with dry apple seed to finish. Moderate carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. Warming alcohol linger.
Keg at brewdog Edinburgh. Grapefruit, malt and pine resin. Fairly sweet. Pale amber, marmelade hops with bitter pine resin.

Bottle from a cheesy Mexican theme restaurant. Pours gold with good, long-lasting head. Good lacing. Aroma and taste are what you’d expect from an IPA. Citrusy through and through. This beer gets demerits for a lack of maltiness and body, but comes through with a great aftertaste that gives a clean, pleasant bitterness.
Pours a golden color with a pillowy white head.  Nose is malt and floral hops.  Taste is pretty typical for an IPA not overly and a balance of malt.  Solid IPA

Keg at Brewdog Camden. Amber orange colour with off-white fluffy bubbly shiny head. Aroma is slightly funky, with something savoury in there. Taste nice and crisp, bit of sorachi ace maybe. Little prickle in the mouth and a touch of alcohol. Can’t put my finger on the unusual taste but it is lovely.

Bottle. Amber color with small off-white head. The nose is floral, light citrus, subtle sweetness. The taste is initially bitter with a clear, easy finish. Light. The palate is somewhat oily, the carbonation lively. Overall, an OK IPA, but my socks are still on my feet...
Zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz.  I didn’t know how else to rate it. Alright but I was falling asleep while drinking it.
Keg at Brewdog. A hoppy IPA that has a decent aroma and favour but nothing exciting. I tasted this after a few other (better) beers so my appreciation for this was low. Decent.
Keg at brewdog. Orange with white head. Hoppy and that. Lost in the lagunitas taps. I’m sure it’s better when it’s  the main event.
Tap at brewdog. Very weak aroma, some caramel present with some hops. Taste is also quite weak. Not bad in any way, just somewhat forgettable

Excellent nose of caramel, nuts, raisins, figs, and dates. Lighter mouthfeel than most IPA styles. This one goes down easy with a decent aftertaste.
Bottle at Olive Pit bar in Milwaukee.
I normally dont like ipa so i have avoided this for awhile. However this is pretty well balanced and not too bitter. Not bad.

Bottle 33 cl, ØlKonsortiet. Pours clear copper amber with a decent creamy beige head leaving lacing. Aroma is spicy, toasted, malty, sweet, caramel, fidges, raisins and fruity. Flavor is like aroma, pungent, bitter and peppery, too. Finishes spicy, bitter sweet and pungent.

35,5 cl. bottle. Clear, dark golden colour with a small off-white head that laces nicely. Aroma is hoppy with citrus, grapefruit and floral notes along with some pines and nice caramel malts. Taste is medium bitter, hoppy and floral, but the good malts balances it nicely. Finish has a medium duration with bitter hops. A good, drinkable IPA. Uhmmm...

Bottled. Pours clear and deep golden with a white head. Nose of citrus and floral hops. Sweet flavor of citrus, grapefruit and caramel. Medium bodied, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Ends up more dry and slightly bitter. A nice clean IPA.
Bottled. Courtesy of jaghana. A very pleasant IPA. Flawless and delicious. I really like the hop profile. A bit underrated in my opinion. Thanks a lot jaghana!
Little.head, golden. Light hoppy nose, with a little grape. Semifullbodyband good length. Taste is fresh with a little grape and hops. Not a very hoppy IPA.

(Bottle) Mostly pine and spruce with a hint of citrus. Difficult to isolate any one flavor but surprisingly not very complex. Thin and bitter the whole way through. It pretty much sets the example of a west coast style ipa.

nice bitterness and aroma, full bodied. Cool bottle and sticker. Complex flavour with everything u’d expect from a india pale ale. One of the few minuses is that it doesn’t bring really anything new to the ipa-taste
Fairly standard fair in the IPA world. Balanced, not overly bitter, but unfortunately nothing that makes me want to try it again.
Fresh crisp aroma with hop and pine needles. Taste has a medium bite with some citrus. Apples and pears with some spruce. Long finish.

Golden pour, good head that dissipated in the center quickly but lingered on the glass a while.  Full aroma with grapefruit, pine, and floral on the nose.  Good amount of hoppiness; bitter, but not completely in-your-face.  Its closer to the bitter of grapefruit, and allows the pine/woody flavor to come through as well.  IPAs must be growing on me; I like this one.
nice looking deep orange pour with a frothy white head. smells of citrus hops, some malt and spicy. hoppy on the tongue with a lingering bitter pine taste. light/medium body.. i can’t decide.

Wildly aromatic and deliciously crisp with a bitter finish. Another good brew from Lagunitas! They say that this brew is made from 43 different hops and 65 various malts; I say it’s quite tasty, whatever they used! The strong, balanced flavors of caramel and grapefruit help pave the way to a warmly bitter finish and leaves a bitter aftertaste that is quite enjoyable. A good IPA that I look forward to enjoying more of!

Pours a clear orange/amber color with a medium white head...nice lacing!  Aroma has light sweet citrus notes, a bit of earthy spiciness, and a touch of doughy malt backing.  Flavor is very citrusy up front with grapefruit and pineapple...some piney notes and a hint of spice at the end...some caramely malt notes.  Mouthfeel is somewhat light and the finish is fairly bitter and dry.
Bottle @mondial de la biere, a clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is amazing on fresh hops and grass, very intense. Aroma is resinous, sweet, fresh hops, grass, agrume notes, a very nice ipa.

A: Clear golden color.. minimal white head.. little lacing..

S: Lots of citric and floral hops.. nice malt/grain base to balace it out..

T: Subtle balance between the initial citric hop flavor the grains in the middle and the slightly floral hop finish.. just a dash of bitterness in the finnish..

M: Smooth. Medium bodied. Crisp finish. Moderate carbonation.

O: A good showing from lagunitas... just doesn’t look like its a great one from the pour.. but it certainly tastes pretty solid.

Color ambar y espuma ligera, aromas sutiles a fruta y citricos con notas a naranja. SupOngo que la gran mezcla de maltas y lupulos le da ese sabor final caracteristico.Lastima que no he podido probarla en condiciones optimas pero se puede percibir una buena IPA.

Poured from a draft into a pint glass at San Diego Brewing Company. Color was caramel amber. About ¾ inches of head once I got it. A healthy amount of lacing. Lots of frosty film on the sides.

Smelled sweet citrus, mainly grapefruit. Also some orange and floral hops in there.

A slow-moving taste that rolled on the tongue. Unlike the nose. Tasted light grapefruit. Pretty hoppy, but not as bitter as I expected.

Medium body. Average carbonation. Long finish. Consistent throughout.

I have to say I enjoyed this beer. Not a bad IPA.

Bottle.  Pours clear yellow.  White head.  Smells of grapfruit, citrus and hops.  Taste is citrus and a hoppy bitterness, but the hoppiness is a tad low compared to the great IPAs.  Surprisingly thin mouthfeel.  Moderate carbonation.  Very refreshing.  I’m a tad disappointed, but a good beer all the same.

Pours cloudy light cold with a fizzy bone-white head. Aroma is of caramel malts, spice, citrus, and a ton of grapefruit. Flavor is of grapefruit and citrus hops with a sweet caramel and light fruits backbone. Good balance of fruity hops and sweet malts.

Bottle 12 oz. Clear yellow with an orange glow, and a large off-white head. The aroma is weak but with clear notes of grassy hops, citrus and pineapple. The flavor is sweet with flavors of grapefruit and pineapple. A bit thin mouthfeel. All in all an easy drinkable IPA

Honestly, Im a bit IPA’d out, but this is a great IPA if you’re a fan of the style. Lagunitas is not shy with their hops. This is a very well balanced IPA that has all the desired flavors of the style. Bitter citrus hoppiness that is well-rounded with just enough maltiness to make this a very hoppy, but well-rounded beer, but I still need a small break from all the pale ale hoppiness.
An okay IPA, a bit one dimensional. The price is good and the beer is defiantly drinkable, but not anything special.

Pours clear copper with a nice light tan head and a little lace.  Aroma is of west coast hops, citrus and grapefruit.  Nice hop flavor, some citrus and floral notes and some grapefruit.  Well balanced, nice amount of hops, and pretty refreshing with a nice finish.
Friday night bottle.  Pours orange with decent grapefruit aroma.  Taste is citrus, mild hops, light pine, and caramel.  It’s a mild easy drinking ipa.
Ambrée pale et totalement translucide. Très sapiné. Buvabilité au maximum avec un fini sec. L’amertume ne reste pas trop longtemps.
Not as tasty as other IPA’s (Firestone, founders), but amazing drinkability, A good everyday beer.
On Tap at Bier Stein. An average, well balanced India Pale Ale. Another good beer from Lagunitas.

12oz bottle @ The Pabst Theater before the Lightfoot show. Pours a deep amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is hoppy, citrus, a little malt. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, bread, with a pleasant bitter hop finish. A very nice, balance IPA.
A very nice IPA, golden color on pouring, very hoppy very floral notes and bitter taste on the end that lingers a bit.   Had this at Bass Lake near Yosemite Park.

Bottle. Pours a luminescent gold with a large-grained, sticky head that leaves lace. Mild nose of herbal and citrus, with lime predominant. Opens with some bitterness, then continues with a clean, refreshing rosemary and lime bite before finishing with hops again. Very well balanced.
Strong nose and flavor of orange peels. Fairly sweet and fruity profile.  Only lightly bitter finish. Malts are candy like. Copper color. Decent but not great ipa.

12oz bottle. Nearly clear orange color, minimal off-white head leaving some lace. Really nice complex malt aroma, hops seem to accent it rather than the other way around. Savory with a bitter back-bone. Slight syrup texture. Carbonation a bit sharp, though the brew is drinkable. Good IPA, but not one of my favorites. 7/3/6/2/14 

Re-rate, 6/18/2014: Clear orange golden color. Thin off-white head. Leaves a few bits of lace. Head soon fades to minimal. Medium body. Smooth, crisp, lighter carbonation... Just a light roughness to it, not as smooth as other examples, but not bad as I originally found it to be. Nice bright orange citrus piney herbal hop aroma, light bready malt. Pretty bright and refreshing. Moderate bitter taste, light to moderate sweet, light spicy. Alright IPA, not as good as my favorites. Different than how I remember though. I’m surprised my total score remained unchanged, but it was worth re-rating with my now much-wider frame of reference.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Pint glass.

Appearance: Pretty light colored orangish-blonde with a moderate white head and only slight lacing.

Aroma: Expected citrus, grapefruit and pine with some toasted malt.

Taste: Nice citrusy hop flavor with orange, grapefruit and very slight pine. Slightly sweet toasted and caramel malts provide counterbalance before the long bitter finish.

Palate: Moderately high carbonation, pretty light body for an IPA. Very dry finish.

Overall: This is one of the original American IPAs, and it drinks like it. Others have now surpassed it, but this beer does nothing wrong. A very easy drinking, everyday IPA.

Bottle.  Pours an amber.  Off white creamy head.  Some sweet caramel in the aroma.  Unusually sweet for an IPA.  Typical hop bitterness in the flavor, but milder then I would have expected.  Flavor is a little unusual.  Very smooth.  Good easy drinking IPA, but

12oz bottle in a tulip.  Pours ruby/amber with a thick, lacy, lingering, off-white head.  Aroma of strong citrusy hops with a lot of caramel and cereal malts to balance it out.  Flavor about the same.  Average texture.  A good IPA.
(Bottle 27/08-2011) Low white head, clear orange color, some bitterness with some sweetness, subtle aroma. Balanced taste.

from bottle: low carbonation with a thin white head.  translucent amber in the glass.  tons of fruity, floral aromas.  medium mouthfeel.  some lemon and grapefruit on the palate.  finish is exceptionally clean for an IPA.  From the tongue-in-cheek description on the bottle, I figured I was in for a real hop blast.  On the contrary, this is a pretty "mild" IPA.  Even the high alcohol content is masked in the taste.  Frankly, a great starter IPA.

Thought this was a very good, if not distinguished, example of a west coast IPA.  nice hope up front and through the palate with a clean, crisp finish.  Perhaps not the complexity of some others, but tasty and super refreshing.
Bottled. Hazy gold pour with a small head. Bright orange hop aroma. Dry, with fresh hop flavor, and a bit of an alcohol punch with a bitter finish.
Bottle @ Voldby beerfest. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, grassy hops, citruss. Taste is malt, caramel, grassy and citrussly hops. Medium body, soft carbonation. 270811
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is dry, malty and moderate hoppy - citrus and grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Quite dry and moderate bitter finish. 270811

Poured into a chilled mug.  A nice amber color.  The taste had a mild bitterness.  The aroma was oddly neutral.  Overall a nicely balanced quenching brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The standard ipa that all others will be compared to. It’s growing on me, and the buttering hops aren’t overpowering

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Location/Date:Bottle from Dave on August 23d, 2011.


Appearance: Pours an opaque copper.
 
Aroma: LIght hop, some spruce.
 
Taste: Mild bitterness that hangs on the tongue, plenty of malt to bear the brunt of the hops at the start
   
Palate:Lagunitas brews always have a sort of "clear" palate to me, maybe from the water. Medium-light body, quick finish.


Summary: A solid example of an IPA, I feel I could drink many of these with no problem because of the palate.
From the bottle (many of them, actually). Poured a nice hue but nothing special. Very fruity taste with suppressed bitterness and high smoothness. For a cheap, go-to beer, this one fits the bill.

One of my local favorites. Bottle, poured a strong golden color with a small white head (I haven’t perfected my pour yet). Strong hoppy aroma, this is my favorite aspect of this beer. Slightly sweet taste which goes down surprisingly smooth.

poured into glass from 12 oz bottle. golden orange color with weak head and no lacing, aroma is outdoors grassy with sweet wet dog, taste is dry and not bitter (for an IPA), balanced hop flavor, low carbonation, long finish, very drinkable, a great beer

A: Big nose, grapefruit, sweet white grapes and pine
A: light amber, medium offwhite head.
T: Medium/great bitterness, grapepeal, litchi, apricot, fruity
P: Well balanced.
O: Nothing thats stands out, but well proportioned.

355 ml bottle, from Ølkonsortiet, Aalborg. ABV not mentioned on the label. Deep golden colour, moderate white head. The aroma is fairly moderate, notes of dust and fruity hops, hints of tropical fruits. The flavour is distinctly hoppy throughout, as expected from an IPA, with fruity notes. Bitter finish, but not too extreme. Not too sweet, refreshing.
Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is light citrusy hops, biscuit, caramel bready malts and lime . Taste is pretty soft with hops, peach, light pine, bread crust, sweeter malts and some light lime.
The aftertaste is a little more bitter than I prefer, but the overall body of aroma and flavor is good.  The head dispersed rather quickly, but all is not lost.

(draught) clear amber, creamy off white head, nose of rhubarb, umami, weird but mildly enjoyable. Taste of umami, mildly bitter citrus, raw grain malt, bready and maybe too balanced towards the malt/bread aspect. Medium thick creamy body, easy drinking.

Bottle. Pours a lightly amber color with an off white head. Aroma is of grapefruit, peach, citrus, pineapple, light pine and caramel malts. The flavor is of grapefruit, caramel malts, orange notes along with subtle peach and pine. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a solid West Coast IPA, but definietly not the best I have had.

Nice IPA. Neither the aroma nor the taste are very complex. Fresh, floral hops and citrus dominate. Not too thick a body with correct carbonation. Very drinkable. Not amazing, but certainly very satisfying.

Floral aroma out of the bottle.  Nice slightly off-white head with excellent lacing.  Looked good, a bit paler amber than I was expecting but definitely "ale-ish".  Flavor was good, decent bite but not so much to turn off everybody.  Excellent lingering flavor.  An excellent ale!
Pours almost clear with a white head. Nice hoppy aroma. Taste is caramel with a bitter finish.
Sampled at taproom. Light amber with off-white head. Marijuana, hops and citrus on the nose. Starts slightly sweet, then bitter, well carbonated, bite of alcohol at the end.
Humle, korn, halm, lakrids efter humlen, grape, fyrrenåle, træ, gylden, klar, hvidt, tæt, skum, sød og meget bitter, tør,livlig, tung bitter tæt på harsk.

12oz bottle, pours a clear orange/amber with a thin white head and spotty lacing, aroma has a good amount of citrus on the nose mixed in with the malt nicely, aroma had nice touches of grapefruit mixed in with the bitterness in the finish, all around pretty solid and enjoyable.

I had been drinking some pretty mediocre ipa’s lately... Then came this one. It poured clear, little white head. I don’t have a great nose, so I didn’t get too much from the aroma but the taste was an explosion of hops! Tad of sweetness in the middle and a pleasant bitterness at the end. Loved it. I will buy this again and again.

Draught @ Amity Hall, New York, NY

Pours cloudy amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, grape and citrus. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Date: July 8, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Costello’s, St. Paul, MN Appearance: Translucent golden with thin head Aroma: Weak hoppy Flavor: Bitter finish and slight carbonation Other: Very easy to drink, but yet I was not overly impressed.
A really nice IPA. Golden and hazy appearance with a small head. Quite bitter with an explosion of its different hops. Recommended!

Pour from a 12oz bottle.  Cleam amber brew with ample head and lacing. Nice aroma of citrus and pine hops, light malts, a little apple or other crisp fruit. GFlavor is great as the swallow leads off with a fine moderate maliness and quickly transforms to a complete and bitter hoppiness with an excellent citrus and pine hops finish. Lighter in body than some IPA’s but refreshing, crisp, and clean. A fine, fine brew.
Good IPA not overwhelming but has good bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel. Despite its relative low alkohol. Lovely hop aroma. Good summer IPA. A little sweet but good balanced IPA.

Poured into my Sierra Nevada hops glass. Color is a nice copper color with a thick if white head. Aroma is nicely hoped. Flavor is great, one of the best IPAs out there. Palate is thicker than most ipas that I comment on being watery. Overall one of the best ipas out there, I was surprised I hadn’t rated this yet!

Poured a dark golden color.  Nice frothy head.  Fresh aroma of citrus hop, pine, grapefruit, Med/lite bitter taste.  Slight sweetness up front.  Med body, velvety texture, clean finish.  This is a fresh, smooth tasting, balanced IPA.  I may pick up a case of this.  Also has a nice palate.

Pours a golden yellow with decent head and good lacing.  Aroma is hoppy and syrupy malt mixed with a subtle cider mixed in.  Taste is nicely sweet.  Malt is kissed with honey.  The mouthfeel is nicely thick.  There is a subtle growing peppery spice that grows through until the end balancing out the sweetness and ending the beer with a sharp crispness.  One of the best IPAs I’ve had.
Either I had this before and didn’t remember liking it, or (I can’t believe) I had never tried it. Either way, it will now go into my basics rotation. Great for an everyday IPA!

Draught @ St. Augustine’s, Vancouver, BC



Pours orange with a small white head. Aroma has hints of fruits and hops. Taste is quite sweet with notes of fruits, berries and hops. Bitter, long lasting finish. Quite good and balanced, but nothing special. In other words, a great, great session beer. 8-3-8-3-15 = 3.7





Re-rated @ Jasper’s Corner Tap, San Francisco, CA on 21.1.2012 - A much fresher taste with a lot of pine, grass, fruits and hops. Sticky, bitter and fruity finish. Well balanced, tasty IPA.

Pours pretty clear amber with a medium off-white head. Aroma of citrus, grass and floral hops and caramel malt. Taste is mildly hoppy (not really bitter at all), with a semi-sweet malt flavor. Balance is good. Very easy drinking and accessible to those who might not like the bitterness of many IPAs. Medium bodied. Nice beer.
Golden brown clear pour. Hop nose.  Cant remember the rest. Ob iously not exactly a.memorable brew.

12oz bottle.
Copper pour with a amall amount of white head.  Caramel malt, pine and herbal hop aromas.  Flavors of citrus hops with a nice around of malt keeping the bitterness at bay.  Not my favorite west coast IPA but not bad either.

This beer is orange in color with a filmy white head. Clear body with little apparent carbonation. Aroma of piney hops and fresh cut grass. Very fresh smell. Taste is much maltier than advertised by the aroma. Not a bad beer but lacking a bitter character.
I don’t know how fresh it is. Not super hoppy. A nice tart edge to it. Hops edge on the citrus edge, not surprisingly; not bitter. Nice.
Draft (and many bottles over the years) in NYC. Soapy but very great standard IPA. Bit tart and light drinkable body. Very tasty.
Aroma is grassy and hoppy. The taste is much more malty with a great bitter finish.
Amber to orange.  Poorly held head.  Good, but not "homicidally hoppy" as billed.  Definitely inferior to their Maximus product.

Bottle.  Pours slightly cloudy orange with a decent amber head and great lacing. Aroma of sweet and fruity hops overlaying sweet and grainy caramel.  Flavor is sweet and hoppy citrus and pine nicely balanced by the caramelly malts.  Overall, a really nice IPA.

Citrusy hop nose.  Grapefruit aromas and flavors.  Slightly oily.  The hop and malt sweetness blend nicely, with the bitterness more in the background.  Clean dry bitter finish.  Refreshing, I like it.
Heavy simoe and cenntenial on this beer. Good standard IPA, thinking about throwing it into the rotation.

8/9/2009
Picked this up at Beers of the World while on vacation.
Say "LAH-GOO-KNEE-TUSS"
Pours a clear orange amber color with a thinnish white head that dissipates, but never really goes away. Smells mostly of caramel. pine and citrus, with a slight mineral smell in there as well. Nothing overwhelming in the aroma, nothing offensive either. Taste is initially sweet caramel followed by a slight mineral, segue to some citrusy hops. Lingering citrus hop and sweet malt in the finish. Oily resinous mouthfeel, medium carbonation medium to thin body. Pretty standard IPA I could drink a few of these, but nothing mind blowing here.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours dark gold with a white head.  Aroma of hops and some maltiness.  Taste is not very hoppy for an IPA, but very tasty and balanced.  Very drinkable at this low ABV.

Decent aroma of a hoppy IPA, flavor is very smooth, hoppy, and tart.  A little lighter taste of hops that I would like, but ends with a nice flavor of hops.  Not overpowering, nice malt balance.  A solid IPA.
Pour is a nice amber color with a small white head. Nose is pretty much the staple of of IPA, the taste however is a bit more complex and a nice refreshing offering for the style.

A simple pale amber is poured on tap with a clear orange/brown body. Head is an off white and creamy, with some small fast rising carbonation.

Bouquet is particularly simple but solid. Real fleshy smelling grapefruit, very juicy it seems, but not much else. It’s quite good though.

Taste expands on the hint of juice. Fleshy orange and grapefruit citrus, with some simple soft chewy hops and aromatics. Feels very soft bodied and tasty in the palate for feel.

Super easy, great flavor, this is the easy mans drinking American IPA for sure.

Draught from growler picked up at Consumer’s Beverage Niagara Falls. Pours a darkish colour with a red tinge, nice off white almost creamy head and good lacing. Aroma is hoppy, pine, grassy. Tastes so damn good, just love the hoppy bitterness. Good stuff.

Clear darkish golden pour with a nice white (but quickly dissipating) head.  Strong grassy pungent aroma with a very slight ’skunked’ hint (did I get a bad bottle?)  Nice sharp bitter taste but still ... that grassy skunky flavor persists.  I have really liked the other Lagunitas beers I’ve tried so I was a bit surprised by this one.  Definitely a candidate for retasting.

With an immediate oroma of hops you know what your in for with this IPA. This beer has a great clear amber color and a hopy bitter after taste. This american hops movement isn’t to my preferance but if it is to yours, this is the beer for you.
Golden pour. Touch of red, orange, and copper. Sweet orange sticky hop aromas. Not much else though. Tastes sweet and hoppy. Not overkill. Nice palate. Yummy, me like.

(12oz bottle).  Pours clear golden color with white head.  Aroma has grapefruit, other citrus, some dank hops and cardboard.  Taste is sweet from the light, citrusy malt backbone followed by hop bitterness.  Thin bodied with oily texture.  Bitter finish.  This is a very good IPA.
(bottle)  A solid IPA from a brewer that knows how to do it.  Traditional hoppy signature and ABV is right for a session.

A very solid IPA indeed, nice hop presence, some pine and citrus, lighter malt character, fruity flavor, great summer beer.  Very hop forward, could use a little more flavor to it, a little light for my taste but still pretty good.

Tap @ THE Steakout Saloon. Clear, dark golden appearance with a frothy white head. Somewhat tropical fruity, a bit piney, earthy hoppy aroma. Toasty malty, light caramel, bready, somewhat fruity flavor. I re-rated this thinking I must have had a subpar bottle but this is just mediocre.
12 oz bottle pours a golden orange color.  Aromas of pine, grapefruit rind and grass.  Medium bodied with some creaminess.

13 Sept 2011, bottle. light gold, clear, some bubbles. gorgeous nose! sweet pink grapefruit w/ some citrus pith bitterness, some bitter grassiness. med body and slightly fizzy. some bitter lemon citrus and some carmelized honey, there is a bit of a bitter lemon pith finish. pretty decent ipa. 

(original rating 7 3 7 3 14 = 3.4) june 2010, bottle. light yellow w/ some bubbles and frothy head that fades fast. nice hoppy aroma. not strong but nice. more bitter hop taste than i expected based on low aroma hops. still, it isn’t very bitter and finish is quick. it is kind of watery. this is nice but not a nicely aggressive IPA. fiarly thin body and slightly creamy.

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a snifter. The color is a nice light copper with a long-lasting white head. A bit of lace rings as it goes down. The nose is fairly strong on citrus rind. No real malt backing. The taste is some light citrus hops, orange and grapefruit. No malt. Definitely West Coast. Feel is nice and bitter and this drinks quite well. Love the below-6% abv on this.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010

Bottle. Uplifting glowing red body with vibrant orange fringe. Rich aromas of pineapple, melon, cherry and high-quality malt richness. Big IPA flavour with swelling bitterness leading to a dry bitter finish. A snack cup of fruit salad towards the middle of the flavour progression and an omnipresent piney note throughout. Finish feels a little incomplete but highly enjoyable overall.

No bottling or best-by date. Why???

Pours a nice deep and shiny orange/amber, with a beautiful white,fluffy head that stays a good while. Nice creamy lacing on the glass. Wow,this should be the standard appearance-wise for any IPA. An automatic 5 here.

Very grassy and bland aroma,not much going on here. This might be because of the age/staleness,lack of BB date. Some light malts,faint hops but very dull. WTH???

Not too impressive here, only mildy hoppy, and lacking in other areas. Average medium mouthfeel. Heavy carbonation. Rather dull.

This is probably past it’s prime, as I can taste staleness. Again,no bottling or best-by date, so I can’t know for sure. Either way, this is the most unimpressive IPA I’ve had, outside of the appearance. Will try again if I can acquire a guaranteed fresh one.

Bottle. Pours clear gold with a bit of off white head that laces nicely. Aroma is hoppy with citrus and floral notes along with some pine and a decent malt, caramel component. Taste is hoppy and floral, fairly bitter, but malt balances it nicely. Finish is piny hops. A very solid west coast IPA.

Was very surprised with this one. Wasnt expecting much but turns out it is a very solid IPA. Aroma is hop resin and grapefruit. Sweet malts throughout. Flavour is syrupy hop resin with sweet and sour tones throughout, caramel/grapefruit. Very solid IPA

On tap at Bistro 1 West.  Clear dark golden color with white head.  Aroma is filled with citrus hops.  Body is medium.  Hops are apparent throughout.  However there is a nice malt balance.  I feel that this is such an underrated IPA since it is getting so available in bars/restaurants.

Bottle.  Pours orange/copper.  Really like the hops in this beer.  Its different than other IPAs.  Less pine and not as sweet.  The hops are fairly fresh tasting.  Reminds me more of a wet hop ale.  Citrus comes through pretty pronounced.

This pours a medium to light orange with a white head that disapates quickly. Decent but thin lacing.

The aroma is very citrusy with light notes of hoppy but not bursting out. 

The taste is a little simple and disappointing. The first sip has a tinge of orange but almost no taste at all. The bitter finish is very light, nothing special. 

This is an OK IPA, I’d probably drink it if a bar offered it but would not seek it out again.

Pours a golden yellow colour with a nice size white head which leave a a nice lacing around the glass. The aroma is very hoppy citrus and the taste starts very sweet but smooths out and has a light bitterness in the aftertaste
Golden pour, soft carbonation, medium body. Tastes of caramel, light sweetness, and medium bitterness. Overall a very pleasurable IPA.
Golden colored beer with an ok offwhite head. Hoppy aroma with some mash and some citrus notes. Hoppy bitter flavor with some perfume. Surprisingly flat and quite a disappointment.
Bottle. Pale gold amber color. Thin head. Smells of faint hop, lemon and citrus. Taste is hoppy and bitter. Almost more like an american pale ale. Very drinkable and flkavorful nonetheless

Clear golden pour with very thin white head reducing to just a layer of soapy foam leaving some lacing on the glass. Sweet caramel and grassy hops in the aroma. Crisp balanced taste. Medium body with light carbonation. Balanced bitter sweet finish.

Great appearance, lovely tight thick head. Quite a stronp citrus aroma with some light toffee. Up front its strong lemon with a nice malt deck propping it up. Well balanced, lingering and very drinkable.

Can’t believe I’ve never rated this. Pours attractive clear copper with a three finger eggshell head. Tight bubbles and persistent lacing. Great nose of flowers, pineapple, grass and caramel. A little bit lighter in the taste, with more malt standing out. Nice dry finish.

Golden orange/yellow in color with white head.  Malty caramel sweetness on the nose with a hint of citrus.  Aromatic hops are present, but not strong.  Initially sweet up front with a nice finish of bitterness in the back of the throat.  My kind of IPA as I like them a bit on the sweet side but not cloying.  Carbonation is crisp with a smooth mouthfeel.  Overall and very drinkable and good beer.

12oz bottle.  Copper orange with a slight haze and vigorous rocky tan head.   Has a mild aroma of piney, woody hops with a touch of fruity esters. Mild up front, tastes of pine & grapefruit. Bittering hops come through midway and give it a solid bitter finish.

Medium sticky IPA, perhaps the hops have faded a bit, taste of light melon, a bit of citrus, not very bitter finish.  Clean but on the sweeter side. 

I can’t believe my bottle consumed in 2016 Japan tastes fresher than my 2011 glass must have. But here we are.

Unlimited release beer with a clean, attractive label. 45.6 IBUS. 22 oz bomber with no sign of a freshness date.

Pours a golden/orange/amber with a thick 2 finger head that sticks around nicely and leaves nice lacing.

Smell is good with nice but mellow citrus grapefruit and piney hop scent. A bit of sweetness, smells tasty.

Taste is good, not the best but decent. The mouthfeel is a little off. The taste is a lot maltier with more piney, bitter hops than citrus. Burps reveal more of the citrus.

Overall it is a good west coast IPA with just enough bite to make it interesting.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-09-2009 21:45:32

A little disappointed with this one. Unremarkable in just about everyway; weak aroma and underwhelming taste, both very alcoholic in nature. I like my IPA’s hoppy as heck with an abundance of flavor and a powerful aroma and this unfortunately was not it.

Aroma greets you from 6ft away, syrupy, caramel? marmalade? Whatever it is, it is delicious. Quite a bitter mouthfeel, tart and abrupt. This smacks of a well-made beer and worth whatever it was I paid for it. 43 different hops and 65 malts? Are they taking the piss? There was no alcohol content on the label of the bottle I bought, which is illegal in this country, nonetheless, i would break the law to buy this again.

12oz bottle.  mber with a decent hoppy aroma. Flavor has some good malty taste with a medium bitterness and good hops. The first taste didn’t seem that hoppy but it built up after a while. Not a bad IPA.

Pours a clear orange with a lot of bubbles but a very thin white head. Aroma of sweet malts and floral hops. Flavor is a decent amount of citrusy hops balanced nicely with the malts.  The hops aren’t as strong as I was expecting, but this is still a decent IPA.
Has a nice color to it and a fresh scent. Has a lit bitterness that fades with the after taste.
Very nice hoopy IPA poors beautiful and makes you want another.  I like the hops bitterness, seems about right.  A beer I’d gladly pay for at any time.

Bottle, pours clear orange with frothy white head. Very juicy nose, full of fresh, bright citrus notes and slight caramel on the back end. Significantly weaker taste, but still decent: orange, pine, tangerine. Hint of toffee. Much less of a hop bite than I’d like, but pretty sessionable if nothing else.

Pours a pale amber/orange with a nice head of tightly packed bubbles that open up... a thin but solid head remains... smells of soap, and fresh air after a snowfall... hoppy, sweat and sour, bubblegum, apricot, and some orange... clean finish. Nice.

Poured a crystal clear deep amber yellow with ample off-white head that did not lace at all. None whatsoever, even with agitation, etc. Smell is leafy hops, with some grainy malt in the back, but not much else. Taste follows, with plain ol’ hop bitter body with some bready malt to back it up. Aftertaste is clean and fresh from the hop assault (which isn’t really an assault after having beers like Stone Ruination). Don’t get much complexity from this at all, which isn’t to say its bad, just that it’s...boring. Mouthfeel is nice and balanced, although approaching thin at times. Drinkability is average due to singular nature of taste.

Pours a dark golden with a decent light head.  Aroma of hops with light floral.  Taste is the standard hops of an IPA.  Smooth along the palate with slightly bitter finish.  Solid IPA, but doesn’t really stick out from the bunch
Clear golden body, white head. Very crisp spicy lemony aroma. Some caramel malts too. Flavour has lots of caramel and nice hops. It is little of everything, but nothing much.

12oz bottled January 10, 2011.  Quite fresh.  New recipe?  Label states 6.2% ABV.  Pours clear amber with a large off-white head that leaves tons of lacing and holds a rocky island and ring.  Aroma is pine, grass, floral hops with a bit of citrus, some malt and some alcohol.  Moderate to good strength.  Flavor is some floral and sweet citrus hops, some grass, touch of pine, fair caramel malt, moderate bitterness at best.  Finishes dry.  Mouthfeel is thin to medium, oily, medium carbonation.  Solid IPA but kind of tame especially compared to others that Lagunitas puts out.  Never had it before and thought what the heck, it’s very fresh so I’ll give it a shot but in hindsight I shoulda went with the equally fresh Little Sumpin’ Sumpin’.
Bottle, pours a clear gold w/ foamy white head, aroma is light citric hop, flavor is biscuity malt with bitterness throughout and moderately bitter finish, smooth, good sessionable IPA

Amber orange with medium small head.  Aroma pine and citrus hops.  Medium body without much alcohol or carbonation.  Good balance of hops and malt.  Not the bitterest of IPAs.  For some reason always feel like there is a strong background of carrots with this one.  Solid not spectacular.

22 oz. Aroma- Piny and citrusy hops upfront. Not pungeant but very present. AppearanceBright orange color with a dense off white head. Taste- Hop flavor up front with grape fruit as the predominant flavor along with some residual sweetness. Some caramel notes. Stong medium dry bitter finish. Medium full mouth feel very little if any alcohol. Great IPA.

22 US.fl.oz. bomber poured into a pint glass...



Appearance - Light amber body, with a very rich creamy beige head. Great head retention and amazing lacing! Looks very good for an American IPA!



Smell - The aroma is not very intense, but then again, the bottle I had was fairly old. Grapefruit, oranges, pine, a bit of flowers, and some nice bready notes on the nose.



Taste - The taste starts out with quite a good hop bite, with grapefruit-like bitterness and some pine. Then comes a surprisingly nice mild sweetness. Some caramel, some bread, and some toasted malts are also present. Finishes in a slightly dry and bitter after-taste.



Mouthfeel - Light-to-medium body to it. Low in carbonation. No real hints of alcohol, yet it may give a warming sensation to your body.



Drinkability - Goes down smoothly. For an American IPA, this is a very sessionable beer. Drinkable enough for a beginner hop-head, yet not too light or lacking on flavour.

The beer pours a golden orange color with a small white head. The aroma is pine and pineapple hops with a little bit of malt mixed in. Definitely the aroma of a hop-forward, Lagunitas beer. The flavor is heavy on the pineapple, grass and pine. There is also a nice malt backbone featuring toffee, caramel and bready malts. Low bitterness and actually fairly well balanced. Easy to drink. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A nice IPA.
Pours a nice orangeish red with a tan head. Aroma is great. Piney hops with orange and grapefruit. Taste is good with hoppy citrus. But a bit mellow. Overall a really solid brew.

Poured into a pint glass.

5.0 A: Almost neon orange in color with hues of red. Thick creamy head that retains exceptionally well and leaves tons of lacing.

3.5 S: Floral hops foremost, grapefruit citrus. Aroma isn’t very strong.

3.5 T: Really hoppy and to a slightly lesser extent bitter. Reminiscent of Flying Dog’s IPA, only there seems to be more depth to this one. Citrus hops foremost, then earthy hops, and then biscuity malts. Not a whole lot of balance. If there was a stronger malt character, this beer would kick ass.

3.5 M: Light/Medium body with good carbonation. Not as creamy as I would have expected from the appearance.

4.0 D: Good brew, really for hopheads like me though. Would like to see a little more balance.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-21-2008 02:13:52

Brownish-reddish-yellowish pour with a fluffy white head. Aroma seemed unnaturally abrasive at first. I was really preparing myself for a harsh bitterness when I sipped, but was pleasantly surprised to find a bunch of sweetness. Aroma seemed to tilt back towards citrus and malt as it warmed up. Lots of citrus and floral hop flavors. Not aggressively bitter, but there is definitely a dose of bitterness on the long finish. Good stuff.

Can’t believe I haven’t rated this one yet - it’s become (thanks to Jane) one of my favorite widely available IPAs. Pours a mostly transparent orange, just a bit of sediment haze. Smallish off-white head. Nice, fresh, citrus hops on the nose, with a bit of a mineral note underlying the caramel malts. There’s a crisp punch of hops up front in the flavor, and they remain the predominant note throughout - as an IPA should be. This has a perfect balance for the style, is wonderfully refreshing, and I could drink it all day long. Nothing spectacular, but then again sometimes you don’t want spectacular. You want what makes you want to kick your shoes up after a long day and say, "aaaaahhhhh."
Nice floral citrus hoppy aroma and attractive pour with some sediment throughout; taste is well balanced if anything a little malty IPA with nice balance of hops and citrus
Light orange color - clear. Thin head.   Smells of Bready malts. Citrus and Pine hops.  Tart, grapefruit hoppy flavor.  Sweet bread maltiness. But not too sweet.  Light to medium body.

Had this one many moons ago and apparently did not review it.  Got a sixer for Christmas and really enjoyed it.  I don’t remember this much lemon in it before.  Nice hit of citric bitterness.  pours very light orange.  aroma is really nice.

Bottle pour in Lake Tahoe. Pale amber with off-white head that subsides quickly yet leaves frothy "legs". Pleasant hoppy aroma and drinks easier than most IPAs. Bitterness hits you right off the bat and lasts long after the sip, but. Isn’t as overwhelming as other IPAs. A pleasant, approachable IPA.

Light clear copper pour with moderate head.  The best I can say about this IPA is it is very well-balanced.  Not too fruity, not too dry at the finish.  On tap was very enjoyable IPA.  Above average offering and would purchase again
Copper pour with a big white head. Big citrusy hops aroma and quite spicy. Flavor is very smooth, hoppy, tart,  but maybe a touch thin. Still a very solid IPA.
Poured a clear copper with an appropriate IPA head. Nice hops right away with a little bitter  finish.  Some citris notes in there as well. Not my favorite IPA, but a solid one.

Several on Draught@The Fillmore for the last Black Crowes shows, SF. Orange colour with a a medium off white head. Aroma was piney hop, grapefruit and caramel malt. Pretty good hop profile in the flavour which was similar to the nose and on the sweet side. Dryish bitter finish. Perhaps lacking a little in finesse, but a much better beer than you’d ever expect to find at a live music venue in the UK. Freak n’ roll man.
Very hoppy and bitter (but in a good way). Has a pine-y taste from the hops, with some citrus notes as well.  Golden in color, with a decent head that doesn’t last.

Copper colored with white head.  Citrus aroma.  Grapefruit hop flavor, not as bitter as I like my IPA’s, but a great flavor all around.  A bit of a sweet aftertaste.  There is a slick texture that lingers.  Well balanced.  A good IPA.
Bottle. Pours golden with a white head. Flavor is fruity, grapefruit/tangerine, light pine hops, caramel malt. Very refreshing.

Gold beer with a frothy, white head. Aromas of fresh cut grass and grapefruit. Taste follows the nose along with pine/cedar notes. Very mellow and easy to drink. Sweet aftertaste. Some mixed spices here and there, much sweeter than the typical IPA. Highly recommend.
Deep dark gold color, lovely peachy hoppy scent and very strong citrus fruit and hop flavor with the requisite bitterness, excellent IPA

355ml bottle. Golden amber with some light brown hues coming through. Rocky head that collapses fairly quickly. Rich butterscotch and toffee aroma that clings to the inside of your nose. Strong hop flavour with a hint of bitterness right at the end. Feels rich and creamy in the mouth.
12oz bottle from Jeffs, sweet cirtusy hops with and bold mellow malt backing.  A little dry, but very well balanced.

Clear gold pour carbonation decent strong head aromas hops citric stonefruit note woody note caramel nutty flavour citrus peel bitter ibu medium apricot  caramel sugary sweetness earthy taste finishmalt is sweet hop bitter smooth aftertaste not much aftertaste a sessionist at best

12oz bottle. hazy golden color and a solid small white head. light citrus pine aroma. nice taste, nothing overpowering, nice blend of hop and malt with a smooth malt finish and a bit of hops lingering. good solid beer

Pours straw colored but slightly hazy with tiny white bubbles. The nose is pine, citrus, grapefruit, apricot, straw, caramel malt and resin. The taste is caramel malt at first that transitions into slight straw, slight resinous/earthy hops, pine, light citrus, light apricot rind, and an underwhelming hops aftertaste. Decent ipa for everything I’ve tried but good for barely a buck per bottle. Also, mouthfeel is a bit watery.

Another Lagunitas jettisoned at The Luxor- you can only bring home what you can carry. Dusted gold with a fine white neck of froth. Lychee, pine, honey and liquorice aroma with greener, more resinous hops as it warms. Brusque and pithy with a rasping, mandarin and quinine kick rounded faintly with cream and honey. Lean and biting; unlovable- needs meat on the bones.

Ar: Huge hoppy nose.  Slight pine, lots of fruit, specifically grapefruit and apricot.  Very nice.
Ap: Pours a slightly hazy light straw/amber with a 3/4" white somewhat pillowy head that dissipates quickly.  A bit of lace.
T:  Light malt sweetness on the tip of the tongue, but overall a slight bit watery.  Underwhelming hop bitterness on the finish.
P: Medium-thin body with very heavy carbonation.

O:  Good, but not great, IPA.

Amber with an inch of off-white head that fades. Aroma has passionfruit, kumquat, peach and some pine.Taste is light and fruity with peach and some sugar followed by decent bitterness - clearly this is one of those IPAs where the hopping is mainly about smell. Quite sweet, but the sweetness isn’t bland or lolly-like. Easygoing and refreshing.

Clear orange in colour with no real head, has a great sweet hop aroma of fruits and florals along with sweet caramel type notes.  Pleasing.  Palate is well rounded and fairly balanced.  Nice bitterness and a good hop flavour.  Perhaps a little sweet, but easy to put away and I would drink this again.
Poured nice and golden smelled and tasted hoppy and grassy great beer but so so as far as lagunitas is concerned

Pours a golden color with a slight brown highlight.  Aroma is a powerful combination of hops, grass, and floral notes.  Taste is hoppy with a hay bitterness on the back end.  Excellent IPA.  I’ll take a six pack.

I was completely stunned to find some Lagunitas on a recent trip to Kansas City.  Having heard good things I came home with a six pack of IPA and the Hop Stoopid.  Tonight I’m trying the IPA – if I get adventurous I may try the Hop Stoopid but we’ll see.  

It’s interesting to note that Lagunitas uses short-neck bottles.  Pours a hazy gold with a pretty bubbly little head.  Nice lacing, too.  Color is gold with just a hint of copper.  Aroma is, at least at first, challenging for me to discern.  All I can say is that it’s got a faint hop nose, though I can’t really get anything beyond that.  Orange peel, perhaps.  Maybe it will open up a little as it warms.  Mouthfeel is lightly sticky and lightly carbonated, and the bitterness in this isn’t as moderate as the Dogfish Head I had earlier tonight.  Interestingly enough, I called that one a West-Coast style IPA from the East Coast.  I kinda feel like this Lagunitas is an East-Coast style IPA from the West Coast.  For me the taste is kind of inverted, especially for an IPA.  Heavy malt sweetness starts things off, before hops finish things off.  Sadly, the hops aren’t pronounced for me, much like the aroma.  They’re just … there.  Maybe the aforementioned Dogfish Head fried my palate a little bit.  Best way I can think of to describe the taste of Laguniatas is that of orange marmalade on white bread.  It’s less assuming than others in the style but a damn fine beer in it’s own right.  Looking forward to having this one again.

355 ml bottle. Am10. From København, Denmark.

Clear golden colour with small white head.
Sweet sugary fruity aroma. Flavour is bitterish fruity hoppy with distinctive sweetness. Short bitter aftertaste. Rather mild for an IPA.
Bottle. Nice and bitter, good hop flavor, not too biting or alcoholy. To be honest I can’t really tell the difference between different IPAs. I’m not a very good beer reviewer. This is tasty though.
A very enjoyable Indian Pale Ale. Quite a bitter beer, but the floral aroma and flavour are very well balanced. Worth a second bottle.

(Bottle @ Blue Zoo Restaurant, Orlando, FL) Pours slightly cloudy orange-amber with a few fingers of light orange-amber head. Aroma of sweet and fruity hops overlaying sweet and grainy caramel with light vanilla. Mouthfeel fairly smooth, maybe a touch pebbly and a light bit sticky. Stout, almost perfect rings of lacing. Flavor is sweet and hoppy, lots of flavor, sugary caramel and vanilla overlain by bitter grapefruit and pine. Bitter hoppy and grainy caramel aftertaste. Rich and drinkable.

12 fl.oz. as  a gift. Thanks Balazs!

Poured deep golden with a nice creamy off white. Fruity aroma with apricot and raisins, orange peel, honey, caramel, nice resiny hop. Lively carbonation with a medium body, oily mouthfeel with caramel and tropical fruits, balanced resiny-citrussy hop. Fine, easy drinkable one.
Bottle:  Poured a golden orange with a little head.  The aroma was pine and flowers.  The flavor was sweet malts, citrus, and pine.  A decent IPA.
Pours clear golden with soapy head and thin lace. Floral nose with a hint of malt. Metallic taste with caramel, hint of lemon, and slight resin. A good IPA from a great brewery.

From notes compiled on a recent trip to northern California: On tap at AT&T park, where the Bay views and a Giant division title made up for the plastic cup and usurious prices. The cup could have made it tough to judge the appearance, but this managed to lace even slick plastic. The nose and flavor fit that profile, with quite a bit of hops but more malt balance than you would find in many ipas. Lagunitas can proudly join other west coast brewers such as Stone whose excellent ipas exceed their dipas. I am guilty of underrating Lagunitas amid the many other fine craft breweries in the US, but this was a real treat that I am glad to have enjoyed.
Solid IPA. Really good citrus and pine hop aroma. Great balance. Overall a very solid beer.
The only time I ever seem to drink this is at Chicago Fire games. I am pleased they have it on tap. Nice beer, the end is a little too sharp bitter but don’t let that deter you. Serving: Tap

This is a good ipa in six pack. I like trying any six pack ipa’s I can find. And this one doesn’t dissapoint me. I enjoy having a couple of these after work or sharing one with a buddy who has heard of IPA’s but hasn’t had a good one. Not a bad place to start. Good aroma. Nice grapefruit tartness to the taste.
first off, too malty like. I do not think this is a great representation of a IPA. It had a decent hopping but the malty aroma and flavour was too much.

beautiful. nice head. nice IPA tint. nose is awsome and welcoming. pine cones and citrus.dry hopped goodness! some pinapple in there as well but it is a really expressive and fresh brew. on the palate it is fairly hopped but not as hopped as i thought given the nose on this. the palate is about good balance between hops: crushing bitterness and orange peel mixed with some malt notes of caramel and and almost grain/cereal note to it. An absolute stand out. great stuff.

Pours golden with a light head. No aroma, pretty nice flavor of malts and hops. Drinkable but a disappointment.

(020714) 0,33l bottle @ St. Urho’s Pub. Head is medium, aroma is fruity malts. Better than I remembered.

Hoppy aroma. Malt was present. Golden brown with small head. Crystal clear. Grapefruit hops are primary flavor. Heavy caramel malt is also present. Well balanced but hop driven. Medium crisp palate. Hops linger. Overall a nice beer. Very crisp and refreshing. Hops are not overpowering but very present. Nice balance of aroma and bittering hops. Malt is also very nice and crisp. Well balanced American IPA.
Between this and Dogfish 60, my go-to IPAs.  Too bad each of these averages $20 for a six-pack in Canada....was spoiled while living in Boston.

Light Orangey-Amber color, small off-white head. light hoppy nose (really doesnt smell like much)  peppery hopped flavor medium body- fizzy mouth feel. dry bitter finish. One of my regular everyday beers since its widely available in corner stores and chain groceries in the Bay Area and further afield.

Bottle. Not much aroma except for some strong grapefruit like hops. Taste is a blast of hops right away, followed by some citrus and floral notes. A strong malt backbone with some noticeable caramel and bread like aftertaste. Long bitter aftertaste, a good IPA.
Light copper in color, pretty basic IPA, not bad of course, but nothing very memorable. A bit on the watery side, it’s lighter on herbal and fruity flavors. It would be a good starter IPA.

Clear golden color and a rich white head. The smell is very suttle but I get some orange and sirup. I think my rating would be slightly higher if the aroma was more potent. The taste has a very fresh sweetness similar to e.g. the Alesmith IPA. Very drinkable, but yet exciting. Fruity with citrus and floral notes, clementine, gooseberries and a bit of caramel. Best enjoyed outdoors with friends on a sunny summer day. Delicious!
Poured honey yellow with an off-white foam. Aroma of honey, pine, caramel. Not too complex, but to the point. Honey sweet aftertaste with mild bitterness. Good!

12 oz bottle into shaker. Aroma is grapefruit, pine, floral, caramel. Pours copper with a medium head with nice retention that leaves some decorative lacework. Taste is more malty than most examples of the style. It’s definitely hoppy, but the malt presence almost overwhelms it. I wonder if it’s a bit past its exp. date. Taste is sweet and finishes bitter. Medium carbonation and body. Not bad, but not the IPA experience I was looking forward too. If I got an old bottle it’s a damn shame.

12 oz. Pours a solid copper with decent head that dissapated quickly leaving intricate lacing. Aroma is pure hops pine grapfruit floral ctirus.  Taste follows aroma with a bitter trip through the hop palate. Smooth drinking and crisp on the finish with a lasting bitterness. A very tasty ipa.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass.

Appearance: Pours a clear light caramel brown with orange hues and a 2 finger foamy white head which lingers throughout. Very minimal lacing.

Smell: Pine, grapefruit and floral hops with just a hint of caramel. The smell is much lighter than expected and leaves something to be desired.

Taste: Pine is dominant up front followed by a sweet citrus in the middle then grapefruit and lemon rind at the finish. Aftertaste is a nice mix of hoppy bitterness and sweet citrus.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a moderate amount of carbonation. Feels a bit slick on the tongue due to the oily hops.

Drinkability: High drinkability. You could knock back a few of these without any trouble.

Overall: Solid IPA overall. Definitely not the best in the style but you could do worse.

pours golden with a nice white head and some lacing. aroma is caramelly and sweet.  taste is mildly hoppy with some grapefruit and just a hint of pine.  finish is graceful but not overwhelming.  A modest but well made IPA

Bottle from GBBF 2010.  Clear gold, thick lasting beige head.  Very hoppy with a little bit of toffee.  A touch toasty on the hops.  Tasty grapefruit piney resiny hops on the finish.  It’s a decent-ish IPA, but maybe a bit hard in the mouth.  Maybe the bottle had suffered a bit on the journey over from the States.  Decent enough, just that hardness on the finish is a bit much.

Cask conditioned	Gravity Dispense	GBBF 2010.  A clear copper coloured beer with a tiny off-white head.  A typical US piney hoppy nose with a bit of crystal malt.  Subdued lemony hops in the mouth.  A pleasant and understated US IPA.
Nice, not sweet IPA with a dry finish. Carb has a bite.  Fine, sticky lace leaves defined layers on glass. Approx $8/sixer at Total Wine and More in Boca Raton

Something odd about the smell of this brought the rating down a bit. It was malty sweet with some bread and a bit of garlic. Maybe I’m losing it but that’s what I got from this one. Flavor on the other hand was quite nice with a heavy pine citrus hit. It looks good and the after taste was nice it’s just a little weird on the nose.

pours a hazy amber, nice smooth body. nose of butterscotch and citrus. flavor is decidedly butterscotch, a little funkiness, a little citrus. finish is long, creamy, and slightly bitter, largely malty.

Cask gravity at GBBF ’10. Gold with a small white head. Piney hop aroma. Sweet malt and sharp hops as expected. I would have scored this higher in 2007. Mais aujourd’hui, autres temps, autres moeurs, as they say in France.
Nice flavor. The malts dont overpower the beer. The hops are not overwhelming either. Something you could make as a benchmark to meet or beat. Smooth mouthfeel.
Sweet hoppy aroma. Clear golden color. Rich hoppy almost sweet taste. Wonderful beer and a wonderful daily drinker.

Light Golden orange in color; crystal clear.  Good medicinal hops flavor with some floral notes mixed in.  Good strong toasty malt aroma and some pine/floral hops.  Overall, this is an excellent brew.  Good solid example of an American IPA.

A: The pour is a burnt orange color with a finger’s worth of slightly off-white head.

S: A decent hoppiness to the nose. Citrus and floral notes on top of a bready base with a bit of pine on the finish.

T: The flavor is not as intensely hoppy as you usually find in CA IPAs. A nice bitterness to it as well as citrus flavors of lemon and grapefruit. The bread/malt base comes through quite a bit as well.

M: Nothing out of the ordinary here, medium in both body and carbonation.

D: A nice easy drinking IPA that’s not over the top hoppy, but not too sweet or malty either.

Light caramel blends with orange-zesty hops in the nose of this golden-orange beer. Light malty sweetness is well attenuated and balanced with a moderate hop bitterness... fairly fine and doesn’t coat the tongue. Easy to drink. More. Pleasant tea-like hop-resin burps afterward.

Bottle (old rating 10/08). Pours a clear amber. This beer has a nice hop aroma, slightly piney. Pretty good balance, just enough caramel malt to carry the hops. Pretty common West Coast American IPA. I like the style so I like the beer, but there are many out there that are better.

Bottle. Poured a light orange color with a small off white head.  Aroma was good with caramel, sweet malt, citrus.  A lot of sweet malt and caramel flavors.  not too bitter; just right finish.  love ipa’s and this one doesn’t disappoint!

12 oz. bottle from Blueberry Hill.  Pours an orange-gold color with a finger-thick white head.  Notes of caramel malts, pine resin, floral and herbal hops, orange citrus, and wood.  Light-medium bodied, with high carbonation and a citrusy mouthfeel.  Some lingering bitterness.  Nice IPA.
don’t usually care much for ipasm but this one wasvery smooth and not overly bitter on the way down.

12 oz bottle. Even with a hard pour on second half of bottle, still had only a tiny white head. Very full nose with citrus, floral, and pine notes equally present. A bit light on the body with weak carbonation yet still managed to be crisp. Some light balancing sweetness sandwiched between some really aggressive bitter on the front and back ends of the swallow. Good long finish that twists to an almost acidic tart if silly enough to wait too long between swigs. Not bad. Not great. But not expensive.

A decent offering, well worth the money and i’d possibly get it again. Just didn’t knock my socks off. Good, just a little sweet, lacked a bitter bite i was expecting. decent hop flavor, just wish it was drier.

Bottle.  Pours clear bright orange with a small beige head that leaves patchy lacing.  Aromas of sweet pine, citrus, and sugar.  Flavor is pine and citrus rind, sweet malty caramel, and some biscuit.  Well-balanced and nice.
Yellow orange, whitish cover.  Aroma is pine, orange citrus, caramel.  Taste is nice bitter hop, pine, some orange, caramel.

355ml bottle. Pours a clear copper leaning toward orange color with slightly off-white head that laces out quickly. Big grapefruit on the nose with some underlying spruce. Crisp hops in the mouth that mellow out through the finish. A solid IPA, but no eye-popper.

Piney citrus aroma.  Amber-orange, clear.  Decent head.  Flavor:  Same as aroma plus light malt sweetness.  Decidedly bitter, but not overpowering.  Medium body, foamy mouthfeel.  Bitter finish.  Alcohol is well-concealed.  Not great, but solid.
A lighter IPA. Orange colour with a quickly disappaering heaqd. Dry but not overly bitter, very floral hopping. Fairly light bodied, a decent beer, but somewhat forgettable.
Pours amber with decent white head.  Aroma is citrus and pine with spices.  Taste is bitter with a sweet finish.  The grapefruit comes through.  Very easy to drink.
Draft. Dark yello and clear. Upfront hops with citrus. Taste is sugary and sweet like most of their beers. Full body and drinkable. Nice.
10.06.25 hazy orange no head. A:Citrusy, pineapple, grapefruit. F:Grapefruit. Thin to med body. Finish is bitter and medium long. The malt bill let room to a nice hop bouquet. Thx Jc for sharing  !
One of my favorites.  Definitely a go to beer.  Very malty beer but not too much to the point that it overpowers the brew.  Very good blend of hops too.

Wonderful just off white head and some lacing.  Aromas of malts-some cara, some melanoidin maybe.  Loads of floral hops blend nicely.  sweet flavor of floral earthy hops melding with sweet malts.  crisp bitterness in the finish but does not linger.

Pours slightly orangey yellow with a one finger white head.  Laces only a little bit.  Maltier than it is hoppy but still has some hops and only a touch of the bitterness.  Smooth drinker with not a lot of carbonation.

Pours a dark copper cor wih a full thick white head.  This had big aromas for my nose to enjoy.  Very resinous pine in the nose, loads of rich grapefruits, and a nice earthiness to it.  Wonderful IPA flavors wih a full bitterness upfront, some soft and subtle sweet caramel, then the finish is long with a strong bitterness and a sweet honey as well.  Great IPA!

Served from tap into a RJ Rockers standard pint.  Poured a nice golden yellow-orange with a one-finger white head.  Lacing was excellent throughout.  The aroma was comprised of malt with a low hop presence.  The flavor was malt with slight hop notes.  It was light on the palate with low carbonation.  Overall this was a smooth IPA that was not overly hoppy like I would have hoped, but overall nicely put together.  Definitely went down smoothly.

Rating #356, bottle from Lagersalget @ Grønjordskollegiet 
 


Appearance is hazy red-golden with a minor head. Aroma is very hopped with citrus, orange and tobacco notes. A bit of berries are present too. Very nice. The flavor has a bitter and flowery hopped beginning with butter notes, caramel, tobacco, loads of grass and then a slightly yeasty bitter finish. Medium long hopped aftertaste. Medium body, bit creamy.
Pours a light amber with a slight head.  Aroma is delicious of honey, grass and hops.  Taste doesn’t live up to the aroma, it’s medium bodied and a little flabby.  Decent IPA.
Bottle. Vibrant golden beer with a light head. The aroma and flavour is well hopped. Overall an average IPA.

Bottle.  Hazy gold and orange with acwhite foam.  Aromas are caramel malts with creamy, woody pine and floral perfumed notes.  Spiced oranges with some soapiness.  Flavours are sweet citrus with grapefruit and pine bitterness.  Quite woody with some herbal, medicinal notes.  Dry and hoppy on the finish.  Spicy on the aftertaste.  Good.
Sample. Dark amber with off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, little fruit and lots of hops.

Got a big wiff of piney hop, not really hit with a big citrus. The finish had a good tell tale op bitterness and a deinite crispness about it. Nothing was overkill. Just a well made IPA I would happily have again.

12oz bottle from a six-pack.  Pours a fairly thin head that dissipates relatively quickly, leaving a good amount of lacing.  Appearance is a clear medium golden amber.  The taste is well-balanced; not overly malted or hopped, with a very nice, lingering bitterness on the backend.  Overall it’s a very nice, not overly aggressive IPA.

Bottle bought at Kegs and Barrels on 15th in Plano TX and poured into a pint glass.  

Poured a nice hazy honey color with a finger of offwhite head that reduced to a ring around the glass in fairly short order.  Smells mostly of caramel malt with the requisite grapefruit that an IPA brings.  The taste is honey and caramel up front with grapefruit on the finish.  One of the most pleasant and balanced IPAs I have had to date.

Bottle and draft. One of the most sessionable IPAs around. Pours light gold with a fizzy, all-white head. Citrus fruits and light floral hops in the aroma, with some mild caramel. Decently hoppy flavor, some more citrus, some grass, a little earth. Finishes very crisp and dry. Light to medium in body with lively carbonation. Not as aggressive as many other West Coast IPAs, and therefore much more accessible.

12-oz bottle. Aroma: Ruby red grapefruit, spice, and peaches. Honey malts. Appearance: Pours a crystal clear, yellow-orange body with a full, foamy, white head that doesn’t hang around. Taste: Lightly sweet pale malts with a hint of spent grain. Spicy, citrusy hop flavors. Medium bitterness for an IPA. A final taste of caramel. Finishes with a light bitterness. Palate: Just barely medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Overall: A fine little American IPA, it delivers pretty much what you’d expect from it.

Light copper in color, flaky boozy head. Aromas of citrus hops, peach, apricot, caramel. Flavors of pine/citrus hops, peach, light caramel back. A pretty decent IPA. Bitter, semi sweet, decent balance. Good but not a stand out.

12 oz bottle.
Dark amber with a good sized head. Some banana, a little clove and maybe brown sugar. Crisp light body and nicely clean finish. 
I agree with one of the previous raters who called this one of the most all-around solid IPAs at a good price.  This was one of the first IPAs I liked and remains a perennial favorite.

This company is really doing something right with their great pricing.  A 9 dollar 6 pack... I had a 14 dollar bomber last night!!  I’ll take it!  The beer pours crystal clear, deep copper color with a nice white head that fades pretty quickly but leaves awesome lace.  The aroma is really pleasant and flawless, jut a bit soft.  It is dominated mostly by a citrus hop profile, which I really enjoy (grapefruit, oranges, and lemons).  The flavor is very sold and balanced, but also a bit muted.  It wrestles between a citrus and a piney resinous hop profile.  Its fresh and balanced and completely inoffensive and drinkable.  The malt comes through on the finish.  nice medium body with perfect amount of carbonation.  Overall: just an extremely solid easy drinker here.  I’m completely content sessioning this all night tonight.
This is a very hoppy IPA with a nice color and decent balance, however I didn’t enjoy the pure bitterness with little hops flavor. Could be improved with better hops choice.
Just hands down one of the most solid and affordable IPA’s on the market.  Please never change this recipe!!!

Bottled.  Pours a clear amber color with a few specks of yeast floating underneath a medium sized lasting white head.  The aroma has a nice blend of floral, citrus, and pine hops with some toasted caramel malt in the background.  The flavor is very similar to the nose floral, citrus, and pine hops with a modest malt backbone, somewhat earthy.  The bitterness is at a nice level for an IPA.  Medium bodied, nice drinking IPA.
Solid IPA.  Beautifully balanced.  Hop character midway between floral and pungent/piney.  Eminently drinkable.
12 oz. bottle, pours a hazy golden with a white head. Fantastic pine hops, grapefruit and floral notes on the nose. Flavour follows similarly, with a balanced malt underlay. Really great IPA.

12oz bottle. Rating #1156. Nice dark yellow/gold pour with a pretty nice long lasting white head. Citrus (light grapefruit/orange maybe) with an underlying pine aroma as well. Medium bitterness and a little sweetness as well, very drinkable and a real solid IPA. (1192)
Not really the best beer in the world, but it succeeds as an IPA. Plus, the cap has a logo featuring a darling little dog.

This poured a rich dark orange with a finger’s worth of white creamy head. The aroma has some pungent aromatic hops. Taste at first has the aromatic hops come through with a solid malt backbone, though the crisp and piney hop bitterness shines through on the aftertaste. An excellent everyday IPA. I give it extra points for the very low price for this solid brew.

Pours clear amber with a thick yet quickley dissapateing head. Aroma is great! Lots of cascade, and  strong floral hoppy notes.  Flavour is also exceptional. Bold and rich, malt giving way to a citrus flavour and then into and excellent lingering bitter hop finish. The hops really make this beer it is an excellent IPA start to finish.

12 ounce bottle from Total Wine in Tustin ($1.79).  Pours a murky orange-amber with one finger of frothy off-white head.  Aroma of more mellow and less "bright" hops (grass, peach).
