Taste is initially mellow hoppy as well but the malt soon kicks in, leaving this generally well balanced and smooth.  A big of lingering bitterness in finsh along with some booze which is surprising since this weighs in under 6%.  I bought this about seven months ago, so that could be a reason for the mellow-ish hop profile (at least for a California IPA).  Good enough, but not a whole lot going on here.  (1152, 275)

Bomber thanks to Timbo and April. Pours a mostly clear amber color with a medium white fluffy head. The aroma is sweet citrus and malt. A smooth hop bite; easygoing light citrus, lots of balance from a earthy dry malt. So easy and tasty.

Intense peach and melon aroma.  Powerfully fruity, not sickly sweet.  Even non-beer drinkers (!) ought to be lured in by this one.
Deep piney colour with few bubbles.  Not clear: clouded with pollen-like particles.  Pure white head.  Lasts nicely, doesn’t obscure aroma.
Fruity taste, at first.  This fades after a few sips.  Then crisp, tart, strong and still fruity.  Quite bitter aftertaste.  Grapefruit?  A little malty.
Excellent overall - a really interesting beer.
I wouldn’t say I found anything outstanding or extraordinary about this beer but it had no faults. Bitter like grapefruit and pine resin yet subtly sweet in way that made your lips smack. Just solid.

43 different hops? 65 various malts? Wow.  Pours deep orange with white head, aroma is sweet citrus and piny with a resiny quality.  Taste up front is nice and piny up front, leading into a nice balanced caramel malt profile that finishes nice and bitter.  Great session IPA, whatever that 43 hop combination was worked!

22oz. Pours a very clear medium golden color, white head with light retention, some  decent lacing on the glass. The aroma is very sweet, reminiscent of a fruit I can’t quite put my finger on, then of course a light hop aroma to accompany. Has a dominant hop flavor, medium-mild bitterness, a good amount of malty sweetness. Medium carbonation, slightly thin body with a slick texture.

A solid enough IPA that pours a pale yellow--about the color of straw or a pilsner--and creates a thin white head.  Piny, dry hops predominate.  An easy drinking IPA that is pretty straight-forward, but not too interesting.  There’s a place in the world for beers like this, but I’ll pretty much stick with the Hop Stoopid when drinking Lagunitas IPA.
good solid smell, citrusy. excellent amber color, very good looking beer. strong taste with a pleasant finish. sweeter than i expected. definitiely a go-to ipa.

Bottle. Pours medium gold/amber with a medium white head that laces very well. Nose is quite well put together, bright fruit, great overt pine, and tremendous balance between the two. The word that keeps coming to mind with this beer is ’lush’, big juicy fruit, rich malty palate, great balance, I went in not expecting much but I was quite surprised, and very pleasantly so!
Pours an amber like color.  Pleasant citrus aroma.  Slight grapefruit and apricot flavor with a dry and hoppy finish.
Pours light amber with a white head.  Huge aroma and flavors of grapefruit, citrus, hops.
From a bottle poured an amber color with a fair amount of head.  Nice strong piney citrusy hoppy flavor with a lingering finish.

Lagunitas IPA is a tough call for me. I’ve had it in the form of a sixer and loved it and had it on tap at the High Dive and have been kinda "ehh" about it. Nose is sweet, floral and fruity, pours an amberish copper. Gonna give this thing another couple tries fromm diff sources and increase/decrease my rating accordingly.  A decent go-to IPA regardless.

Draft a the seafood joint in the Kingston Rondout with dinner last night.  Pine and grapefruit nose.  Thin spiral of carbonation yields a thinner version of the same in the Guinness glass. A vibrant amber that is sparkling ans transparent.  Pine and grapefruit absolutely dominate.

I’m a huge fan of the India Pale Ale beer style, but I’m not so crazy about imperial versions since they tend to be a little too rich and not crisp enough for me. What would happen if an IPA had the taste of an imperial but the weight and drinkability of a regular IPA? I suppose the answer would be Lagunitas IPA, which seems to be a hybrid of the two.

APPEARANCE AND AROMA

This beer flows very smoothly out of the bottle due to its thick composition. It’s bright orange with some yellow colors around the edge. It’s mostly clear, but slightly cloudy (like a summer day here in Albany – ha!). The head is off-white, frothy, and leaves generous lacing on the glass and sticks around long after the beer itself has been consumed.

The aroma is indicative of something much heavier than the beer actually is. I smell a rich floral bouquet with notes indicating rich sugary sweetness from the scent alone. There’s a touch of pine, but it’s more like pine sap rather than pine needles.

TASTE

When I took my first taste of Lagunitas IPA I was immediately reminded of many heavier versions of the style I have encountered over the years. The taste is extremely rich and malty with a distinct hoppiness to the body but followed by a dry back end. Overall, the palate is best described as sweet and syrup-like, almost sugary.

What’s interesting is there’s a creamy texture as well as a distinct caramel taste – but which is responsible for which? This is definitely one of the sweetest and maltiest IPAs I’ve had - which is fine because it’s tasty and refreshing. 

DRINKABILITY

It’s rare that I pay attention to the speed at which I drink a brew, but I was honestly surprised that I was able to slug down Lagunitas IPA so quickly. This is even more surprising considering the mouthfeel is rather thick, but soft. It finishes very smooth despite the bitterness to the palate. 

WEIGHT

I did not know the weight of this beer until after I had drunk a bottle of it. From the aroma and taste I assumed Lagunitas IPA was something bordering on an imperial style, but considering the ease of its drinkability and its lack of an effect on me; I knew it couldn’t be too hefty. I was vindicated of this once I discovered this is only 5.7% ABV, which is actually a little light for an IPA.

FINAL THOUGHTS

I have to say that Lagunitas IPA took me by surprise in more ways than one. I was impressed by its versatility and drinkability, and while the palate was definitely inviting it didn’t quite blow me away. However, it’s one of the few IPAs that would lend itself perfectly to sessioning.

13-MAR-2010, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer".
A while since I had this last. But no danger in going back:)
A textbook example of an IPA. Not the most extreme, not the hoppiest, not the most bitter, not the most anything - just a very pleasant drink. Very smooth, nice tasting, not overly bitter. I could drink a lot of these. And then Lagunitas are perhaps the cheapest American craft beers sold in Denmark. No doubt, I will revisit.
yellow golden colour with a little white lacing. nice hoppy, floral, citrus aroma. citrus hop flavour. not a bad summer drink.

2007: Really nice light orange color. A bit hazy, but light colored. Nice finger of foamy head. Good ring of frosty lace. 

Good flowery, estery hop smell. The smell is somewhat mild. Has a fruity citrus. Smell strengthens as it warms up. 

Fruity but bitter hops. Nice combinations of hop flavors: the bitter, the fruity and the estery. Very smooth considering its complexity. Great bouquet of flavors. Both bitter and flowery. 

Creamy and even bubbly. Has a nice thick feel but smooth as well. What a nice drink. Flowery, smooth, a little bitter. Easy easy drinker.

Pours a clear amber with a bubbley, off-white head. Aromas of carmel, dough, pine and citrus. Med-full body with flavors of carmel, oranges, pine and very light coffee. It has a long, biting citrusy finish. Quite good!
Bright orange in colour with thick white head. huge floral hop aroma, hint of caramel. Short hop mouthfeel, dry finish. Amazing.
Slightly hazy orange appearance.  You can definitely get the caramel, pine and hops in the aroma.  Citrus and caramel taste, but not very bitter at all.   Medium bodied quality IPA from Lagunitas.

Pours from bottle a coppper/orange with a white foamy head. Moderate carbonation, aroma of hops. Creamy mouthfeel, taste of floral sprucy hops, balanced well by caramel sweetness. Very good beer, should of tried it sooner but was turned off of IPAs by a few bad examples the first times i tried the style. Brewery is only a few blocks away, gonna have to visit now.

Pours a semi-cloudy copper orange with a thick layer of cream-tinged head that dissipates quickly with a lot of lacing. Aroma is a mix of floral and spruce  with a hint of citrus. Flavor is a bit spruce, caramel a bit of spice and woody notes. Body creamy with quite a bit of carbonation.

From the bottle. Pours a cloudy amber color, off-white head that coated the glass very nicely.  Aroma not too powerful, hint of hops and bitterness, nothing special.  A sharp crisp bite initially, then smooths out and finishes with a slight bitterness.  Could taste the alcohol slightly. Pretty decent.

Slightly hazy orange, frothy beige head. Aroma of caramel, pine and slightly oxidized hops. Taste is better, crisp citrus andf caramel but not as bitter as expected. Finish is slightly bitter. Medium body, smooth carbonation.
Pours a nice dark orange amber with an off white head.  Aroma is pine hops, some grapefruit.  Flavor is pleasantly hoppy without being smack you in the mouth bitter.  Easy to drink. Nice beer.
Amber colour with a thin white head.   Aroma is faint hop.  Taste is awash with hop, slight floral and medium bitterness.  Good beer but no Stone.

Draft at the Avenue (Brighton, MA). Pours a dark copper color with a foamy white head. Nose is piney hops with a light caramel malt note. Palate is medium with a sikiness and a light bitter finish. Flavor is piney hops with a caramel malt, some light syrupy feels.

12 oz. bottle to tulip glass. Pour is flat minimal carbonation and quick white head that dissipates. Color is amber red. Taste mild grapefruit and honey. Overall nice beer not as hoppy as I was expecting.

re rate on 3/1210 the appearance not as murky as I remember but the taste bit a little too much.. too my rating down to a 3.9 froma 4.3 sitll a great brew...

original rating2/3/10
Has that  old familiar sweet molassas hoppiness scent and the color is a beautiful golden amber... No real head but rather a thin frothy blanket.. First hit to the palate, oh my......  a sweetness reminissent of a green flash ipa immediately comes to mind.. the hops have a light floral bite but then earthy malts carry the flavor on through my palate.. A very subtle yet apparent aftertaste abundant as the taste dissapates in my mouth.. A crispness normally reserved for summer ales can be detected although its a crispness that is on steroids because it lingers long enough to allow the cornucopia of hops to mingle with the malts.. Quite simply one of the best first time IPA’s I have ever tried... I cant wait to crack open my second one!!

Bottle. Honey golden in color with a half-inch of foamy head. Aroma is caramel malt, pine and herbal hops. The flavor begins with toasted malt and caramel followed by resiny hops and grapefruit. It finishes crisp and bitter with a tongue numbing bitterness kick at the end. Solid West Coast style IPA.
Awesome beer.  Aroma of flowery hops and citrus notes. Nice big foamy head. Taste is hoppy and citrussy with more hops coming through in the end. Smooth and light carbonation. Pretty much awesome.

Lagunitas Brewing
Lagunitas IPA on tap @ Piece’s in Sacramento.
Pours amber with a thick white soapy head. Good retention with lots of lacing on the glass. Abundant aroma of hops, hops, and more hops. Flavor is much the same but not as powerful. Slightly sweet with a bitter hops finish. Not super well balanced, but well enough. Lagunitas does some better beers. (specifically Brown Shugga

On tap at Brixie’s in Brookfield, IL. and dispensed to a shaker. The color was clear, light orangy amber, with decent white foam to the head, and spots and streaks of lacing. The aroma was fresh citrus with some pine back up, and light fruit and malty sweetness. The flavor followed as these notes in addition to a hop bitterness that balanced well with the smooth malt presence. Lightly dry on the finish, and a sessionably favorite and widely available IPA (thanks to Karen) for securing the necessary hop fix.

Enjoyed on tap @ the Green Eye in Chicago.  This is a standard dry hopped IPA, rather floral in aroma and taste with not much bittering effect.  It’s very good, nothing too much going on here that lets it stand out from the rest, somewhat creamy and smooth.

This was called "IP-fukn-A" on tap at Rattle’n’Hum.  I bet they were being cute, and that it is in fact one of the 2 Lagunitas IPAs already up on Ratebeer - but I don’t which one.  This was a solid West Coast IPA.  Thick, pine aroma.  The flavor was mostly astringent and dry, with a grapefruity hop flavor.
Earlier Rating: 6/2/2008 Total Score: 3.4
65 malts and 43 hops?  Is that a record, or a joke?  Malt-floral aroma.  Amber brew.  Solid, grapefruity hops.  Bracing and forceful, but not harsh.  Good.

Draft at Duckworth’s.  Really disappointed, I don’t know if this was especially fresh, but nontheless.  Lacked hop flavor and aroma, as if the hops faded, really nothing underneath.  Their other IPA’s are way better.

Lagunitas Brewing Company	IPA--India Pale Ale--Unlimited Release 2008--22 oz. Bottle--5.80% ABV--45.6 IBU’s.  (4.25 / 5.0)  IPA--Lacy off white head.  Clear bright rich amber color.  Malty floral hop front.  Creamy smooth sweet mild doughy toasted caramel mildly fruity body.  Smooth balanced mild hop spice cloying malt end.  Malt over Hops Medium IPA.  Sampled 7/18/2008.  $3.50 Each.

Bottle.  Huge grapefruit and citrus nose, huge caramel, and some of the stickiest malt I’ve ever smelled from a pale ale!  Golden body with a lasting carbonation and a rocky, soapy beige head.  Medium body is a little too sweet, but firmly bitter without going overboard.  Citrus and nice fruitiness with sticky pine.  Excellent. [2010.01.12: 3.6]

Another bottle, this one not amazingly fresh, but only a few months old.  Piney and sticky indeed!  Resin, citrus, malt, touch of spice, bready finish, perfectly moreish carbonation, balance superb throughout.  I’d wanted to come back to this one after hearing about their mash schedule; there is some mild residual sweetness, but a great medium-full body that doesn’t overdo it and just might accentuate the crisp malt character that not only supports, but also propels the hops forward.  There are some homely Amber qualities afoot, but the results are still standout.  [2015.10.21: 3.6]

Bottle.  Amber with white head that lasted ok.  Grapefruit, orange, sweet hop with slight hop.  Initial kick of medium bitterness that turns into slight sweetness, similar to a Korean Ginseng.  Short finish with bitterness that remains on the tonge.

12 oz. bottle. This is the IPA I get when I’m just looking for easy drinking. It has only a faint presence of hops, despite the brewers plastering that word all over the label. The ABV is pretty low for an IPA, so if you want the full experience you should check out Maximus, their imperial IPA.

12 oz bottle pours reddish amber into a tulip with some off white head.  Aroma of typical Lagunitas grapefruit hops, some sweet malt, a bit floral, pine.  Quite bitter grapefruit (plenty of hops) up front, too much for my liking, prefer New Dogtown.  Finish dry and hoppy all the way.  Mid to high carbonation with a fuzzy mouthfeel.  Light to medium body.

The flavor was mildly bitter with a hint of citrus that was pretty refreshing as well as tasty. It was good, but compared to any other IPA I’ve tried, it really doesn’t stand out in any significant way.
Bottle.  Copper in color, pute white head that rapidly faded.  Aroma is floral, grapefruit notes, pine notes, yeasty bread.  Flavor notes of citrus, cereal grain malts.  Crisp and clean finish.

Fruity nose of grapefruit and rose hip, moderate intensity. Beautiful clear amber, medium white head, great lacing. Thin mouthfeel, light grapefruit and lime flavor, piney lemon zest finish. Nice transitions and fairly well balanced.
Tap. Copper with small foamy head. Aroma is floral with grapefruit, biscuit, and pepper. Flavors of grapefruit, biscuit, pine, caramel, and pepper. Foamy mouthfeel with medium body. Quality.
Clear orangey amber body with a short head. Nose is hoppy, citrus. Sweet marmalade in the taste, pine as well with good bitterness that lasts long.

Pours orange with a thin head and thick lacing.  Aroma is hops, slight vegetable notes.  Flavor is big hops that get bigger, unbalanced caramel malts underneath with a pleasantly bitter finish.   A slightly above average IPA, but not noteworthy.

Bottle. Pours golden with a lasting rocky head. Fantastic aroma and flavour of citrus, grapefruit and pine, with a supportive malt backbone of caramel and biscuit. There’s moderate bitterness that shows right through to the finish. Perhaps a tad too sweet which would be my only flaw with this IPA. It’s quite sessionable though and enjoyed it.

12 oz bottle. Pours clear golden amber with a dense off white head. Aroma of floral and citrus hops, that signature Lagunitas sugary sweetness and some light caramel malt. Flavor is pretty sweet, once again that sugary sweetness that is common in a lot of Lagunitas beers, there is also a medium hop bitterness. Medium body, average carbonation and a syrupy mouth feel. Overall a decent IPA, bit sweet but good.

Pours orange/amber with no head. Nose has caramel/toffee with heaps of citrus & pine. Palate translates well but doesn’t add a whole lot else. Still has a decent amount of hops but not overly robust, bit of a maltbomb at this point. Finishes with a touch of piney hops. Quite tasty but doesn’t really grab me, suspect it would be much better/hoppier fresh.

Bottle. Clear golden orange body with a short-lived beige head. Hoppy nose has notes of citrus (particularly orange), pine and caramel. Similar flavour with some noticeable sweetness, light and smooth mouthfeel and a long mildly bitter finish. Easy drinking and flavoursome, this is a very nice IPA.

Poured gold with a small white head that leaves some lacing. The beer has a nice upfront hop flavour with lots of citrus, mostly lemon, and some pine, but then there is not much to back it up and you are left with a bitter aftertaste. The flavour is nice but it’s just not very well balanced making it a good beer, but not great.

Aroma is very nice.  Citrusy, pine, and some maltiness.  
Pretty straightforward, but the citrus just explodes in your face.  haha
Taste is a bit watery, but a lot of flavor from the hops.  Not much malt backbone at all, but this is drinkable.
Citrus out the ass, and pine on the back of the palate.
Finishes with a little bit of lingering pine.
Nice.
Poured amber orange. Fluffy head. Nose of pine and slight citrus. In the mouth it is easy drinking slight sweetness with pine, grass and more citrus. Not over the top but still well made.

(br-btl cm-lbl big-txt, Petaluma CA, 5.7%, 12¢/oz)



lct-cpr, lasting-crmy-head, ^creamy-med-full-body, §co2, wavy-lace.



sweet-malt crmy-hop aroma.



§fruity sweet-malt T1, hop-^resin ^caramel T2, short hop-bitter T3.

more-crml less-hop-resin if warm.
On tap at The Half Pint, NYC. Golden body with tall head. Notes of hops and citrus. Lots and lots of hop in the taste. Really nice. With malts in evidence too. Silky finish. A delight.
Very complex and deep IPA. Has a very dry aftertaste but is not as bitter as it seems with all the malts and hops used. Is a very good IPA
Bottle. Typical dry IPA with citrus nose and grassy hoppy flavor. Tight carbonation. Pretty good, but blends in with the IPA crowd.

A: Copper orange color with a medium head that settles down perfectly. A few bubbles rise to the top helping to keep a lilly pad like head and there is some lacing left behind as it is consumed.

S: Not a lot of aroma, but what’s here is nice. A bready sweet maltiness is right up front. The hop aroma is noted, but not overpowering. The hops show up smelling like pungent flowers and cut grass.

T: A very nice yet mild IPA. It starts off kind of sweet and malty, but only for a moment. Then the hops kick in. The IBU’s can’t be very high. There is a hint of bitterness with a dab of pine.

M: Medium bodied and easy drinking.
Bottle. Pours clear gold with a medium off-white head. Sweet malt nose with some earthy hops. Citrus and grassy hop flavor up front giving way to sweet malt before a bitter finish.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Very good though mild IPA.  Great starting beer.  Lots of grapefruit in the nose, a little pine.  Really not any hoppier than the New Dog Town.  Would need to try them back to back to really compare.  Nice hop flavor but not aggressive.  I’m into it.

Bottle.  Pours a nice copper color with a thin, foamy, white head that slowly fades.  Taste is of hops, pine, citrus, grapefruit, caramel and some malt.  Similar aroma.  Easy to drink and leaves me wanting more.  Not a bad beer and is worth picking up again.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear amber color with a moderate cream head that leaves a sticky web of a lacing.  Aroma is dominated by citrus and pine notes with caramel lying underneath them.  Taste is the same, with the citrus and pine notes being more pronounced, and the caramel barely being noticable.
Bottle. Poured a golden amber with an off white head. Aroma was full of hops both citrus and piney. Flavor was nicely balanced as it began with citrus and ended with a pine kick.
Bottle. Poured a medium amber with a fluffy head. Light hop nose. Well balanced and pretty drinkable beer. Finish is fairly bitter. Pretty good.

aroma of strong toffee crunch and background of pine. appearance is mostly clear sunshine. flavor is bigger then its labeled style and ABV present: big balance of toffee malt and huge pine crush. this is one intelligent IPA.

I’m getting a lot of citrus and floral character in the arouma. I’m not getting that excited about this beer. It’s got a nice mouthfeel, bubbly and smooth, but the taste is just not that complex. It’s missing malt presence, I think, and finishes slightly astringent. 

Possibly I’m not just in a great beer drinking mood right now.

12oz bottle.
Appearance: Pours a med gold that is slightly hazy with a nice white head and plenty of lace in the glass. 
Aroma. Citrus & spicy with hops
Taste: Spicy hop flavor
A good IPA
Nice aroma and flavor, lightly bitter with citrus.  This doesn’t stand out in any way from other IPAs though.  Good beer

A very mild aroma with grassy notes.  Pours amber and leaves behind fine lacing.  The taste produces citrus hops aplenty, crisp and refreshing.  The malt is mild and not obtrusive leaving hops in the forefront.  A nice pleasant hops bitter in the finish.  Not a single off-note in this beer.
Pours with almost no head. Smells of hops and flowers. Taste very light bodied with a pleasant hops bitter. Not a real robust IPA but good.
On tap at rattle n hum.  Candi sugar and citrus hop aroma.  Taste is tart, sugary, and grapefruit bitterness.  A solid medium body, somewhat creamy.  Slightly better than I expected.

Bottle. Poured a paler yellow orangish color with no real head. Aroma was pine, floral hops, spruce, and citrus. Flavor medium bitterness,  floral hops and grass. medium body, sticky, average carbonation, bitter, long finish. Very good beer.
Amber with a nice hoppy aroma. Flavour has some decent malty flavours with a medium bitterness and hopping. The first bit didn’t seem that hoppy but it built up after a while.

Resisted trying for a while because lacked endorsement and I agree with the underwhelming review, pumpkin color with creamy light tan head, decent lacing, smells of malt and hops, thin and weak texture, a little bitterness with faint citrus, not to complex.  Overall to light and thin with lack of flavor I like in an IPA.
Very good IPA and nice balance of hops. Pours a nice orange color. The aroma is standard IPA like: Pine. Taste is very nice with a slight bitterness.

Nose is slightly dank fruit with some peanut shell and orange rind. Really nice nose for a "standard" IPA. Taste is more of the nose, with the dank, resinous hops in the foreground and a nice transition to a slight tartness and a clean finish. Just enough bitter caramel sweet malt to wrap around. Solid IPA.
Had on tap at the Fort Worth Gingerman.  Pretty orange pour.  Very fruity hop aroma.  Taste has a lot of hops with a hint of clove and rotten fruit.  Mouthfeel is sticky and unpleasant.

Clear orange red. Frothy head. Sweet hop aroma. A wet smell that’s not sticky. Soft hops upfront that provides for a wet bitter background. Some kind of tart fruit in the taste. Almost like kumquat or dry grapefruit. Finish is wetter than expected and not distastefully bitter. Better than anticipated.

Serving: Draft.
Appearance: Light copper color with a pillowy, off-white head.  Decent head retention and good lacing left behind.
Aroma: Nice pine hop nose with citrus and dark honey notes.
Flavor: A big pine hop wallop up front.  It quickly fades, leaving behind orange citrus, herbal, and grass notes.
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium-light, dry mouthfeel and a medium, hoppy finish.  Lighter in body than I was expecting.
Overall: A lighter, but solid IPA.  The light body and dryness make this one extremely sessionable.  A nice take on the style.

Bottle split with Pat. Pours a dark hazy orange body with nice white head. The aroma is delicious hop. The mouth feel is medium and great. The taste is filled with flavors of citrus hop, with a smooth, crisp finish.

Bottle pours amber with an off-white head.  Aroma smells of oranges, caramel, and what seems like peanut brittle.  Brittle characteristic not present in the flavor, primarily just caramel, orange, and mango. Starts sweet and finishes slightly dry.  Not a bad IPA, but there are plenty of better ones out there.  Completely lacks complexity when it comes to mouthfeel.
Bottle. 12 oz. Pours murky amber. Aroma of hops, malt, barley, and citrus. Medium body, with a smooth finish. Great IPA.

Bottle. Darker amber color topped by a thin white head. Light sweet orange hop aroma reminds me of jolly ranchers and indeed the flavor starts off very sweet and fruity...then some caramel malts and an easy short bitter finish. Crisp and refreshing and not overwhelming on the hops.
Poured orangish amber, clean and balanced, caramel malts, citrus hops, slightly floral.

[2495-20090926] Tap. Navel orange hops aroma is a little grainy. Slightly hazy, orange amber body with a quick foamy off-white head. Sweet navel orange hops flavour has grainy bitter hops. Medium body is bitter. Wow, awesome game beer.

(@ Toyota Park; Chicago, IL)
12 oz bottle from Princeton’s.  Golden color, decent head and lacing.  Sweet malty hoppy aroma.  Sweet and slighty malty flavor with fair amount of hops but not too bitter.  Sweet citrusy finish.

Pours a clear honey color.  Aroma is very floral with strong hops.  Strong floral hops on initial taste, which diminishes to a smooth finish that isn’t too overwhelming.  Strong hops is well balanced in the finish.

0.355 l bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2009. Orange amber color. Juicy hop aroma with orange, mango and grapefruit. Bittersweet flavor with juicy grapefruity, mangoish and grassy hop. Firm but not very strong bitterness for an IPA. Slightly salty finish. Hoppy mouthfeel. Very juicy IPA.

An appealing golden color. Pours with a solid one inch head and nice lacing. Moderate spicy hop aroma. Strong malt backbone offsets the hops nicely. Finishes slightly spicy sweet. Loses some points as I prefer my IPAs with a higher gravity and much more aggressive hop profile. Still, this is a well-crafted beer that I would recommend for those that enjoy their IPAs on the lighter side.
12 oz. Bottle. Poured a nice golden color. Decent white head. Smelled of hops. Tasted of hops as well. Good IPA. Recommended.
Smooth..one of my personal favorites.  Good hop favor, but not terribly strong.  An IPA that I can have a couple of at a time.

This beer is too easy to drink.  I’m surprised, because I drink alot of Lagunitas... And I’m not used to this lightness.  Light aroma, light almost amber hop flavor, with only a hint of finish.  This is a great summer beer...

Pours a golden color with a moderate amount of white head and some lacing.  Good hops flavor nicely balanced with malt, although not as hoppy has they claim.  Medium bodied, and an all around good IPA.

Light and refreshing. Not heavy on bitter by any means &#40caution I like hops&#41. This has a different taste that i find interesting. This is by no means as good as Racer 5 or Founders but it is good in taste and for being unique.
Bottle in the rake. Alround rating: Excellent balance of american caramalt and tangerine lychee hop. I could have sunk these all day but we only had like 6 bottles and i stupidly upsold them all.
I found this beer very interessting. I couldn’t really find anything similar but I find that a good thing.
Clear orange color with a high amount of lacing. Strong bitter aroma and a bit flat and watery palate.

Cask at the Horse Brass. 
Faint citrus fruit aroma. Light malt flavor, with grape, honey, yeast. Reasonable hop flavor with medium bitterness. Rather bland.
very little bitterness, nice hoppy and citrusy taste.  Golden pour, very refreshing.  On tap at My Big Fat Greek Restaurant in Tucson

tap @ Citi: not bad, but def not great.  Though the hop level was too low... malt/ sugar level was too high creating a overly sweet, not as bitter an IPA as one would come to expect.  Still a very solid beer, but the balance was too even, not enough  lean on the hops.
***RnH*** "bitter front, all fruit in middle, dry crisp bitter end... caramel color, thin head ring, mild sweaty nose, almost creamy, full body feel, decent lacing." Way better experience than my previous try... was probably too wasted!
Yellow-copper with some cloudiness and light carbonation.  Slow clear lacing.  Hoppy, citrus-like aroma.  Good clean mouthfeel with a slightly bitter, clean aftertaste.

I really liked this beer. Nice red-orange color with nice big white head. Aromas of hop, herbal, fruits&#40grapefruit&#41. Taste is the same , plus some malty sense. Refreshing, nice body, medium bitter.

On tap at Beer Bistro late night. This pours an amber colr with thin creamy white head The aromas are mostly of carmel and grapefruit. Low hop bitterness with a citrus hop finish.  Decent IPA but have had better.

Clear almost golden yellow with a sticky off-white head that rose up fast at first and lasted the whole glass. The smell is slightly hoppy and sweet. The taste is hoppy but not quite “homicidally hoppy” as the label indicates but it is bitter. The carbonation seems a little low but makes the drinkability go up. This stuff goes down smooth.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-05-2007 15:32:05

Pours amber orange ale with frothy  but quickly receding white head. Aroma is sweet malt with a bit of pine. Good IPA with balanced maltiness. Tart with pine notes and nice brisk bitterness at the finish.
Copper blond with a very fresh hop aroma.  The bitterness takes over any malt profile but remains well balanced. Good IPA but the fresh aroma is the real winner in this.

Draught on 28th July 2009 at Rattle & Hum, NYC. Clear gold with good white lacing head. Grassy hop and some floral aromas then deliciously hoppy throuhg to a LONG satisfying finish - very good characteristics for a US IPA.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy fine to medium sized bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a hazy with fine particulate softly carbonated and a good lacing. The mild aroma was hoppy and floral. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a mellow hoppy aftertaste. The mild flavor contained notes of hops. An OK brew just nothing special.
Aroma and flavor both have notes of grass, herbal and pine with a hint of resin. Some malt is present underneath the hops. Pretty decent session IPA.
Light citrus. Bitterness. Bright orange body. Overall light sweetness that lingers. Nice IPA.
12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass. very pleasent citrus &#40marmalade&#41 aroma. a little bitter in taste, could be a little sweeter on the citrus.

12 oz bottle served in a clear pint glass.  Pour is a light bronze with a small layer of quickly dissipating white head.  Nose is hops, orange rinds, grass, and light caramel.  Taste is Pine tar, hops, and citrus.  The finish is a lingering bouquet of orange/citrus bitter.  This wasn’t bad, but I would have enjoyed it more if it was a bit sweeter and had a slightly heavier body.

On tap at the Flying Saucer in KC. Pours a clear, copper-bronze body with a finger-width, creamy, beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves lots of creamy lacing. Aroma is mostly a boatload of grassy citrus with a light caramel sweetness. Flavor is exactly the same. Lots of grassy citrus hops with a medium bitterness and a light caramel malt keeping this just balanced enough. More grapefruit and lemon comes in during the finish before it dries with a long lingering taste of grassy citrus. Palate is relatively thin bodied. Overall, a pretty straightforward westcoast IPA. Tons of hop flavor and just enough caramel malt to balance. Damn tasty, however, and its about time Lagunitas came to KC.
Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a plastic cup (sacrelig... I know): Copper appearance, citrusy/hoppy/piney taste. Tastes a little watered down. Needs more malts, man. #096 on 22082009, DG.

Light copper colour, nice fluffy white head. Fruity, citrus and slightly piney hop aroma, very nice. Light to medium bodied, with nice hop/malt balance. I expected a little more matliness though, more thickness on the palate. But a very nice, easy drinking Pale Ale.
Bottle at Cropredy ... copper ... big foam head ... sweet pale ale hop nose... soft toffee ... light hop fruit ... easy.

22oz bomber shared with funkybrewster.  Pours a lovely glowing orange amber with a nice sticky white foamy froth with great sticky lacing.  Mmmmm fresh! what an aroma! super green oily sticky piney resiny hop pellets, some sweet sticky rich honey and caramel just underneath, beautiful!  Flavor is also quite green, hop pellets, lots of hops, soo soo green tasting, a bit herbal, some med/light toasty caramel with a very bitter finish.  Medium bodied, on the thinner side though, light stickiness.  The greenness is amazing in the aroma, but of course it hurts the flavor a bit.
12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Not too shabby... nice fruity/citrus hop notes, but not as good as their crazy story, as usual.

Bottle, shared by Taylor. Thanks dude. Golden orange with a small white head.  Nice floral hoppy nose.  Flavor is bitter- earth and pine, and a slight buffalo chicken wing thing.  Really strange. Bitter finish.
Bottle @ GBBF ’09. Clear amber with thick lacing white head. Strong citrus, pine and floral aroma. Sweet toward a bitter dry end. Fruity. Medium bodied.

Pours on draught a clear orange-amber, with a nice offwhite retentive head. Big floral aromas, with nice orange citrus upfront in the mouth. This is followed by solid rind and zest notes midway through, and a crisp pine needle hoppy finish. The mouthfeel is clean and almost fruity, with a medium body. Lingers appropriately, wi a nice hint of pepper in the back-palate, closing the pull very well.  A nice offering.
amber pour with a small dense off white head. very little hops aroma, great hops taste, not over the top on ibu’s . a few fruit esters
Bottle.  Pours clear gold with a medium off-white head.  Bready and sweet malt nose with some earthy hops.  Citrus and grassy hop flavor up front giving way to sweet malt before a bitter finish.

Pours a dark golden color with a thick, off-white head that is very foamy and leaves nice lacing on the glass.  The aroma is somewhat fruity and sweet with a hint of hops.  I would have expected the hop aroma to be a little stronger in an IPA.  The flavor is also only slightly hopped.  It is more malty and fruity than most IPAs I have tasted.  At some points it has an almost appley flavor.  It’s not a bad flavor and is easy to drink because it is crisp in the mouth, but it is not what I generally expect from an IPA.  Overall, this is a good beer, but it is a bit off the beaten path as far as IPAs go.  It’s a little different, so as long as you are expecting that you should enjoy this beer.
Bottle at GBBF 2009. An amber coloured pour with a decent white head. Hoppy aroma as expected. Malty, fruity, hoppy taste. Nicely balanced IPA. Reasonably good.
Pours a nice amber color.  Smells of piney, citrus notes.  Overall a very nice IPA.  Would buy again.

After reading the bottle I’m excited to get this one into a glass. It pours a bright burnt orange thats very clear. The head  was minimal but left amazing amoutns of sticky lace all around my glass. The aroma was hoppy but I got plenty of malt sweetness as well. The flavor was delicious. Almost perfect balance of biting hop bitterness and malt sweetness in every gulp. A vicious piney wallop hits on the finish. The beer has a medium body with mild carbonation. On par for style. I really enjoyed this beer. My tastes have started to come around to the bigger hop flavors so this was right up my alley. I can see myself picking this up again.

I haven’t rated this yet? - 2009 Bottle - Pours clear orange with a frothy off white head...aroma is biting citrus peel and massive hop florals, with some sticky pine resin mixed in as well...flavour is different than I remember, slightly sweet caramel up front, giving way to grapefruit and pine bitterness that lingers shortly and is then gone...decent IPA, but doesn’t blow me away any more....hmm...

Bottle.  Golden with a large white head.  Great lacing.  Aroma of mostly floral hops.  Flavor is mostly hops - once again the floral variety.  Other hops are present in the taste that are not present in the aroma.  Crisp and refreshing.  Good beer.

Bottled. Slightly hazy amber with big white head that thins quickly. Nice big hop aroma with notes of fruit. Flavor is a blast of sweet malts with caramel notes balanced with  fruity hops that ends with a long dry finish.

Gift from Louise, LA, USA.
Bottled, 160709.
Orange-amber with white head. Aroma of malt and citrus. Flavor is spiced with malt, orange and fruity notes.
amber, sparkling,  a minimal head, medium bitterness, medium body, citrus,   nice IPA.  enjoyable

Draft at The Bier Garden.  Pours a lacing, off-white head with a golden-amber body.  Smells strongly of citrus hops along with some spice hops and dirty socks.  Flavor is floral and spicy hops with some honey.  Finish is citrus and bitter hops.

Overall Impression: 
These guys make a really tasty IPA, comes at a decent price too.  Solid and enjoyable example of the style.

Pours a clear copper with a tiny white head that dies rather quick. The aroma is a mad mix of hops... citric tropical fruit,  earthyness, floral, herbal, and slight pine. The flavor is similar, but with a ton of very sweet malt that doesn’t blend well. The sugars seem distant and, although there is a thick oily mouthfeel, seem thin and unraveled. Perhaps I got an old / bad bottle. I’ll probably re-rate.

On Tap at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 10/10/2007
Some carbonation. Hop and fruit aromas. Amber coloured strong in alvohol hoppy and fruity pine flavour with a crisp and slightly bitter dry finish.
12oz bottles, wonderful full hoppy aroma, nice bitterness initially and a little malt body. Very good beer that I can drink a lot of.

On tap at Jans Wine and Boos #2 (Tampa, FL). Pours a hazy amber copper color with thin white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of citrus, pine, grapefruit, tangelos, apricots, hint of spice. Flavor is sweet and floral with notes of malt, citrus, caramel, pine, hints of grapefruit and floral hops. Generally medium body with a pleasing floral hop finish.
Stong hoppy aroma, like some early bitter hops.  Very fragrant- great color- overall- one of the better IPA’s I have had-

Pours a brilliant orange-gold, with a lovely but short-loved head and nice lacing. Aroma is biscuity and lightly perfumey. Taste is surprisingly restrained; not as hoppy as o had expected, but still quite pleasant and balanced. Good carb, lightly creamy body. A nice light treat!

Aroma is of sweet malt. Taste is of sweet malt. If I didn’t see the label I would have thought this is a weak pale ale. Maybe there was something wrong with my bottle but I could barely taste the hops
BEAUTIFUL GOLDEN COLOR WITH NICE HEAD THAT DOESNT LAST LONG, SUBTLE HOPPY FLAVOR NOT TO BITTER WITH HINT OF CITRUS GOOD BEER GOES DOWN EASY NOT AS ROBUST AS OTHER IPAS BUT STILL BETTER THAN AVERAGE
Bottle. Golden amber colour with white head. Surprisingly sweet hops and fruits in aroma.  Nice fruity and bitter hops flavour.  Oily texture despite moderate carbonation. Dry, bitter aftertaste.
Beautiful clear copper with a white head.  Aroma is citrus and pineapple, and taste is the same.  Sweet and balanced with perfect hop bittering.

The predominant taste here is honey. Even the smell is honey. This is too sweet and not hoppy enough. Do you know what I mean when I say its not "beery"? Other than that, it was clear, tawny, and did have some identifiable grapefruit flavor. Bottle.
Decent flavor and depth to this beer, but light on the fruity, grassy, hoppy notes. Not as bitter a flavor as I would prefer, but quite decent when fresh and on tap.

Bottle...pours brownish/goldish.  White head, lasts a bit.  Not much of a smell really...a little fruity, a little hoppy, nothing spectacular.  Taste is good.  Mild for an IPA in terms of bitterness, very sessionable.  Could drink a lot of these.
Bottle and Draft.  Pours an amber body with a white head.  Very fresh chewy lush hop character and loads of grass, its like chewing on some fresh cut grass.  Good shit.
Tap. Enjoyable IPA but probably not a beer an hop fiend would love given that its a IPA. Flavor is not that in your face, very drinkable beer.

Bottle @ Ørsted Ølbar, Cph.

Pours a fine, copper-amber with a medium, creamy, off-white head. Aroma is surprisingly malty, light caramel, slightly grainy. Fine fruity hops as well. Medium carbonation, fair dry mouthfeel. Flavour has fruity hops, dry pine, oranges and grapefruit. But it mostly taste and the beer feels to fat, compared to how crisp I’d like it.

Pours a clear golden orange with a very thin, non-lasting white head. Not much aroma but there was a little sweet malt, and slight hops. Taste starts sweet, for just a moment. It then goes to a citrus hop flavor with some good bitterness. Finish is bitter. An alright IPA but not something to rave about.

Bottle.  Pours a nice yellow golden color and a large white head.  The aroma is all hops, and the taste follows.  Pretty nice balance, nice malt body and big hop feel.  The only knock is a thinner palate.  Overall, a nice deal and a nice IPA.

I thought I had rated this before? Oh well. Anyways, good looking IPA. NIce fluffy head that doesn’t fade away quickly. Orange/caramel brown in color. Looks pretty good. An awkward hop aroma. This pisses me off. I have had a few IPAs that had a tea flavor. This is one of them. The Hoppin Frog Imperial/Double IPA was just like this! An almost tea-like aroma. There are some hops, but there is this sweet flavor that improperly balances the beer out. A very sweet caramel taste. Just lacking in hops. A semi-smooth beer, but overall, a beer that doesn’t come close to Lagunita’s standards. What happened with this one?
Folks this is your standard well made LIGHT IPA. Nothing impressive but none the less an IPA.

Pours a hazy orange color with thin white head.  Faint aroma with notes flowers and apricots.  Flavor is lots of citrus hops that give way to a ridiculous amount of bittering hops in the finish.  Watery mouthfeel.  OK, but nothing more than that.

Draft. Poured a deep copper with ample thick head. Smells very hoppy. This one taught how great an IPA can be when it’s fresh! Bitter hops, pine, and malt flavors. Bitterness is not overdone and just about perfect.
Bottle. Pours a clear amber with a creamy offwhite head.  leaves some lace on the glass.  notes of sweet malts, caramel, some grassy hops.  Well balanced.  I liked it.

Tap.  Orange/yellow pour, plenty of carbonation and aroma of fresh hops.  Flavor was that of your standard everyday solid IPA, plenty of in your face hops, citrus and a good bitter bite on the finish.  Not a fan of all Lagunita’s beer, but this one was solid and I will be buying a sixer of this sometime soon.
pours copper. grapefruit, citrus hops. Sweet malt. Flavor is hoppy citrus, bitter, sweet candy malts. caramel.
Pours copper orange with a beige head. Sweet aroma of caramel and apricot, as well as grass and pine...it is what it is...
bottle: pours orange with a nice miedium head.  Slight fruity smell.  Tastes lighty sweet with smooth bitter end, and lightly fruity in the middle, but not very complex or flaorful.
Tap at McRaneys.  Good standard.  Nice orangey color with a a nice dose of hops.  Very floral and fruity. Really like it.
Pours a hazy orange color with a thin white head. Aroma of hops and light pine. Flavor is citrus, pine, and sweet malt. A bit bland for an india pale ale but decent.

Bottle.A nice golden orange color with a small white head,light carbonation.Aroma of toasted grain,caramel,and resiny pine and floral hops. Flavor is balanced,quite malty at first then hoppy,spicy,floral and fruity,much sweeter as it warms. Medium body,crisp mouthfeel,and a good drinked,quite sessionable,and a pretty good IPA
Tap, bar, Kalamazoo. Hazy golden colour, white head. Aroma has floral hops. Flavour is malty, with citrus and pine hops. Bitter finish.

On tap at the Federal. Thought I had rated, but I guess not. Bright clear amber pour with gauzy foamy near-white head. Some citrus and tropical fruit hop notes; as piney as some of their other offerings. Good bit of grainy malt. Quite nice, with a smooth, crisp finish. Slick palate. Easy to drink.

Pours an amber color with a huge beige head with great retention. Very fresh, grapefruity aroma with an orange, grapefruit flavor and solid bitterness at the end. Its really a great, tasty IPA, but it lacks the stylishness and balance to put it at the very top of the list. On the West Coast, however, its hard to find a better value at between 15-18 bucks per 12 pack.
Cloudy golden with a light white head. Aroma is hoppy (grass) and some fruityness. Flavour is medium hoppy (grass and Pine) and some fruit.

Despite the sheer mind-boggling number of breweries in California alone, not that many of them have widespread national distribution. While the west coast may see far more of their beers, the east coast sees very little.




Rays of amber orange sunshine illuminate my visage while a comforter of soft white foam lazily melts into a thin ring under our dual gaze. Like a sweet swamp mist, her nose smothers with sticky orange, honey, and hop oils while lemon zest bares her teeth from the safety of cover. Wet and sticky; just the way I like it. As I am sucked into her heavy depths, I am met with a surprisingly medium body which denies to a certain extent the heavy weight of her nose. Sticky, juicy, pulpy orange drips while lemon sparkles and glints in the background, revivifying my laden tastebuds. Each quaff is clean-cut with whispers of fresh-cut grass while hop oils kiss all porous surfaces. As she warms, grassy, lemon bitterness with a concentrated purpose of honeycomb, orange pulp, and succulent hop oils slowly rise to the occasion. Deliciously quaffable, I find my glass emptier far sooner than I anticipated. My mouth thirsts for more, but alas, I shall have to wait until a later date to renew our scandalous love affair.




I think I enjoyed the Lagunitas IPA more than I did their Maximus. The balance of flavors, texture, and aroma is excellent. Not too often are regular IPAs big, wet, and sticky without being Imperial. I am extremely pleased and shall have to hunt down some more.

Bottle from Sun Devil.  Hoping it was old or something because this was underwhelming as hell.  Aroma was non-existent, flavor was like a sweet pale ale or a plain cider: very subdued, like watered-down juice.  No hops, grainy finish.

smells a ilttle hoppy with that lagunitas sweetness that i’m not sure i like. a little raisiny. pours very thin almost lager colored. the taste is hoppy at first and then just kind of fruity raisiny at the end. its just too fruity and top heavy there’s no guts to this one.

Bottle.  Poured an orange color with a small to medium off white head.  Aroma was quite good with caramel, sweet malt, citrus, melon/pineapple, and fruit.  Flavor was good, but not quite as good as the aroma.  Alot of sweet malt and caramel, perhaps more pronounced than the hops.  Melon, earthy, and citrus hops in the finish.  Solid amount of sweetness.  Solid beer.

Pours orange.  Aroma is indistinct of malt and flowery hops.  I am guilty of trying Hop Stoopid before this, which in retrospect is an obvious mistake.  Comparatively, this IPA comes out too bland, too muddy, too inferior when sizing up Hop Stoopid.  I suppose taken alone it is not all that bad:  just more caramelly-red fruit fruit than I would like out of an IPA.  The bitterness does come in at the finish, but rather passively and inharmoniously.

Fantastic Cascade aroma and flavor, but milder bitterness which I appreciate in an IPA that I want to drink more than one of.  Citrus, pineapple, a touch of sweetness, and dry to accentuate the great hop flavor
Bottle. Golden brown pour body underneath a fizy white head with good lacing. Aroma of pine hops, exotic fruits, and earthiness. Flavor was fruity hops, pine, earth and dirt. Pretty good IPA.

Bottle. Pours with a clear, copper body and covered by a fluffy, barely off-white head that leaves decent lace. Aroma is pungent with pine C-Hops, caramel, dust and lightly estery. Taste is pine hops, light citrus, caramel and tea. Creamy bubbles and mouthfeel.

Reddish-Copper pour with white head. Malt and little hop aroma. Malt flavor is more prominent than anything else. Gives a dry aftertaste  and leaves a nice malt flavor. Well-balanced beer that leaves a nice lacing on the glass. Drank it right out of the cellar(55F). Could of been a little cooler, but very tasty anyway.

Beer poors golden with a nice white head.  Aroma is subtle but has nice notes of malt and hops.  The flavor is enjoyable.  I was a bit suprised expecting a lot more hopiness but the beer was extremely drinkable.  Flavors that came out were a bit of malty sweetness with citruis and grapefruit notes.  Palate was nice with a bit of stickyness.  Overall the beer was good.  This beer would be something I would recommend as summer IPA that you could have a few of.

Pours gold.  light head no retention.  no lace.
Aroma- hoppy, spruce grass. Taste is grassy, alcohol  and falls to a bitterness. Finish is strong bitter that lingers. I’m not a fan of IPA’s.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam - one of the incredibly rare places in Europe where you can buy some US craft beer to try.

Pours a beautiful deep clear orange with minimal head that quickly disappears, leaving a fine lacing. Strong sweet hoppy aroma, chewing gum, pine resin. Taste starts out quite sweet and malty and then gradually a bit of grapefruitish hops comes through. Quite herbal, pine trees and caramel. Very flavourful for a beer of such moderate strength. Low carbonation but crisp mouthfeel. Clean smooth taste but a bit too sweet for me with not enough hop bitterness.

Golden amber body with a thick lasting tan head.  Nice aroma of pine and citrus, very fitting for an IPA.  The palate is a bit light, but pretty smooth.  The flavor is not quite a good as the aroma would lead me to believe.  Biscuit malt sweetness up front is quickly pushed aside in favor of bitter grapefruit and a hint of pine.  Not much aftertaste, just a bit of bitterness.  A decent IPA.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is light... fruity hops with a hint of grass. Taste is light for an IPA. Starts out decent with a nice hoppy flavor with an undertone of sweet malt. The aftertaste is not pleasant though. An unnatural bitterness that didn’t seem to taste right. Not a horrible IPA by any means. Just wouldn’t be the first one I would reach for from the cooler.
Fresh and clean. Aroma of cascade hops and sweet malts. Taste is sweet and hops linger a bit. Well made and very consistent.

Grassy and hoppy ipa with a rather dry earthy taste. Didn’t care much for it, just not too much going on with this one plus there was some unpleasant taste lurking in the background reminding me of carpet cleaner. I wonder if this was gone off or something.

Bottle. Amber/dark golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma: Tropical fruit, dried fruits, bisquity malt, light hops, citrus. Taste: Tropical fruit, citrus, toffee, grain, bisquity malt, menthol, a bit salty. Not very bitter or grapefruity at first, but bitterness and grape grows in the finish. Medium body and light carbonation.

Bronze with consistent carbonated bubbles feeding a thin, but resilient head. Floral hop aroma with slices of peach and apricot, and orange marmalade with a deep musk overhang, then a last dash of grapefruit and catbox. Easy hop flavor with a sold malt backbone. This one has been fridged for a year, so that may have subdued the hops a bit. Well balanced, with a mild refrain of bitterness.

With a super large I-P-A on the front of the bottle, I expected to be wowed.  This is a fair IPA with a little bit of a dirty after-taste to it.  Great color, okay balance, but need more of a hop presence.
Copper color. Citrus and sweet caramel balance. Nothing over the top. Good balance.

Bottle from De Bierkoning. Clear amber colour, light orange white head. Sweet fruity and hoppy grapefruit aroma. Flavour is fruity, citrus, grapefruit, a bit of caramel, dry hoppy bitter finish. A bit less than medium bodied. A nice "light" IPA.
12oz bottle; not too hoppy; nice starter beer for the evening; this would be a good craft to have on hand for those new to this type of beer. (#49)

Botella, courtesy of Pinball. Unclear golden amber colour with a medium frothy mostly diminishing white head. Quite hoppy fruity piney nose. Good mothfeel. Fruity hops and citrus in the flavour along with some yest, caramel and pine with a bitter well lasting finish.

golden orange red small white head.
aroma is hoppy, sweet, grapefruit 7+
flavor is sweet, hoppy, grapefruit, well composed.
another great ipa style beer from lagunitas.

Bottle thanks to roborb!
Shimmering transparent copper-amber, small, frothy beige head. Nose is very sweet, loads of caramel, burnt pb cookies, and minor tea and leafy hop. Flavor is similar but there’s more nuance, some bitterness from the hop emerging with minor grapefruit citrus. Moderate body with juicy mouth, a little salty, lingering bitterness in the finish. Overall the hops lose here, but if you don’t believe in style-points, then this is a sweet and juicy beer, very drinkable.
Pours a golden brown color with a bit of a haze, and very little head.  Pretty basic IPA, but always enjoy drinking this none the less.
Flaske. Flot mørke orange IPA. Lækker duft af humle og den umiskendelige Lagunitas terroir. Virkelig solid maltbase til at bakke humlen op med. Frisk og lækker øl. Ville elske den helt frisk.

12 oz. bottle. Initial hop nose gives way to sweet malt aroma. Taste is light and has some hop presence that is overpowered by the malt as the beer goes down. Pale gold/yellow color with a head that you wont see to the end. Very easy to drink and has low Abv for an IPA, making it seem more like a pale ale in my mind.

12 oz. bottle at Union Jack, Arlington VA.  Overall a run of the mill, but decent craft-brewed IPA.  Good bitter IPA punch like Smuttynose.  Body is thin, however.  Would like more fullness.  Tried it again 2/25/12 -- I like it more.  It has very bold IPA presence with an extremely clean finish.  A very solid IPA.

12oz bottle. $2.10 Julio’s Liquors. Very hoppy and citrusy. A good but not great IPA.

7/30/17: Not sure why I rated this so low. This has been a go to IPA for several years now. Bumping up the score to reflect reality.

A little bit of citrus and pineapple in the aroma. A little bit of bitterness, a little bit of malt. A bit on the watery side. It’s almost like a ’lite’ version of what could be a really tasty West Coast IPA.
TAP: at Stub & Herb’s, 2.22.09. Clear orange pour, mild head, pine hop aroma, well-balanced, slightly dry on the finish but not bitter. Outstanding flavor, and a good malt backbone.

Clear copper with a slightly off white head.  Lots of citrus and floral hops in the aroma.  Taste is very much on the hoppy side, with citrus/grapefruit qualities balanced with light caramel maltiness.  Nice crisp bite in the palate and a lingering, bitter finish.

Nice crisp hop aroma of pine and pine needles.
Poured a clear light iced tea color with a copper hue. Frothy white head with some action and no sediment, this was a twist off bomber.
Great complexity of flavors including pine and pine needles and maybe some tangerine. The malts are blended within and have hints of caramel and maybe grain (barley).
Medium bodied, very resinous, with lively yet soft carbonation.
Great blend of hops, says 43 different hops on the bottle. As a courtesy I think they should have a born on date since this bomber had a twist off cap, they do not keep the freshness as long as the solid sealed caps.

(35.5cl bottle) Slightly hazy, amber colour with a short off-white foamy head. Sweet cara-malty and slightly toasted aroma with biscuits and a delicate hoppy touch with lemon-fruity and slightly woody notes. Bitter-sweet flavour, medium bodied with a smooth carbonation. Aromatic and complex malt-character with notes of biscuits, caramel, licorice and subtle fruity and woody hoppy accents. Almost dry, malty finish with a good bitterness-sweetness ratio and light to moderate but aromatic hops (18.II.09).

This poured a nice copper color with a big fluffy white head. Aroma was bittering hops and some mlatiness as well. Flavor was some what bitter, but not much of hop flavor, but sweet malts instead. Not a bad beer, but not too great for an IPA
Pours an orange color with a nice white head.  Nose of floral hops, pine and citrus.  The taste was nice grapefruit, hops and some caramel - a solid IPA.
Clear amber with nice tight head.  Citrus nose with slight malt notes.  Well balanced hop and malt, mainly hoppy but malt is right there maintaining a balance.  Palate is full and creamy.  Nice brew.

This is a great beer!  This brewery knows its stuff.  The flavors of this beer jump out at you.  I find myself truly enjoying every sip.  About a quarter inch of head after the pour which stayed until the first sip a few minutes later.  The hops were very rich .  Overall this is one of my favorite beers and breweries.

Purchased a single 12-oz bottle at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a semi-clear, copper-amber brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of both pine and citrus zest, a hint of caramel and some light spice. Taste is medium bodied, some citrus zest, a hint of grapefruit and caramel malt. Finish is slightly metallic, with a short lived, mild bitterness.
Bottle pours amber/light orange color with off white head.  Aroma is malt and some citrus.  Must not be fresh.  Flavor is more of the same as the aroma.  Overall just an ok ipa.

On tap at the Nut House in Palo Alto.  Pretty solid showing if nothing spectacular. Golden-amber appearance with white head.  Piney aroma.  Piney hop flavors are there, along with sweet malt and good bitterness.  Medium palate.  Nothing special but a nice west coast IPA overall.
golden and red with mild head.  flavor lacks on the malt balance, with some strong hop bitterness, lacking somewhat on the the hop flavor profile.  disappointing for a west coast ipa

Very good IPA, on draught at Plan B, starting to really like this brewer and the IPA doesnt dissapoint. coppery color, almost caramel, not very hazy with an off white head that clings for awhile. typical IPA flavor of pine and citrus with just the right kick, hoppy finish that asks poitely for another mouthful.
Copper in color with a good sized white head. Aroma is of pine and citrus. Taste is of hops, caramel and toffee.

Poured a nice rich copper color with a big fluffy white head that dissipated rather slowly. The aroma was of fresh hops; citrusy with touch of pine. The flavor starts with a bit of malt up front then the hop takes over a provides great balance. The mouthfeel is very nice. The drinkability of this one is very high as the relatively low abv makes it one easy drinker.
This was a good, refreshing brew but the hop profile makes it fee more like an American Pale Ale and not an IPA

Brewed in the USA........ Pours a copper color with some mild carbonation and a very thin white head. Aroma of spices, hops and grapefruit. Taste is of citrus, pine needles and caramel. The mouthfeel is refreshing, but i wish it were alittle more hoppy. Overall, This was a pleasant pale ale and i would like to drink another.

[Bottled from Fish and beer, Copenhagen.]
Deep amber with a creamy, tan head.
Soft, grassy, smooth, hoppy aroma and flavour with light toffee.
Slightly vinous with a dry, medium bitterness.
12oz bottle. Good beer. Lacks a real hoppy punch, but a nice beer to have around. Pours a pretty small head.

Re-Rate 11/19/2014, original rate 1/7/2009: Definitely better than my original rating. Nice, clear gold pour with a 1 finger, creamy to soapy white head. Flavor and aroma wise it’s actually a decently well rounded IPA with some decent pine, citrus and cereal grain notes. Light to medium body, kinda syrupy.              Original rating: Pours a cloudy dark amber with a 2 finger buttery tan head that lasts long enough for me to research infected beers and come back to it. The atricle on infected beer said that the giant greeinsh tan chunks that are in this beer may be only precipitated proteins, but damn do they look nasty, I mean they are huge, I am used to getting occasional yeast floaties but these look like someone threw cornflakes in the beer, I am a little apprehensive but as the aroma seems normal if not a bit weak for an IPA I will soldier on. Aroma is sweet caramel, honey, a little toast, some citrus and some pine hops really weak though. Flavor is.....here it goes not turning back now...strange and weak fo an IPA. Not really in a oh my god I am drinking giant bacteria colonies kinda way...more of a really weak take on the IPA style kinda way. Caramel and toffee in the begining, then a little citrus and pine, some straw in there too. It actually seems like it may be a well rounded beer if it were doubled, good thing Maximus is up next...hope it looks better! Body is thin and somewhat under carbonated.
Tap at Papago.  Pours a filtered copper color with a creamy off-white head.  Mild with citrus and hops.  Neither aggressive or ambitious.  Balanced, but seemingly uninspired.
6 pack 12oz bottles. Good everyday drinkin IPA. Nice hoppy grapefruit aroma.
aroma has a nice hop/orange, appearance is a little lite flavor is out of this world with a lot of hops , citrus, grapefruit , orange / overall this is a great IPA
Bottle from Premier Gourmet.  Pours dark amber in colour, with nice head.  Hoppy in both aroma and flavour.  A good IPA.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a crystal clear golden color with a nice white head that has decent retention and good lacing.  Aroma is a nice mellow, not too in your face citrus hop.  Very nice, but I was expecting it to be a bit larger.  Flavor is orange/citrus fruit.  There is a slight bitterness to it but, again...I was hoping for a bit more.  Overall, this is a good beer but it’s a bit too mellow for me as an IPA.  I don’t know...maybe it just me.  Good beer though.

Thanks for the bottle JoeMcPhee. Great aroma of honey, spices, raisins and plenty of hops. hazy copper with a decent white frothy head. Flavour is sharp, citrus fruit and grapefruit. As i drink more I’m getting oranges and more grapefruit flavours coming through with some hops. This is a very tasty IPA, can be sharp but steels to a delicious brew. Very enjoyable IPA.

12 oz. bottle at Beer Bistro in Toronto.
The color is a hazy amber with a thin beige head. The aroma and taste are of hops. Also in the taste is a sweet malty caramel feel to it, you can also taste some citrus fruits. The finjsh is a nice bitterness of an I.P.A.
I am not a big fan of IPAs but I definitely enjoyed this one. Very smooth and flavorful, without the overwhelming aftertaste of hops

Clear, deep amber appearance with an average size, white head and good lacing.  Resinous hop aroma.  Ample, sweet, caramel malt backbone allows the huge variety of hops to bounce around and develop flavors of grapefruit, orange, pine and herbs.  Medium bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel.  Bitter, lingering finish.  Could be a good everyday IPA, if you like piney hops.

12 oz. bottle - Poured rich copper color with small head.
Aroma - grapefruit, lemon, light pine and subtle hops. 
Flavor - tasted more malt than hops. Weak for an IPA, no hop bite??
Palate - medium mouthfeel with average carbonation. Finish is slightly dry with little aftertaste.
Overall - very drinkable and not what I would consider an IPA. For first time IPA drinkers
Had a couple pints at the King Street Bar. Kind of warm but pretty tasty. I have always liked the copy associated with Lagunitas beers, but 43 different hops? That sounds crazy, and crazy expensive.
Bottle, at breakfast, during EBF 2008, Copenhagen. Amber with a good white head that leaves lot of lace on the glass. Soft yet full bodied and tasty. Very drinkable - an approachable American IPA.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy amber gold with a moderate linen white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left very little lace.  Very pleasnt hoppy aroma of grapefruit and pine, with more emphasis on the citrus.  Some notes of malt are also present.  The flavor is malt up front, albeit a bit restrained, followed by a strong dose of grapefruit and pine hops, again with more emphasis on the grapefruit.  The finish is especially bitter, akin to the white pith of a grapefruit.  A good IPA, but the bitterness is a bit over the top for me.  This one is for the hopheads.

Bottle from total wine.  Copper pour.  Small white head.  Hoppy aroma to say the least.  Spicy and citrus notes stand out.  Flavor kicks your taste buds with some pretty bitter hops.  Decent malt backbone.  Not bad, but a tad bitter for my preference.

(10/26/08) Bottle at Spuyten Duyvil in Brooklyn. Clear amber color with a bit of white foam. Aroma of floral hops. Sweetish flavor with some malt and bready notes at first and afterwards nice refreshing bitter hops with a bit of citric notes. A nice quaffable IPA.

12 oz bottle, pours a clear copper color with minimal head. Aroma is very intense and hoppy with a distinct fresh floral quality. Taste is overwhelmingly bitter as advertised but is also balanced out by a bit of sweetness. Palate is kind of rough given the bitterness but is very satisfying. Good option.

Huge ass hop flavor, though not nearly as much so as my beloved Maximus. Nice copper colored pour with a decent white head that sticks around and a nice bitter hop conclusion. Solid amount of malt in the finish that stays out of the way enough to keep me happy.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are malt, hops, flowers and fruits.

Poured from a bottle into a pilsner glass.  First time I was a bit shaky, it made a huge head that ran over the glass.  After that smoother pours resulted in a medium head.  VERY hoppy. Label says "suicidally hoppy."   I’m really more of a dark beer drinker, but I thought I liked hops.  This beer is too much though. All I can taste is the hops.  Doesn’t sit well in my stomach.  

It would probably rate really high among IPA lovers, but stout drinkers approach with caution!

Pours a slightly hazy orange with a small to medium sized white head.  Ample aromas of hops and citrus with a hint of pine, and a soft undercurrent of malt.  Hops come right out in the mouth mellowing for a moment, and then slowly fading into a mildly bitter finish.  I find myself going to this beer quite often as a casual IPA that is very approachable, and very affordable.

pours a copper colour with a large off white head.
Aroma was wicked grapefruit and white grape juice as well as light floral tones. Flavour is citrusy hop, some caramel malt body through the back end, a nice clean bitter finish.
Excellent IPA.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of ucusty. Thanks! Pours a clear amber color with a medium white head, average retention and great lacing. Sweet floral hop aroma. Taste is citrus and leafy hops with some sweet malts. Medium body.

Crushed with Honkeybra.  Lots of awesome floral hops on the nose.  Gave way to...nothing.  This is the Calista Flockhart of ipa’s: probably smells and looks nice, but absolutely no body whatsoever.  Flavor is severely lacking in anything related to a ipa.

Crushed with TheDude at Budde’s pizza in Galesburg, IL. Looks nice, golden with some hops. Smells really nice, beautiful floral hops. However, this beer has no body. Just hops and  Very disappointing.
Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.  Light amber, clear.  Hoppy, light fruit aroma.  Nice hoppy flavor and dry finish.  Liked it a lot.
Pour is orange with thin head. Aromas of hops, faint citrus, and malt. Tastes is nicely balanced with malt and hop flavors. Good beer.

Copper color with a large head.  Light grassy aroma.  Malty flavor with some caramel finishing it up.  No hops.  None.  Not even a residule bitterness.  43 different hops?  It doesn’t seem like they even used one.  If this had been labeled an Amber, it would have been great.  As it is, it is an okay tasting brew that is completely disappointing considering the label on it.

Draft at Loki Music Festival.  Pours a light amber beer with a decent orangish head.  Aroma is hoppy and citrus fruit.  Flavor is your typical hoppy IPA.  End is bitter and a little bit dy.  Great beer very drinkable

A nice and true IPA.  Fairly normal color.  Hoppy scent with some type of sweetness in the background.  But then again if you’re using 43 different hops in it, then that’s probably part of the sweeter scent I can smell.  One or more of these hops probably has a sweeter scent than others.  Has a nice hoppy taste with a great aftertaste.  I heard good things about this one and it lived up to the hype.

Great malty I.P.A.  I like how this brew stands out from the crowd. Flavors of caramel, citrus, and roasted malt.  Very close to an A.S.A imo, a bit alc and it would be there.  Well rounded drinkable IPA
Nice IPA. Pours a bright amber with light orange head that dissapears quickly leaving a medium lace. Aroma is great - a big orange citrus marmalade bouquet. Good Palate, with medium astringecy.

On the thinner side in terms of body for an IPA.... There was a slight astringency to the hops i thought, though the overall flavor aside is quite nice... The balance is quite nice, very very drinkable for an IPA...
Poured light amber with light head and nice lace. Very good blend of hops with a light malty bottom. Good dry finish aswell.

Pours clear light amber with light head and nice lace.  Wonderful hop aroma smells like fresh wildflowers and grass.  Malty base with sweet edge is also evident.  Mouthfeel is unremarkable, but not bad.  Taste is weak compared to the aroma.  Little bit on the front end, hop flavor is more like dried wood with herby edge.  Alcohol is totally not evident.  Tastes good, but I’d rather bathe in the aroma all day.

(Bottle).   Huge resiny and citrus hops aroma.  Orange-amber body, off-white head.  Flavor is medium-sweet citrus (lemon and orange) plus malt.  Nowhere near the bitterness of, say, DFH.   Almost closer to an APA.   Subtle dry finish.  Refreshing, but not eye-popping.

From bottle.  Part of April Dayton Beertastring event.
Pours light amber color with a solid inch  white head.Aromas of citrus, piney hops and malt. Thinner than expected.  Short finish.

Had this at the Orsted cafe/bar, Kobenhaven 13-09-08   Poured amber with a white bubbly head. This had a good hoppy aroma tinged with some malt and light alcohol. Hoppiness getting better and quite mushy, good beer but not quite up to the level of the Pale Ale that we’d also tried.

6-pack from Total Wine, River Edge, NJ...bottle pours clear amber with a white head...aroma of tangerine and pine...flavor includes the same with a nice hops presence and mild bitterness...thin but smooth mouthfeel, thin lacing...easy drinking IPA.

Bottle from Ølbutikken.
Lovely golden beer with rocky head. Aroamtic and bitter hops, fruit, pines, the works. Full sweet body underneath.

Bottle (Orsted Olbar, Copenhagen)

Nutty US hop aroma, quite pleasant. Similar US mouthfeel, but ends a bit flat. There’s a plain bitterness, and some plastic in the taste. Smells nicer than it tastes. At least the hops don’t build obnoxiously. Docking a couple of points overall for the utterly wanky commercial description. Someone kill whoever wrote that. (6-3-6-3-8=2.6)

Rerate: 355ml bottle (Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam) (6-3-5-3-8=2.5)

Pleasant piney hop aroma, nothing particularly special, and certainly nothing like an IPA. Perfumed and fruity soapy taste. Finish is astringent, grassy, and metallic. Commercial description still wank - "unique version" just means "unable to make anything like the original version". Why be so proud of their own inabilities?

average white (mostly lasting) head into copper body.  aromas of moderate grapefuit and moderate toffee.  flavor is initially light bitter and finishes moderately sweet.  long finish duration.  watery to dry texture.  damn fine IPA.
On tap at Mgoos.  Amber, very slightly cloudy with nice floral hops odor and good mix of floral and dry hops, just a little thin, but nice clean finish

bottle poured a light amber color with a two finger white head that fell slowly. aroma has piney hops, lighter citrus, and mild caramel malt. mouth feel is on the lighter side with medium high carbonation. resinous piney citrus hop leads into a thinly malted brew. somewhat thin for such a hopped beer but lending nice flavors. bitterness smacks it down and perfumey.
Pours orange with an off white head. Nice citrusy hop aroma. Flavor is more of the same; nice and clean. Lacking a bit of body, and a bit of secondary flavor, but still tasty and enjoyable.
Bottled. Clear orange golden color, short head. Aroma of some hop and grapefruit, hint of caramel. Bit fruity as well. Taste is only moderately bitter, firm malty body. Crisp. Nice IPA.
I’m not a fan of super hoppy beers and tend to shy away from IPA’s, but this is a great beer.  This is pleasant drinkable IPA.

12 oz bottle - Nothing better than the smell of a solid IPA.  Lagunitas is a very good brewing company and considering I can find it all the way on the opposite coast of the US says alot about it.  Ranks right up there with the Sierra Nevada Anniversary Ale I just drank although not nearly as bitter.  Good IPA
Pours a red amber colour... medium white head... good malt flavour, with an outstanding strong balance of hops... definitely one of the best american IPA beers you will ever have....

Pours a crisp, clear amber with a medium off-white head. Wonderfully sweet aroma of hops, orange, caramel malts. The initial sweetness is fantastic, but the hop finish is just off. the bitterness isn’t really there and and the taste falls off into something a little bland. But the body is smooth and the caramel malts shine through.

Poured orange/red with a medium sized foamy white head. It smells of fruit, citrus, a little bit of hops. Taste is not very bitter, kind of an earthy hop taste. The aftertaste doesn’t linger long and this would make a good session beer. It seems like it missing something that could make it even better.

Pours a copper orange with a one finger creamy light yellow head. The nose was very resinous and hoppy, sweet, citrusy, lightly piny and earthy, spicy, mandarin orange. The flavor is mostly earthy herbal hops, lightly citrusy, some pink grapefruit. The mouthfeel could have been more substantial.

Pours copper with a thin off-white head. Has a sweet fruity aroma. Nice flavor that has a little more malt than I expected for this IPA, but the hops balance out these malts nicely and leave you with a bitter finish.
pours a copper amber with mild head, light hop citrus aroma.  Light on the palate and bitterness, citrus on the back, good stuff.
12 oz. bottle. Pours a nice head, pleasant golden copper color, nose of spice, bit of pine, with malt overtones, initial tastes of spice, then hop bitterness.

Bottle pours clear amber with thin white head. Aroma is sweet malt. First taste is sweet fruit and malt with slight hops bitterness which balances out. There is a mild citruis hops finish and the carbonation is perfect.

On tap at Mcmenamins on the Columbia.


Pours medium amber in color with an off-white head and very clear.  Very unique flavor.  The hops are good and definitely there as well as a nice cinnamon spice note.  Very interesting ginger soy sauce flavor.  Not my first choice for an IPA but points for originality!
Not a fresh bottle.  Had to pour slowly to keep the quarter inch of sediment down. Dark amber.  Almost no head because of cautious pour. Lots of great flavors.  Pine, citrus, bitter, yummmmmmmy.
Fantastic IPA.  Crisp and clean.  Citrus in the initial taste, somewhat spicy.  Smooth, hoppy flavor in the finish.

Pours a cloudy dark golden color with a lush foamy head that clings to the side of the glass.  Their are some chunks of yeast floating around in my glass as well!  The aroma is very rich with toffee, caramel, citrus, and some pine.  The palate is light on the carbonation and smaller than I would have predicted for a Lagunitas beer.  The flavor seems skewed toward the malty for an IPA.  Not bad, but different.

pours a clear copper with little head. Aroma strong of citrus, particularly grapefruit, orange, and lemon. Flavor is similar, with more hop bite and a nice bitter aftertaste. Tasty brew, different than your typical IPA, but still nice.

this does not drink like an IPA.  i had it out of a bottle, and it tasted sweet and sugary, with a strong grapefruit flavor.  it tastes much more like linenkugel’s sunset wheat than a normal pale ale.  in fact, it tastes it tastes a lot like lemon-lime soda.  however, it does have a decent aroma, but the aroma does not match an IPA.  i bought this beer expecting an IPA and i was very disappointed.

Had this while on vacation in CA.  A wonderful beer to have on tap at so many "regular" places.  Though a relatively simply mix of hops and malt, still so much more to this beer than what one usually finds when out at a family resteraunt.
Bottled at Ørsted Ølbar, Copenhagen.  Clear amber,small head. Aroma of grapefruit. Lots of caramelly malt, more so than hops. Above medium bodied with good levels of bitterness.
