Bottle.  Pours a clear orange, with a two-finger head.  Aroma of citrus hops and a bit of malt.  The flavor is assertively hoppy, though well-balanced with malts.  Bready aftertaste, and very bitter.  Solid, but there are many better IPAs out there.
on Tap@hill tavern. Dark red color, beige head, aroma is hoppy, roasted malt and caramel, flavor is refreshing and some note of hop and fruit. Mouthdeel is bitter.

This is a huge hop beer.  Almost over the top.  The nose seems to be mostly Cascades with some other hops rounding it out.  The flavor is big hoppy, but there is some maltiness to help balance it out.  I’m not sure if I could drink more than one of these at a time due to the hoppiness.
Bottle. Pours copper orange with a beige head. Sweet aroma of caramel and apricot, as well as grass and pine. Flavor is also sweet with grapefruit, caramel, and grass. Finish is long and bitter.
Small disappearing head. Aroma of hops and citrus. Nice flavor. More mild then what I was expecting. Hop bite lingers a bit on the tongue. Balanced with caramel and malt. Good brew. Very drinkable.

Huge head. This is quite a fruity IPA, from the aroma of citrus and berries, to the strawberry color, to the abundant flavors of strawberries, cherries - quite unique and odd to the style - moderate hops and a strong, biscuit-like malt backbone for the fruit flavors to play off of

(Bottle, Ölbaren, Copenhagen, 26 July 2008) Amber colour with frothy, beige head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of caramel, orange and toasted grain. Malty, fruity taste with grain, caramel, orange and citrussy hops in a balanced finish. Nicely balanced IPA. Good beer.
On tap everywhere--An old standby--Poured a copper amber body with a medium white head.  Dank, citrus hops and a hardly malty spine.  Well-built brew.

Overall a VERY good IPA. I can’t believe I never rated this. Copper with white head, but this is the perfect half-way mark between the dank, skunky IPA’s that are Blind Pig and Maximus, and the light, refreshing IPA’s that are Anderson Valley and Two Hearted. It also has that bright yeast flavor that adds to the IPA if done right.

Aroma is very strong of hops and florals. Taste is very hoppy but it has a smooth finish that makes the beer. Great IPA, a little better than the double (wish there was a hundreth space) but maybe i just see it being more sessionable.

This here might be the most drinkable IPA I’ve ever had. Honey-amber in color, with a scent mostly of honey, with hints of malted grain and leafy, floral hops. Flavor is very dry, bitter and grassy, yet with touches of bread, and strangely enough, peas. That’s right. Peas. Gnarly.

Good IPA. Not great but good. There is nothing to dislike about this beer. There is a faint aroma of hops. The taste was similar. I found the flavor to be somewhat lacking. It is incredibly smooth and easy to drink. Knocking back a sixer would not be much of a challenge. If it’s available for a good price try it, if not, there are better IPAs for the money.

Very floral initial palate and smell.  Slight grapefruit that discipates quickly due to slight sweeteness from the malts.  The carmel flavor helps mellow the hops.  Not the strongest hoppy IPA but hops are certainly evident and well balanced.  One of the better IPA I enjoy on a regular basis.

Not very good. Fizzy and bitter taste, but not the good kind of bitterness. More of a peppery bitterness than I like. It is also kind of watery. Burnt toast malt taste does not complement the hops very well. Pretty drinkable though.

Poured into a pint glass and it pours an amber color. It has a very nice head that disapates about half way down the glass. It is consistant and well balanced through out. There are strong hop notes in the flavor and the aroma. The malt backbone helps mellow the hoppiness and makes it a bit sweet. It doesn’t sit well on the palate in the long run but it is  good drinker none the less.

Amber color with creamy off-white head.  Sweet and hoppy aroma with hints of earthy and piney spice .  Pretty mellow flavor with an IPA.  Obvious hoppiness but really mellowed out by caramel maltiness.  A nice smooth IPA that almost seems more like an Am. Pale Ale.
Small white head sits atop a clear dark golden brew; not too strong on the hoppy side or the malt side.  A real nice IPA.
From standard 12oz bottle-> Nice IPA, quality beer here, great hop aftertaste like a casacade of goodness flowing through your mouth.  Makes me happy.

Impressive IPA.  Tons of hops.  Makes it sharp bitter, but the abundance of malts balances and saves this one from the junk pile.  Good.  Not great, could be better.  Add some spcies and fruit and you got the money.

hazy golden pour, small offwhite pour that . wonderful citrusy, light grapefruit sharp hop aroma.  light but good mouthfeel, lemony, slightly floral, lots goin on here, yet it remains simple somehow.   very refreshing and drinkable.  quite enjoyable

Bouteille de 355 ml bu au Beer Bistro (Toronto), le 11/7/08. Jaune ambrée, petit collet. Arome d’houblon un peu amère, des notes de pêches. Goût d’houblon pas très fort, un peu amère et légèrement fruité. Un IPA simple et plaisant!

12 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a 1/2 finger thick off white head.  Very light spotty lacing.   Has a sharp hop aroma.  Citrus, pine, and herbal.  Flavor is bitter hops with some light malt backing.  The aftertaste just doesn’t sit right.  Light to medium body.  A decent IPA but doesn’t stand up to the Big Boys.

12 oz bottle. Poured copper in color with a beige head. Aroma of citrus hops and sweet floral hops, with a caramel malt backbone. Tastes of grapefruit, floral hops, caramel, lemongrass, and a little metallic hop taste in the finish.  Its a very drinkable IPA.

bottle... poured into my finally-aquired Lag pint glass.  Clear, light copper color with not much of a head.  Aromas underwhelm... some floral earthy hop notes blend with sweet caramel.  Flavors start with light citrus and floral hop notes.  Some orange peels, lemon zest, and grassy notes.  Backbone holds up nicely with a not-overly-sweet toasted caramel bread malt flavor.  A bit of a metallic twang in there.  A bit thin on the palate, with a bit of hop bitterness sticking around.  I’m a big Lagunitas fan, but I can’t say I’d necessarily recommend this IPA over some others available in the area.

Bottle (35 cl) from Ølbutikken. Shady golden/amber, large white head. Earthy and slightly caramelly malt aroma with apricot-like hops.Medium bodied with chewy mouthfeel. Well balanced, dry finish, firm bitterness.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.
Pours a light amber, off-white head. Aroma of grapefruit. Faint flavor of grain, obvious hops, with a very nice hop bitter, nicely balanced. Palate is med-body with med-high carbonation.....Overall, an excellent IPA.

clear light amber body with a bit of a white head. There is a typical aroma with grapefruit, lime and a bit of cherry?  The flavor is a kind of grassy IPA flavor with a lingering sweetness of melon on the finish. Not too big.

Pretty hoppy and pretentious like the label. Too much going on in this one for me to really like it. It’s solid but not exceptional. Pretty good once it warms up more toward room temp. Maybe buy again

On draught at ’Rocks’ in Chicago.  Color was deep amber with frothy off-white head.  Aroma VERY hoppy, strong citrus, with accents of pine, flowers, and grass.  Taste was malty, with bitter hop bite and citrus.  Medium mouthfeel, pretty good beer, but I’m not a huge hophead.

Aroma is a strong citrus hop scent.  Color is a bright golden with good carbonation and a nice head.  Taste is juicy and bitter.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with what I can only describe as a juicy feel.  Finish starts with a sweet malt taste that turns quickly to a citrus, little lemon and a bitter bite.  In the aftertaste the citrus brightens for a moment then fads leaving you with a mild bitterness.  This is a fabulous IPA, its well balanced.  Nicely bitter with a good malt tone and they keep the citrus in line.
Pours dark amber with a large head. Fresh citrus and hops are the predominate aroma. Nice amount of hops, for an IPA. Not too dominate but, a significant part of the flavor profile.

Pours a pretty nice copper color with a white head with pretty nice retention. Smell is of caramel and sticky pine sap, floralness as it warms. Pine sap taste in the beginning, a little bit of biscuit in there as well. Hops are definately the lead role, piney, resinous, some citrus too. High carbonation, medium bodied. This is not the best IPA I’ve had, but it’s a damn solid one, of which I could see myself drinking plenty of.

bottle thanks to metzlers in denton, tx.  poured a clear amber with beige head.  aroma was hoppy of course and some caramel malts.  flavor was good with hops and some grassy notes.  over all pretty good!!

12 oz bottle. pours clear light burnt orage with a white head. Aoma is hops pine and a little citrus and malt. Flavor is light on the complexity side. Basically hops, citrus, caramel and some pine. Mouthfeel is a bit on the watery side. Bit disapointing from a brewery that usually produces solid brews.

Tap.  Pours a hazy orange/golden color with a puffy and slightly tan head.  Aroma is heavy pine hops with slight fruity hops at the end of the nose.  Taste is pine needle up front, with citrus hops and a slight malty finish.  A very solid IPA, on the whole.
Pours golden/orange with thick off white head.  Huge piney, hop aroma.  Taste is pine, and citrus hops.  Aroma was better than the flavor.  Still a decent IPA.

On Tap - Taco Mac, ATL. 
Great IPA. Nice golden color - great hoppy taste to this. Have had a few better IPAs, and a lot worse. Definitely worth a try.

Poured a clear bright golden amber with a nice creamy, foamy head. Mild malty grass aroma with hints of hops. INitial crisp taste with just a mild hoppines. A little bitterness develops on the finish.
nice amber color. definite cascade overtones in the nose and immediately in the flavor. Sweet malt with an end that was really dry, kind of like white toast. Middle of the road IPA Imo

typical IPA pour, dark amber, orange color, good head, and nice sticky lacing on the glass. Nice fresh aromas of citrus, lots of grapefruit, and a touch of pine. Not much malt here, and the hops are a little tame in the flavour, a solid IPA, nothing to knock your socks off, just a good daily drinker.
Bottle. Pours light, clear orange with a white head. Aroma is citrus, grass and oranges. Taste is smooth, balanced, lightly bitter and hoppy. Highly drinkable though not incredibly flavorful.

from a bottle, pours the standard copper color.  Something was off in the aroma, it sorta smelled like new shoes or fresh leather.  kinda wierd.  After gettin past the aroma the flavor was good. piney, citrusy hops with some malt background.  i’ll have to revisit this.

Draught at Woody’s in downtown Raleigh.  Pours copper, with a medium white head, and lacing.  Aroma is very hoppy, with a bit of pine and grapefruit. Flavor is similar, with a decent malk backbone and caramel.  Excellent beer.

22 oz. bottle.  Very strong, piney, hoppy aroma made concerned I was about to be hit over the head with a bunch of hops.  I was pleasantly surprised how well balanced the flavor was.  Nice malt background, with piney, grapefruity hops in the foreground.  Slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Looks fizzy in the glass, but nice level of carbonation.  Really liked the whole balance and composition of this brew, which is saying a lot, since I’m not a big IPA fan.

This IPA is definenlty the most interesting IPA I’ve had. Everything id typical of an IPA except the flavor. To use that many hops in on ebatch of beer and still make it taste good is a gift. A gift from the Lord Himself I believe. This is a well rounded IPA in every sence. This was my first IPA that spun my head around when I first tried it cause I wasn’t used to all those hops yet. Then when I was, and tried a lot of different IPAs I came back to this one and was very impressed. Quite intreging indeed... hmmmm. I like it alot.

This beer was insane. A hop explosion, as well as lingering after taste that was damn near as good as taking a sip. I don’t even think I rated my inamorato, Two Hearted a 9 in the flavor section, but this is I think tied up with my home state hero. Had it on tap at the Box bar in plymouth michigan.

Pours a orange-copper color with light white head and minimal lacing.  Piney aroma is very prevalent upon pour, after it settles a bit, a grapefuit flavor emerges.  Not as hoppy as expected but still nice, touched by a hint of malt.  Very light on the palate and light to medium bodied.  Pretty good brew.

Bottle. Aroma of piney and floral hops, some citrus. Flavor an interesting concoction of all the luscious hop notes and some nicely rich caramel malt. Rich toffee notes really do wonders to accent all that pine. Maybe not as powerful as other IPA’s, but an interesting take that definitely floated my boat.

Bottle.  Pours a clear orange/amber with a huge, creamy white head.  Aroma and flavor of piney, bitter hops with some citrus, salt.  Good, chill, and refreshing.  This really hits the spot after 6 or so glasses of super sour lambics on a 90 degree day sitting outside in the heat.  I would try it again in other conditions, of course.
Lagunitas India Pale Ale is a deep amber color with a perfectly formed orange head. The aroma is soft and mossy. The taste is very clean with a great bitter hop base and quick finish.

Bottle at Zum Biergarten, Copenhagen. Thin, white bubbly head over a brown-orange body. Malt-fruity aroma. Bitter orange tones in flavour with a bitter malty ending. Moderate palate. Good drinkability, but a bit one dimensional for an IPA (30.05.2008).

Nice IPA with a lovely malt profile. The hoppy ending is less coating and crispy that I expected for an american IPA. Rather big flaked sediment blurred this and made the appearance less nice though. Refreshing IPA with a decent - or should I say "adequate" - alcohol burden.

sample on 6/5/08, rating from notes.  pours a golden color with a decent white head.  huge hop profile on the nose... a little disappointed that this didn’t carry through all the way to the finish.  however, it is a solid IPA that is very drinkable - and under 6% making this a great session beer.  the palate is typical of a generic American IPA.  Medium body, average carbonation... and a good bitter finish.  Just wish those hops came through more.

A mild yet tasty offering.  It’s not too overwhelming that a rookie IPA drinker couldn’t handle it.  Mostly sweet, with a finishing bitterness that balances everything out.  Orange in color, a thin white head.

Appearance: Pours a crystal clear, yellow-orange body with a full, foamy, white head.

Smell: Pale maltiness along with notes of spice, pine, and ruby red grapefruit.

Taste: Lightly sweet pale malts with a hint of spent grain. Spicy, piney, citrusy hop flavors. Medium bitterness. A final taste of caramel. Finishes with a light bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Just barely medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: A fine little American IPA, it delivers pretty much what you’d expect from it.

Very good IPA that seems to have both floral and pine and citrus hops to it. It is bitter enough to be an IPA but not enough to be a particulaly brutal one. Very smooth like a good bitter. Pretty simple actually, but very good none the less.
The aroma is malty with caramel and pine/citrus hops. The appearance is amber with a good head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. I really like this one.
decent, the malts are nice but the hops kinda fall flat which is what they wanted to go on. still its some malts character with caramel flavor. enjoyable.
Pour is amber, piney aroma that is the high  point of this beer, after the first sip the beer becomes an amber ale, sweet and malty with a light hop flavor.  relatively heavy mouthfeel

Pour is medium golden with long lasting white fluffy head.  Aroma is of fresh crisp hops and some pine.  Flavor is up front hoppy with some malt aftertaste.  I’m guessing that with all of the different hops and malts used in this, it must have been made with all of the extra ingredients from the brewery.  I can’t see a reason to add that many ingredients to a beer.  There is no possible way for someone to distinguish each flavor in the beer.  It is actually a physical impossibility because our tongue is not that sensitive.  Still a good beer.  May buy again.
On tap at the Map Room in Chicago.  A pretty good IPA. nothing to write home about.

A decent IPA. The aroma is really grassy even for an IPA. Overall I enjoyed it, but it didn’t have the fully rounded taste that other IPAs like Stone’s has. A pretty plain, average IPA. I’ll probably stick to Stone and Dogfish Head.

Clear light amber body with a short lived tan head.  Not a pronounced aroma but a nice one.  It is full of hop with pine and floral notes along with some caramel malt.  A big tart hop bite nips the back of the throat at first sip but that quickly fades to a dry bitterness.  Grapefruit, grass and floral flavors.  108 varieties of hop and malt?!  A good IPA but not quite exceptional.

Lagunitas ipa is opaque amber in color and when poured into a shaker, yeilds a thick foamy head.  It has scents of pine and citrus that entice your tongue.  Once you finally taste it you find that the hops have a nice bitterness to them which continue to follow into the aftertaste. I am still new to reviewing beers but i found this to be one of the best ipa’s i have tried so far.

Aggressive pour left a three-finger head above an orange/amber body with lots of rising carbonation. Moderate pine and citrus - grapefruit - hops aromas, but not overpowering. Hops flavors are strong, but immediately countered by a light maltiness. Hops bitterness lingers in the aftertaste. Medium bodied, less carbonation than expected.
Bottle. Light amber coloured with a nice lasting white head. Aromas of pine, grapefruit and some sweet malt. Flavour of bitter hops, caramel and more hops.

Orange-blonde with a thick rocky head. Aromas of citron, pine and spices. Snappy bitter flavor. Very fizzy on the palate. This has been a go-to session beer for me for a while. One of the best Bay Area IPAs for sure.
Clear, golden-amber with lasting head.  Fresh citrus-grapefruit, and mild caramel notes.  Mild sweet malt caramel and citrus-grapefruit hops.  Refreshing, with the expected bitter finish.

bottle. pours hazy orange with white head. a piney grapefruity nose. flavors are grapefruit and pine. very solid drinkable american example of the style. nothing really surprising but it does the job a good ipa does.
An okay IPA. More ingredients than usually = a bit over average, which means it’s delicious and nice with its fresh wellhopped flavor. Nice and more..

Amber with medium white slowly dissipating head.  Aroma of citrus and floral hops with some caramel and pine.  Decently balanced with enough malt to mix with the hops that do slightly win out in the end.  Not an overpowering bitter finish, a little dry with notes of grapefruit & earthy hops.

I haven’t rated this one yet?  This was recommended to me b the guys at Willow Bend Liquors in Lutz, FL.  Compared to the Dogfish varieties 60/90.  An incredible IPA with a fresh and perfectly intense hoppy taste balanced by malts.  This is smooth and refreshing.  An incredibly good IPA if not one of the best on the market.
I think this is a solid IPA with great flavor. It’s not overpowering with hops.
Bottle from Canals. Golden orange pour with a one finger thick head. Nice hoppy aroma witha sweet pine citrus flavor. Not a bad IPA. This company is pretty solid.

One of my favourite IPAs out there. How could you not love a beer made from 43 different hops?! Very citrusy, bright, vibrant floral aromas compliment the attractive amber coloured body. pine, grapefruit and nectar tastes.

Bottle @ home. Pours in golden with a respectable two finger off white head. The aroma is classic IPA, slightly sweet and I can already smell Cascade hops. The flavor is spicy with a dominant pine hoppiness that is very nice. This beer is very smooth on the palate, mouthfeel is medium to light. The finish is hoppy bitterness but very clean. This is a very sturdy IPA that is a nice ensemble with all parts working very nicely together.

12oz bottle.  Pours a very effervescent coppery amber with a good off white head.  Aroma is light and sweet, with scents of citrusy hops, yeast, grain, and floral notes.  Taste is fairly full and creamy, with a strong hoppy character (not a terribly bitter one, either) balanced out by additional hints of malt, dark fruit, and grains.  A nice IPA -- good and hoppy, but balanced enough that it’s not mouth-puckeringly so.
draft at flying sauce in ft worth.  Big hoppy aroma.. nice amber appearance, very smooth and well balanced for all its hoppiness

Draught at Circa 5/9/08.  A very bitter rendition of a style that probably would have mellowed a bit after 5 months on a boat crossing the equator twice.   Bright beautiful light copper color, huge aroma, huge bitterness, and enough balance to make it a pleasure to drink.
12 fl. oz. bottle at my small outdoor tasting together with Kjetil B., Roger and Asgeir. Hazy copper color, moderate white head. Aroma is hops. Flavor is very balanced with nice hops and fruit.

12oz bottle. Poured a deep copper with orange and ruby highlights and a medium-thick, light tan head. The aroma is hoppy - thick with spice and pine. The flavor follows the aroma - LOTS of hop flavor. There is a distinct spiciness and funkiness from the hops, along with the usual citrus and evergreen (Simcoe hops I bet). The malt backbone is quite nice, too - there is a nice residual sweetness, almost candy-like, but not too much. There is a little fruit in and lots of bitterness by mid-palate. The bready and sugary malts stand up to the hoppy, bitter bite though. The finish is dry and quite bitter with a very subtle sweetness and lots more pine with a smaller dose of grapefruit. The mouthfeel is rich and medium-full in body with a nice, sudsy texture that indicates a perfect level of carbonation. Overall, this beer could have been absolutely phenomenal - the hop and malt balance is perfect and the aroma is great, but the flavor has a little too much funk (from too much "catty" hops - like Simcoe). It’s still good, though.

High hoppiness and citrus abound. Mildly spicy as well. About what I expected, though slightly more bitter and a little less enjoyable than expected too. Acceptable, drinkable, but nothing to go crazy about.
Pretty good...hops are there, tastes piney maybe a touch resiney.  nice coppery color.  drinkable not exceptional

On tap, dark copper pour. Hoppy, floral, and fruity aroma. Taste was similiar. Can’t remember too much about this brew only that it was not exceptional or terrible. A little too bready and yeasty for an IPA. Drinkable, but nothing special.

Pours an orange color with a fairly thick white head. Aroma is slightly peachy with a bit of grapefruit. Not incredibly bitter but still plenty hoppy. Fruity. Peach and Grapefruit. Creamy mouthfeel. Good. Easy as shit to drink.

Had on tap at the "Hops On Equinox" in Seattle ’06 and in bottles in Portland, OR and Oakland, CA.  
Best on tap, and one of the best brews/IPA’s available @ HOE in Seattle.  In the end, I kept going back for more.  Very HOPPY, fruity, aromatic, kicky, etc.  In bottles, however, it dropped a notch, but that’s expected.  Overall, a very satisfying IPA.  Oregon-worthy beer,  brewed in or near Petaluma, CA.

Decent IPA. Pretty much what you’d expect. Had a great hoppy nose to it. On the palate the hops dies down slightly, but still enough to leave your mouth a bit dry. Reminded me somewhat of the Rogue Juniper Pale Ale. Good for drinking a few on the porch in summer.

This is a style I’ve come to appreciate a lot more.  The aroma is very hoppy, specifically citrusy hops.  Some pitch pine odors mixed in.  The flavor is very hoppy, and has strong notes of grapefruit.  Very refreshing.  Thin mouthfeel, and a citrus/hoppy palate that fades relatively quickly.Good overall.  (i’m drinking this on the Long Island Railroad, and everybody should be wasted if they ride the LIRR!!)

Ho hum.  Poured a copperish color with big head lots of noticiable yeasts in there.  Aroma was very yeasty and light pine/citrus hops.  Flavor was much hoppier then the aroma lots of grapefruit and yeast, just an average IPA.

Coppery orange, small white head. Great aroma - resin, pine, sticky hops. Flavor is, as one might guess, dominated by hops - resiny and sticky, but also nice notes of grapefruit and, uh, more grapefruit? Really hop dominated, and I really liked it. WBF, Raleigh.

Had on tap at McCray’s.  Poured to a yellowish gold color, unlike the orange copper I was expecting. The anticipated citrusy nose and flavor were there, but slightly muted, as was the bitterness of the mouthfeel. This all led to a medium length, slightly bitter flavor which was nice and smooth. Not a bad beer at all, but still below other Lagunitas offerings.
Nice straightforward IPA.  Rich hop flavor and aroma.  I like their Maximus IPA a little more, but I suppose that’s neither here nor there--good beer!

12 oz bottle. A slight unclear deep golden colored beer with a fully diminishing near-white head. Fresh fruity and hoppy aroma;  sweet grapefruit, tangerines and tropical. Grassy, light piney hops. Notes of peppermint and sweet nutty malts.Taste is not that complex, but has fine distinct bitterness and leaves some likeable flavors of citrus and refined malts. Lasting fruity-bitter finish. Loveable.
Clear light copper fluffy white head a some slight spotted lace.  Pine and yeast on the nose.  Lots of citrus hops with a clean bitter finish

Aroma: smells marvellous, pine, fresh as hell, lovely. Raspberry, pineapple, sweet malt. Dominated by fresh sourish superpiny exotic hops. 

Flavour: nice, sourish, fruity, malty backbone. Pleasant hopbitterness, brackish. 

Appearance: nice, clear orange body with fluffy & lathery white head. 

Palate: harsh, acrid but smooth. Seems alkalic.
Tasted 2008-04-19. Pours hazy, orange with white head. Aroma: Sweet, toffee. Flavour: sweet, very bitter. Very tasty. Me likes!

20080413  Bomber.  Mostly clear golden color with sticky, lasting, small white head.  Aroma is mild citrus, some earthy/grassy notes, and tea.  The body is thinner than I’d like, almost zero astringency, some decent finishing bitterness.  Flavors of iced tea with lemon, mildly grassy/pithy hops, lightly solvent.  Compared to the other CA IPA standards like Stone, Pelican, Bear Repub, Alpine, Sierra nevada, and on and on and on , this one doesn’t hold a candle.  Meh, I’m probably overrating.
From bottle... poured clear gold. Disappointingly weak aroma. Light citrus flavor to start. Slightly bitter. Finishes dry. This was decent, but I was hoping for much more.

Beer pours copper color with a dense suspension of tiny yeasties throughout (I thought they were bubbles as first).  Weak aroma of malt.  Flavor was very hoppy with grapefruit, some earthy/herbal notes and peppery flavors.  Not really much in the malt department even after it warmed...very faint caramel.  I was pretty unimpressed.

bottle - Pours copper with a one finger white head.  It has a nice citrus hop aroma.  The flavor is, as one would expect, all about the hops.  There’s just a little citrus in there and some light malt.  I thought it could have used a little more malt balance and a little more character.  That’s a ridiculous number of different malts and hops though.  It’s medium bodied and leaves the characteristic long, bitter finish of an IPA.
12oz bottle: pours amber brown with decent white head, aroma not all that strong but of hops, flavor pretty srong of citrusy hops and pale malt. pretty good IPA.

A copper pour.  Not much of an aroma. Understated up front (watery) with a slight cinnamon hint that builds to a grassy (not overwhelmingly) and hoppier palate and then settles into a oatmeal aftertaste.

Pours a copper color with a decent initial head and a pretty good amount of lacing ends up on the glass. The aroma is quite mild. It consists of citrus fruits with hints of caramel and malt but hardly any hops. Upon further examination I get a small grapefruit hop presence but not enough. Maybe it was my desire for hops that created it. A semi spiced malt characteristic comes out first in the flavor followed by a sour hoppy grapefruit flavor. Caramel mixed in. A slightly sour grapefruit flavor lingers a bit. A wet finish for an IPA. As the beer warms a little it starts to somewhat resemble more of a traditional IPA (at least the one’s I’ve had) with a sour hop flavor. Interesting mix of malts and hops but not necessarily what I look for in an IPA. Decent enough beer but I probably won’t get it again.

have had in bottle and on tap, various occasions.  this golden, aromatic, and wonderfully bitter brew meets or exceeds all the requirements for a good west coast ipa, as you can see from many other ratings.  I would like to note, however, that the lagunitas ipa lacks a certain individuality, or strength of character.  this makes it less memorable than it should be.  perhaps because they blend so many types of malts and hops, it leaves a vague impression.
Had it on the ferry from SF to Sausalito.  Great IPA.  Nice piney aroma.  Medium bodied with a nice balanced hoppy character.  Very nice overall.

Bottle.  Pour was a deep gold.  Head was beige with heavy lacing.  Aroma was very big with fruit, citrus and some light pine.  Taste is pretty hoppy with  a decent malt backing.  Some light bread flavor mixes in with the hops and malt.  Overall, a pretty good balance.  A good mix of hops, and  a nice malt accompaniment.  Finish is nicely bitter.  Body is medium with a good bit of carbonation.
what a great beer!!!  great aroma, fantastic flavor.  very citrusy/floral, almost a little grassy, but truely a great ipa.
Excellent true to character IPA.  Slightly orange head, cloudy orange golden color.  Smells of orange of pine.  The 43 hops make this one incredibly rich.  Tastes like a traditional IPA.  Cheers!
This was another classic IPA and very good indeed with hints of citrus and malts and very easy to drink smooth as silk a nice frothy head and a classic look to it .CHEERS!

Pours a clear, bright gold with a rocky off-white head.  Aroma of mild citrusy hops.  Flavor is rich but rather mild, with a thick, doughy malt bill offset by grapefruit, pine and peppery hops.  Neither side of the equation dominates; this is a superbly drinkable, well-balanced beer, even if it is weak by the American IPA standard.

When I saw the rating, I was shocked.  This is rated rather low, but I enjoyed these.

Although the aroma was very weak, I thought that this was an excellent IPA, High in drinkability, and the hops were very apparent but not overbearing.

Hmm.... Oh well I liked this and will drink it again, and again, and then maybe again.

~Pours a see through reddish orange colour with small head.
~ Nice bitter hop scent. Floral with some sweet notes.
~ Smooth bitter taste. small bite.
~Abrupt bitter finish.
~ Enjoyable IPA, seems a bit watered down. I look forward to a long lasting bitterness from an IPA and this seems to be lacking. Still very enjoyable.

Bottle pours a bright copper/light orange with an off-white head.  Aroma of citrus and floral hops, doughy yeast and faint sweet malty note.  Flavor has a moderate bitter opening followed by a nice balance of clean malt flavors and bright citrus hoppyness.  Finishes slightly dry with a bit of lemon peel.  Moderate carbonation and light, but not watery, mouthfeel.  A nice and tasty brew on the lighter side of the typical IPA.

** update rate ** anothe rbottle revealed the peachy tones and quite intereesting if subtle hop profile. Kinda fat but good. Uprate ** Surprisingly ordinary IPA for a West Coast legend. But good. Thin pour and light copper-orange hue, moderate fine head. Lots of hop bitter finish that is a bit one-dimensional, perhaps owing to hops shortage I mused? Good malt body. Citrusy flavors were good, I knocked this back in about five minutes at BeerBistro (at the cost of $2.00 / minute!!)

a very good IPA.  Pours out a coppery color with a small beige head.  aroma was full of hops and grassy with a bit of sweetness to it.  Flavor was very refreshing.  It wasnt over the top with hops and had a nice lasting flavor to it.  over all a very nice brew.
Bottle. Pours golden with white head. Strong hop aroma. Nice hop taste, nice body. Good sessioning beer.
This orange ale poured with a thin beige head. It’s a typical IPA, with plenty of hop bitterness and aroma and a balancing malt presence. There is some carbonation and a bit of citrus in the finish.

Bottle, 22 fl. oz. Pours a light amber beer, with a nice off-white head. The aroma is hops, with notes of herbs and fruits, mainly lemon. Nice hoppy flavor, with mainly american hops. The hops tastes of lemon and grapefruit. Nice mouthfeel and overall a nice american IPA. (#100)
Orangish in color with a decent head.  Hoppy smell with floral and citus notes.  Flavor has the same with some grassiness.  The beer seemed like it was laking in something though.

On Tap at Tank’s Tap Room (Carrollwood, FL).  Draft pours a hazy golden orange with a decent sized foamy head.  Pungent aroma of citrus, pine, and hops.  Very hoppy flavor with a nice aftertaste.  Subtle hints in the flavor also remind me of tea leaves.

Bottle. Pours amber-orange with a moderately sized and lasting white head. Aroma is fresh citrus, mainly orange. Flavor is fresh citrus up front, with moderate bitterness, moving to some sweet caramel maltiness, a bit of grassiness, and a more earthy bitter hop finish. Well balanced but still pretty hoppy. Pretty good.

Most Lagunitas brews are quite good, but this one I found very lacking. I’m not sure if I got a bad batch or what but this is more like an average amber rather then an IPA. The nose is almost non-existent save for a mild hop aroma. For an IPA this beer is quite weak. Like I mentioned, it’s like an amber rather then an IPA. Burnt carmel and toffee dominate over the hops. From reading other reviews I’ve come to the conclusion that either the recipe has been tinkered with because of the hop shortage going on at the time of this review, or I just got a bad brew. I’ll try again in the future and re-rate if needed.
On tap.  Kind of orange with an off white head.  Nice strong fruity hop aroma.  Also a strong hop flavor with a little bit of malt.  I’ll have this again, it’s pretty good.
Nice copper/amber pour with white head. Strong aromas of hops, pine, and citrus. Hops and citrus to taste overall. Very solid IPA from Lag. I could drink this one all night long.
Pours orange with off white head. Aromas of pine and grapefruit. The flavor starts sweet and hoppy and finishes malty. A decent IPA.

Bottle. Pours amber with moderate dense beige head, some lacing. Aroma has mild pine, very slight tropical fruit - esp. mango, sticky toffee. Flavor is bombarded with hops - fruity, flora, mild pinel, lightly peppery, moderately bitter. Distinctive Lagunitas toffee malt flavor throughout. Bitterness lingers long in finish. Archetypal west coast IPA.

TAP@ Maxies? in Ithica. I like this IPA. It’s tasty and pretty true to style. Lagunitas beer has a distinctive taste to it somewhat like DFH. It’s one of those breweries where you could recognize most of their beers if you were blindfolded. Dogfish Head is like that for me too. Does that make sense?? Does anybody else feel that way about any beers? Anyways, this is a good IPA that is easily found here in NY.

Bottle. Small ivory fizzy head that mostly diminished, spotty amount of lacing, mostly transparent, and visible carbonation. Nose was mildly malty, sweet, and citrus hops. Flavor was malty, some caramel, hoppy but not overly so, citrus-grapefruit. Fairly smooth mouthfeel and light-mediumm body. A nicely balanced IPA and one  that I enjoyed because it was not over-the-top hops since I am not a hophead. Would drink this one in the future and worthy of a try.

amber pour .... sweet smell of hops ... grapefruit and citrus .... bitter start with sweet in the middle followed by a bitter finish ... best of both worlds sweet grapefruit and pine resin .... hops are not overpowering .... nice and smooth ... drinkability is high for this one .... i’m drinking this one at about 60 deg F ... probably a little better at 45-50 ..... I love this brewery

Tap: Took no notes so I’m writing based on memory. Deep orange pour with a wispy off-white head. The aroma shows some mild fruitiness of oranges and a light peach touch, but the hops seem restrained. The body is light with a restrained hop character as well. Not much bitterness at all. Reminds me of a watered down, less bitter Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. It seems the wide distribution has given it a "macro IPA" feel to it.

pours from bottle a copper color with off-white head.  Aroma of floral hoppiness with a little grapefruit.  The flavor starts with a hint of sweetness but quickly the floral hop bitterness takes hold.  It is not overly bitter, just enough to balance the beer.  There are hints of grass, gratefruit and maybe a twinge of caramel.  This is a very nice drinkable IPA.
Lagunitas IPA is a standard around northern california. Full bodiedd with great aromatic hops, a well rounded IPA. I enjoy it every time
Sampled at the Arizona Craft Brewers Guild 2008 Strong Beer Fest, on February 17, at the Mesa Amphitheatre.
Medium hop aroma and flavor. Good malt flavor to balance the bitterness. Overall very drinkable and good IPA.
Creamy head on an orange body. This is an IPA, very hoppy, very fulfilling. Now I call this a beer! It brings joy and satisfaction. This brew is well-suited for almost any occasion.

Love this stuff!    Great drinking ale, has supplanted SNPA for me in the best commonly available beer here (CA, that is)  Very Californian, solid hops and malt balance,  with long finish.   Not for the hedonist,  but for the drinker.

This is a solid IPA.  It pours the deep copper color with a hoppy & grapefruity aroma.  The hops bite at first sip just like they should.  The only negative for me was the finish.  This beer has a dry finish that left a bad taste.

On draft at McGregor’s.  Gorgeous looking orange with thick creamy head.  Standard full aroma  of grapefruit.  Very nice balanced malty and hoppy palate.  Loved it.  Had again at the Dinosaur with some spicy food.  Worked very well with the food.
dark amber almost orange pour with no head just some froth.  hops, hops and more hops on the nose.  nice fresh hop taste with a bit of bitterness that fits quite well.

Bottle. Very grassy aroma, a little caramel and tobacco. Hazy copper colour, small white head. The flavour is quite hoppy, caramelly, with a rough bitterness. Not a bad beer, but rather rough, I think.

A really decent IPA.  Pours a coppery color with a small off-white head.  A mix of citrus and floral hops in the nose.  Nice mouthfeel - solid.  Nice flavor profile - with a variety of hops notes.  A little malt in the finish.  Very drinkable.

Bottle sampled. Pourscopperwith a off-white one finger head. Aroma of floraland piney hops, light caramel, and malty sweetmess. Fairly balanced flavor of pine, grapefruit, caramel malts, with a light bitterness and a dry hop finish.

Great IPA! Poured with a big frothy, foamy, textured head and some lace. Very nice slightly spicy aroma with a hint of earthiness. Ditto the flavor. Very clear dark amber color. Head lasts for a while. Very long hoppy finish. Not a citrusy hop character. This is the way I prefer it. This just rearrived at the Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin.

Pours a clear amber with a nice crème head that falls but leaves lots of lace. The nose is that intense piney perfume. Flavor is hoppy, but a bit of a tart edge hits me and I can’t say I like it that much. As I dwell on it, it seems almost wood like. Interesting? Yes. My favorite? No. Feel has a slightly higher level of carbonation to it that gives a bit of a bite and the liquid is well bodied. Overall this is a nice IPA, but that slightly woody tart thing that is going on kind of knocks it down a bit in my book.

12oz.  Pours light, clear orange with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is citrusy though light, tangerines and oranges.  Taste is smooth, balanced, lightly bitter.  Highly drinkable though not incredibly flavorful or unique.

12 0z. bottle in pint glass, this has become my standby IPA since it has become so readily available. big hoppy flavor, lots of citrus and floral , pours a nice head with good lacing, a really nice everday IPA
A great beer.  Nice golden color.  Grapefruit taste / smell.  Very good, lots of hops!  No Stone IPA or Ruination.  I would drink this all days of the week.

Poured from a 22 oz bomber into a generic pint glass. Coppery gold color with a fluffy white 1.5 finger head. Quite attractive so far. 

Aromas of pine and grapefruit, that’s about it. 

Flavors of grapefruit and pine, that’s about it. Lacks a detectable malt presence and consequently tastes one-dimensionally bitter. 

Appropriately medium body and carbonation are this beer’s strongest point. 

The mouthfeel drags the drinkability to a bit above average, but I can’t say I want to go get another one. 

Run of the mill, in my opinion.

I really liked this beer a lot!  The aroma was citrusy, yet piney at the same time.  Nice bronze color to the beer and poured me a thinner than expected head.  The taste was surprisingly refreshing and the citrus aroma actually translated to a citrus taste from the hops.  Finish was very crisp, I enjoyed this beer thoroughly..........

Nice wet citrus smell balanced by a malt undertone. A nice orange to copper tone in the glass, topped by a thick khaki colored head. Abnormaly malty flavor for an IPA but not bad. Citrus followed closely by sweet malt and a slight bitterness at the end. Clean mouthfeel. With a 60/40 ration of hops to malt this is an interesting flavor for an IPA but lacking that sharp grapefruit bite due to the heavy malt presence.

Copper-orange pour with a small frothy white head.  Wet fresh citrus and pine aroma.  Nice citrus hop flavor upfront fading to a sweet malt and pine finish.  Surprisingly clean finish for a strong IPA too.  It almost has a slight lager like character in the finish.  Medium body with soft but plentiful carbonation.

I’m an IPA fan and this is an excellent example (at least on my palate). I had it in a bottle, cold, and accompanied by spicy food (a perfect balance to the citrus, sweet and bitterness of IPAs).

I found it to be similar in malt sweetness and hop bitterness to Boulder Brewing Co.’s Mojo IPA, and Sierra Nevadas’ excellent Fresh Hop Harvest Ale.

It has a nice piney and citrusy hop aroma. A distinct yet subtle maltines, followed by a not-to-harsh fresh hop bitterness and grapefruitiness. It finishes with a sweet + bitter taste that wow’ed me. One of my TOP 10 for sure (and I’ve tried hundreds).
Off-white head and an orange/amber body. Piny hops aroma. Really aggressive hop flavor right at the front. Little bit of astringency. Nice finish that goes off on the sweet side.

12oz bottle. Pours a hazy amber color, not much of a head but has decent lacing. Aroma is more malty than hops.  The mouth feel  is very malty also .  Not much hop bite in flavor, nor in the aftertaste.  Not a great representative of an IPA compared to the other great ones out there.

Pours a cloudy orange with a healthy off white head. Very sweet citrus up front with a mild hop finish. Pretty good beer, but not what I expect from an IPA. (Will have to try this again on a night when I haven’t already had a Hopslam.)
gold-copper with medium orange head, leaves lacing. Citrisy and fruity hop aroma, bitter taste but not extraordinarily so for an IPA, some malt sweetness with a long dry finish. creamy mouthfeel.

Poured a copper-orange color with medium head.  Citrus flavors matched the color for a very balanced Pale.  IPA’s aren’t normally my thing, but Laguinitas make a hell of a beer.  It was very smooth and drinkable.

Pours an orange color with the smell of citrus. Although not my favorite type of beer I’ll try to be objective. Very hoppy and the taste of citrus orange was the most prevalent flavor. Very bitter, but not bad for an IPA

Pours a nice copper color with a thick long lasting white head. Hop aroma just billows out of the glass, like sticking your nose in a bag of hops. A few more whiffs and I get some malty caramel notes, also. Taste is nice and hop bitter. Not a lot of malt, but enough to balance out the the powerful hops. Finishes very clean with just a touch of the hop bitterness. Very smooth and drinkable.
Hazy pale amber with tiny short lasting head. Hoppy aroma with fruity and caramel notes. Flavor is mild sweet with hoppy end. Thanks for sharing Joergen.

22 oz bomber.  Amber beer with a thick white head.  Aroma is well-balanced.  Caramelly malts with some light grapefruity hop aroma.  Fruity hop flavour on the front, grapefruit and light orange/pine.  Simple, fresh, tasty IPA.

Bottle.  Pours hazy golden orange with thick head.  Aroma is grapefruit and hops, very pleasant.  Flavor is grapefruit and floral, very crisp and refreshing.  Cleans palate with very little aftertaste.  A good, sessionable IPA.

Pours a completely clear light amber color with a thick creamy head of 3 fingers.  Aroma of spicy hop.  Really nice aroma.  Flavor is typical of a west coast IPA.  Spicy, pungent yet crisp.  I haven’t had a standard ipa in awhile.  Something seems a little off, but that could just be me.  A nice IPA.  I might have to revist again in the future.
Golden color with a white head.  Aroma is dominated by some nice citrus and assorted hops.  Flavor is a nice hoppy mix of citrus and some floral/pine, plus a fairly sweet malt backing.  Pretty good.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Fort Lauderdale, FL for $1.99 Good.

Bottle from whole foods in san fran. Pours a hazy orange with a small white head. Citrus and hops in the nose. Grapefruit and apricot dominate the flavour, before leading to a refreshingly crisp finish. This is excellent stuff.

12oz - Aroma is citrus hops and a summer wind through a pine forest.  Pours cloudy orange with medium head and good lacing.  Flavor is interesting with the pine, citrus and earthy hops blending together with caramel and some sweet malt to balance it out.  Palate is crisp and smooth.  Just different enough to stand out and pretty tasty too.

Pours a hazy orange with a small amount of foamy white head.  Aroma is sweet and mild citrus hops.  Mouthfeel is a bit light and watery.  Flavor a bit dry and slightly bitter and mild hop finish.  Overall, just a mediocre ipa.

bottle. pours orange gold with one finger white head.  subtle aroma - piney hops.  taste is a nice solid bitter hop over malt.  some floral elements but this one is mostly bitter.  refreshing, clean finish. nothing too unique but definitely solid.
Bottle: Poured a rusty copper with off white thick head. The aroma is hoppy with yeast. The taste was full of malts and a hoppy gritty finish.
Bomber. Copper in color, thin head that laces slightly. Great balanced nose, lots of hop but the malt is there. Flavor follows accordingly. Quality IPA.

12oz bottle.   Orange-copper with a sticky orange head.   Citrusy and resiny aroma.   Quite sweet and malty with a nice balance of grapefruit leaning hops that have a little pine too.   Ends bitter and refreshing.   Medium body with small bubbles.   Very balanced and tasty IPA, just how I like it. (3.7)    Rerate:   Draught at 99 Bottles.   third time that I*ve had this on tap since my initial rating, and every time has been underwhelming.  To thin, and the hips just feel a bit castrated.   Still not one that I would turn down, but a bit below par for a Norcal IPA.
Poured copper with a small fluffy off white head. Aroma of hops and citrus. There wasn’t as much hop character as in the aroma. Wasn’t bad. Good balance of hops and malt. Some citrus hints.

Pours a honey-golden/amber, moderately effervescent, under a thick, off-white head which holds long and spackle my glass with lace. Floral, piney hops coat the nose along with a suggestion of lemongrass above just a hint of dishwater.  A bit bland and mineralish at first, but hops crawl out as it warms (not to the point where I can distinguish one from another of the "43 different" mentioned above, but overall piney, grapefruity and grassy with a touch of pepper to linger.) Not overdone and fairly sessionable. And I am not one to session IPAs.

BTW, glancing 5 ratings below... any low ratings for any beer can be understood by simply reading the ratings!


Received as a Christmas gift, December, 2007.
Not bad, but not great. I’d say it is average. Slight spiciness over a floral taste. Medium head with an amber color

22 oz from Argonaut in Denver.  Pour is a golden - ruby with an off white head.  Quite a bit of soft carbonation.  Aroma of some pine and resin hops.  Taste is nice, good bitterness throughout, and a distinctive citrus sour thing going on in the finish.  Nice IPA.

Poured a hazy gold with little head.  malts and oak dominate the nose.  Taste is similar with a bit of flowery hops.  A bit too sweet.  Finishes a bit syrupy.  This bottle is obviously over the hill for the hops to stand out.

Deep gold color, small barely off white head dissolves quickly.  Smells like crystal malts, some stone fruit, slightly sweet, fruity, hop bitterness is somewhat sharp and lasts for a moment after swallowing.  A liitle citrus pith on the finish.

I don’t understand the low ratings for this beer.  It is my favorite beer period. Assertive hops taste, but still balanced withthe malt.   The low ratings may be the result of what seemed to be bad bottles several years ago.  I just wish it was available in the part of SoCal where I live.

Draught. Medium amber pour with a nice, creamy white head. You could mistake this for a cask or nitro beer if you didn’t know better just by looking at the head. Excellent retention and some lacing. Nose is all hops, big grapefruit hops, with a ton of pine there as well. Don’t really get much malt backing on the nose. You don’t get much in the taste either, except for a faint sweetness. This is a pretty straightforward IPA, tons of citrus and pine. If you like that, this is your beer. Medium bodied, very slick and resinous mouthfeel. Finish is super long, lingering pine, grapefruit and grass. Excellent.

This beer pours nicely out of the bottle a golden straw color. IT has a good amount of bubbles in it. The aroma is good, and smells like the hop flower. Its got that great IPA bitter taste and finishes smooth, literally.

If you are a hop guy like me, this is an awesome beer.  I like it a lot more than the dogtown pale.  The initial taste is sweet and the bang of hops is nearly instant and will stick to your mouth for a long time.  The head on the beer is decent and stays, although a little thin, throughout.  I need to try this one back to back with Sierra Nevada and see which one I like better, I think I like this better.  I have to say, to be fair, that i’m only an hour from the brewery so I’m sure I’m getting a fresh batch everytime.  I’m waiting for a beer that tastes this good to compete with the MBC.  The labels these guys make are classic.  One of the best beers around and on tap all over the bay area.
LOVE

Pours golden amber, medium off-white head, with decent lacing. Sharp Hoppy aroma, packed with an intensely sharp & bitter (almost acidic) taste. Kind of a watery palate. Great beer, but not balanced enough (too bitter) to be excellent.

Taste: Bitter, oakey taste with some sweetness. Watery pallet. Tastes like Killian’s Irish Red. The first taste is good, but the aftertaste is bad. I don’t like it. 
Appearance: No head, no head retention, golden amber color.

Bottle. TIny white head on top of a hazy golden orange beer with a little bit of "stuff" floating in it. Floral hoppy nose, similar taste. Nice bit of spice, complicated hops flavors blend nicely. Not a lot of malt, but not overly bitter. Quite drinkable, rather interesting, and one I’d love to find again.

Bottle. Clear orange-copper with a medium-sized and lasting head. Spicy tea leaf and floral-honey aroma. Initial flavor is earthy-spiced honey and pekoe tea, turns more to a toasted bitter nut and dried wood. Finally finishes with a pleasant woody, earthy, dry cocoa aftertaste. Palate is smooth and nearly medium-bodied with a dry finish. Not your typical West Coast IPA.

12 oz. bottle pours a clear amber color. The off white colored head leaves a nice lacing. Smells of mild floral hops. Medium bodied with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Has a sweet cream and caramel flavor with a mildly tart hop taste to finish. 
Lots of malt flavors. The hops are around but they’re not the highlight here.
dec 2004

Bottle.  Pours a light amber color with a thick head.  Aroma is of sweet piney hops.  Flavor is hoppy, though not as hoppy as some of their other offerings.  Hop lovers can’t pass this one over as it hits all the notes of a solid IPA.

Rated 8/26/07. 12 oz. bottle courtesy of ’Naka.  Light golden amber w/ small white head.  Sweet aroma wit ha bit of hop.  Lovce the label.  "Mortal combat of malt and hops on you palate."  Awesome.  Good hop after taste.  Great beer.  Love to get more.

on tap @ papago. rich golden pour with a thin long lasting white head. aromas of caramel, citrus, pine and bubble gum. flavor is orange, grassy, caramel and pine without being overly sweet or hoppy. finishes dry and piney. it lingers for a while. medium body and carbonation. almost a nice sessionable ipa.... the sugar would get a bit annoying after a while...7/3/7/3/15/3.5

12 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a diminishing white head. Aroma is hoppy and with a slight malty dryness. Flavour holds dry fruity hops, lacks some sweetness to give some great flavours. Ends with a slight soapy and dry hoppy with a bit of bitterness.
Copper color and medium head. Nicely bitter hop taste, but not much malt in flavor or body.

Bottle.  Pours clear light copper with minimal off-white head, some lacing.  A subdued earthy grass aroma.  Fairly balanced tasting with a metallic bitter finish.  Medium boied with a faint lingering bitterness.

Not a bad brew. Caramel, hops, and some fizzy wizzy. Honey coloured pour with a hint of rusty pipes. Some smooth malt hints, but mainly flat pine. Not supper hoppy though, so that was rather a sad note. But enjoyably sessionable.

12 oz. Bottle, pours a honey copper gold with some red at the edges, has a lot of little specks in it otherwise it is clear, a white head,
pine with some floral fragrances and malty sweetness, faint vanilla aroma, sip starts with malt sweetness and 
hop citrus grapefruit mixed with some pine needles, sweetness is nutrilized and finishes with a pine bitterness, mouth feel is a little thin,
this was an ok IPA, nothing real exciting.

Sweet pine resin on the nose, with hints of citrus. Pours pale gold with little to no head.  Sweet upfront, but wow the hops kick in, good piney flavors with grapefruit and bitter orange peel in the flavor. A good session IPA, i like this one.

bottle: pours a clear filtered apple juice with a medium white head. aroma is a citrus hops and some earthy hops also very little malt if any. flavour actually starts a little watery and weak then into the citrus hopsa and some sweet malt in the back. just a small amount of bitter in  the finish a very subtlle ipa not strong in anything but goes down very very easy.
Pours  a nice orangish color. A nice hoppy scent and taste. A pretty good IPA.
Nice balance of malt and hops with a light citrus finish. The colour is a orangish cooper. The smell is citrus, pine, and hops. The aftertaste stays with you in a good way.
Bottle. Very little in the way of aroma. Flavor was very muted hops and malt. I’m thinking I drank this one past it’s prime, will have to try a fresh one.

Forms a slightly thin head with little retention.  It did form nice lacing and good aromas full of pine, citrus, and a slight biscuit smell.  It had a nice malty taste, bread dough, biscuit, caramel, and a lot of other hints of flavors that were hard to distinguish.  The hops are a bit misleading, as its hard to determine the exact resinous flavors that they come with...its not quite bitter enough, but its still tasty and complex

Amber color with a decent white head. Aroma is mainly hops and citrus. Flavor is the same as the aroma. A little watery in the mouthfeel. Overall, an above average IPA but there are much better ones out there.

Bottle.  Poured with a finger and a half head.  Watery brown color, tastes hoppy with a citrus flavor, but bitter metallic finish.  Well carbonated.  I personally do not care for the aftertaste, but it’s a decent IPA.

Slight unclear copper/orange with a decent head & good lacings. Aroma is of hops - piney & bitter. Medium bodied with a average live carbonation. Fresh & mainly bitter taste from hops. Not as sweet as ex. maximus from same brewery. Good & solid IPA with a lovely bitterness!

Pours a light copper with a head average in color and durability. Aroma was mildly fruity. Flavor was satisfyingly hoppy. In addition, this IPA let you know there is a solid base to it - it doesn’t just rely on the hops as many IPA’s do. The label boasts that the hops and the malt battle in your palate; I would rather think of it as a concert, not a battle. Mouthfeel was a little on the thin side, but this ale still established a decent presence, fortified with a long-lasting pleasant aftertaste.
Orange with a diminishing head. Nice aroma of citrus and caramel. The flavour is somewhat salty and grap like with a hint of caramel and hay. The finish is dry and metallic.
Bottle. Fine Ipa, with the hop´s on the top, fine faint malty flavor, hazy golden color. A  ipa with out the heavy sweetness.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber. When fresh this beer has a nice hop aroma, but I have noticed that this varies greatly with age. Pretty good flavor balance, just enough malt to carry the hops. Pretty common West Coast American IPA here. I like the style so I like the beer, but there are many out there that are better.
Aroma is of flowery hops.  Clear amber hue with an off-white head.  Flavor is watery, weak and finishes dry.  Palate is watery soft.  Much too weak in every category.

really good ipa, a bit too bitter. woody and a bit dry but still a satisfying beer.

bottle, mollie stone’s palo alto, ca

The Lagunita sales rep brought a keg of this to my local pub and had a beer tasting event.
Good IPA, nice smooth flavor and decent finish.

Light piney aroma. Copper color. Flavor has some pine and a little citrus with some sweet malt balance. A balanced WC IPA. Extremely drinkable. Not too heavy. Rather sessionable. I drank a 6 pack before the Seahawks - Niners game! Very good.
Cloudy amber color, flavor is dominated by pine, with some citrus hops, and some maltiness for balance,  one of my favorite IPAs

(Green) Bottle 355 ml 

Appearance : Clear standard amber , medium creamy top.
Nose : Good clan classic west coast hops . Well planned – citric mango like hops with greener backing. Harmonus.
Flavour/Palate : Medium soft bodied that goes well with hop-fruit character. Quiet balanced as IPA can go. Soft malty finish with clean refreshing end. Satisfying brew.

bottle, liquorloft Tallahassee. I’m a big hop fan but i don’t know if theres 43 hops in this beer. not complaining, the nose and taste of this beer scream hops. aroma is strong citrus, grapefruit. taste is a strong malt back bone with a heavy hoppping, citrus, pine and floral. fantastic bitter and hop follow up after swallowing. i prefer a bitter bite with my hops so this beer gives me everything i ask for.

I shall preface: I am not an IPA person or lover of single-minded emphasis on hops (although, ironically, I do really like some IPAs & even Double IPAs); I instead like full-bodied, more malty beers like strong ales, barleywine, etc.  Therefore, I am not necessarily a good indicator if this is a good IPA.  That said,  this is all grapefruit to me & while it is somewhat drinkable, I do not like this much at all.  It is fairly pale amber with a good white head and decent lacing.  It smells predominantly of grapefruit and little else.  The aroma is not misleading: it tastes almost entirely of grapefruit, too.  It’s taste at first is not overly bitter or hoppy, giving the briefest impression that it will be more balanced, but this almost instantly becomes all hops.  While it is not exceedingly bitter or piney, this beer’s entire character, taste, and aroma are of unsweetened grapefruit membrane.  For some, I understand, this is great, but for me, I don’t think this even tastes like beer.

Poured draft from Dinosaur BBQ in Syracuse, NY.  Orange in color, light head.  Smells of sweet hops, but not really overpowering.  Just right.  Nice, chewy mouthfeel, great IPA flavor.  Comparable to Dogfishhead 60-minute IPA.  This is an excellent example of the style.
Orange amber color, thick off-white head. Citrus hop aroma. Flavor of grapefruity piney hops. Nice, very bitter IPA.

Hmm.. says they used 43 different hops and 65 different malts. They really should have stuck with just a good few. It’s not bad, but it has too much going on. Rather dry without much residual sweetness, and light bodied. Not sure why you need 65 malts for that. Grassy bitter hop finish.

Pours a clear copper-orange color under a tight and thick off-white head. Decent head retention throughout the glass with a bit of spotty lacing. Nicely balaced, but somewhat faint aromas of caramel and toasted malts with citrus and pine hop contributions. Was a bit disappointed that the nose seemed a bit tame. Palate was smooth, moderately full and had just the right amount of carbonation. Flavor seemed to surprisingly lean to the malty side for a west coast IPA. A bit more assertive and richer than the nose. Pleasant notes of caramel, biscuits, malt-balls, grapefruit, orange peel and pine greet the tongue. Finish is well balanced with a bitter-sweet lingering. Easy goin’ down and a pretty decent IPA.

12oz.  This was a pleasant surprise.  This is what the rest of the lackluster beers I had this evening were aspiring to.  Glad I saved this for last.  Ever so slightly hazy golden pour with lasting white head.  Awesome carbonation that bounces up the side of the glass.  Great pine and wintergreen on the nose, moderate in hoppiness which is kind of a relief.  The slightest hint of syrup and a notion of cream soda on the lingering finish.  I will go back to this one.

On tap, 10/3/07.  Slightly hazy amber color, white foam with decent lacing and good retention.  Aroma is very confused, very muddled hoppiness and a very strange, almost sourness to it.  Flavor is pretty malty, a bit too malty for an IPA, some herbal like hops float around in the background, there’s some nice bitterness in the finish, but the real focus seems to be on the malt.  Meh, call it a Pale Ale and I’m sold on it, put huge IPA on the label and dammit man you gotta try harder.

A nice IPA from those who know hops. Their special releases are a bit better than this, but this is a good IPA. Aroma of grassy hops with a bit of sticky malt. Pour was a nice dark orange with a one finger white head. Taste was mostly grassy and earthy hops with a nice malt backbone. The malt balanced the beer out perfectly which I actually don’t like as much as the overly hoppy IPAs. Nice.

Pours a redish gold color with a thin head.  Not overly carbonated.  The aroma is thin, barely detectable.  The flavor is slightly sweet, with a well balanced hop bitterness.  It doesn’t try to overpower you with hops, just a good bitter flavor that is clean.

Overall a decent brew
Bottled. Hazy reddish orange appearance with low white foam. Hoppy aroma of orange-peels, grass and nectarines. dryish flavour of nectarines grass and grapefuit. with a solid citric bitterness.

pours a light golden color with a light dissipating head that left some lacing clinging to the glass. Great hops flavor. great IPA. Smooth drinking with a delicous bitterness at the finish. Very drinkable.

Date: September 14, 2007

Mode: Bottle

Source: Neighborhood Happy Hour

Appearance: orange with a beige head

Aroma: lots of citrus hop aroma on a sweet caramel malt base

Flavor: rich sweet caramel malt flavor with lots of balancing citrus hops, light bitterness



Date: November 11, 2010

Mode: draft

Words: tmac woodstock

Appearance: clear copper, fine beige head

Aroma: sweet crystal malt aroma with lots of citrus hops for that west coast IPA signature

Flavor: sweet crystal flavor, nice citrus plays off the crystal, light bitterness



Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20

Rating: 3.5/5.0
Drinkability: 8/10

Score: *** /4

From 12 oz bottle-  poured burnt orange color, head formed and went away slowly.  Hoppy aroma with hints of fruit.  Hits the palate with a small body, strong hop overtone, hop finish.  I’m not a big fan of IPA’s, but I wouldn’t turn this down if offered, nice.

From a bottle: Pours a copper orange color. Lightly malty and citrusy aroma. Flavor is somewhat malty with floral hops and citrus fruit rind flavors. Moderate clean bitterness. Clean and crisp finish. Balanced and very drinkable but nothing stands out about it.

From bottle : A medium dark orange color with a white foamy head.  Nice floral hops aroma with pine.  A heavy medium body.  The flavor is a little spicey, but very well balanced with the hops and malts.  A little bitterness stays on the tip of your tongue, its a nice aftertaste.

Orange body with lemon yellow head. Head has various sized bubbles in clumps. Lines of tiny bubbles line the sides of my pint glass. Lots of navel orange citrus aroma. Familiar nose of walking through a pine forest as well. Really full and spicy flavor/mouthfeel. Light aftertaste after the onslaught of hop bitters during swallow. The entire flavor stays on a packet on your tongue and disappears with the swallow. A light sharpness remains on the back of my tongue, but that’s all. Pretty good IPA.
Citrusy and spicy.  Pretty tasty.  Could sit and drink a few of these.  65 malts huh...?
6pack from Bevmo La Mesa.  a little too much on the "herbal" side for me, never the less a great IPA.

$8.49 for a six pack at Broudy’s.   Nice floral hop aroma on the opening of the bottle ( cheap twist-off).  Flavor is mild sweet malt and hops to start and then completely overcome by the hop bitterness.  Long bitter finish.  Body is medium to light, bordering on watery. Also a bit mild in terms of ABV for an IPA.   Emphasis is definitely on the bitterness with this one.  Still a pretty good brew, even with the minor faults.

This IPA was more like a pale ale to me, ather than an IPA.  Not real hoppy, not real memorable, in fact, not much of anything going for it.  I also don’t believe I got 12 ozs. of beer in my bottle because of the space left in my mug after pouring in the entire bottle.  I thought it was 11 ozs., but after spending some time searching the label for the quantity, I found it listed in the contents (not where I’m used to looking, most brewers don’t put it there).  Another personal note: I dislike their commercial description.  I will not buy this again, with all of the other GREAT IPA’s on the market.  Also, I don’t know where they put the 43 different hops and 65 malts because I didn’t taste that much of either.  They probably put them the same place Budweiser puts them!

Pours a dark straw color with a head that slowly subsides.  The nose on this one isn’t all that big, but at first sip the bitterness really comes out of this one. Not very malty, and the bitterness kicks in right in the middle and doesn’t let go. A pretty avg IPA, don’t think I will buy it in the near future.
This is a basic IPA, maybe even a little boring. Was not overwhelmed by flavor and there was not a lot going on in this $2 12oz bottle. Bland for an IPA, I thought.
Orange in color, floral hoppy aroma, taste is well balanced mix of malt and hops. A great IPA.
Single bottle from Total Wine, Jacksonville.  Pours a deep gold color with a slight head.  Aroma is all hops, taste is malty and a little hop on the end.  This is a very nice IPA at a good price.
Clear orange pour with an off white head that sticks around. Strong hop aroma.  Caramel malts in the front end. Strong hop flavor in the finish. Very good.
Oily, floral hop nose. Smells like a field in spring. Sweet full body backed by a wonderful blend of clean hops. One doesnt outweigh the other; nice balance. Great grasp of style.

Bottle - deep, dark golden body with a beige head and tons of floaties.  A nose full of grassy hops.  Nice grassy hops in the flavor, as well, with balancing malt.  Good, strong carbonation.  A very good IPA.

bright orange ale with some brown tones. frothy white head rises and falls quickly. nose is mostly swee malts. faint hint of hop pine is also noted. unfiltered hop particles can be seen floating throughout. a well balanced IPA that is predominately malty. citric hops a re strong but kept in check. mild piney finish rounds it out. a solid easy drinking IPA.

Bottle. The aroma of this beer is what one should expect from an IPA, bordering on DIPA characteristics. Moderate malt aromas of roasted and caramel, heavy hop smells of pine and orange peel and light notes of dough and beef broth for the yeast with date, vanilla and cherry in the background. Head is white, frothy/creamy, mostly diminising with excellent lacing. Color is a sparkling clear amber/orange. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic then the extra long finish is lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is light to medium, between watery and oily with a carbonation between lively and fizzy. I think this beer rivals the top IPAs available in my area.

(bottle) Hazy orange with lots(!) of big "floaties" and an off-white head. Faint aroma of grass, hops, and sweet malt. Very hoppy flavor but with a nice malt sweetness to balance it up front. Finishes bitter. Medium body.

12 oz bottle. Clear amber with a big off white head. Nice foamy lace. Nose is grassy and grapefruit citrus, light pine. Mild sweet maltiness behind the hoppy wall of flavor - lots of citrus and grass. Pine appears toward the end. Lasting bitter finish. A nice drinker - very good!
Aroma of orange and malt, golden/orange, a small custard head. Flavour of orange, some malt. Light bodied, bitter, good.
ehh....not a big fan of this IPA. Color and aroma typical of IPAs. The taste was horrible. Felt very watered down. Overall a mediocre IPA

Hazy pour with some milky bubbles that cling to the edges and occupy a few partial, random spaces on the surface.  Orange, glowing.  Aroma suggests moss, scotch oak, wildflowers, and blonde brownie.  With a lacing of butterscotch.  A faint hint of strawberries with cream.  Tastes more of a mild soap than a crushing weight of bitterness.  Only minor undercurrents of resinous syrups and crushed flowers.  Bitter citrus rind leaps out a little, with a slighter hint of red pepper and grapefruit.  It packs some intensity, but it still retains that cleaning product polish that cripples the impact.  Alcohol resonates with a dark, hollow tone at the finish.  Bitterness is slow to finally arrive after swallowing.  Despite its qualities this is easy to recognize as California to the core, though a morose, cold-weather example.
12oz bottle. Pours clear amber color with foamy off white head. Aroma of floral hops. Taste of grapefruit and with bitter after taste.

Bottle. 12 fl. oz. Clear, amber color with sudsy, white head.  Piney, grapefruit aroma. Dry mouthfeel.  Flavor is pretty much bitter hops all the way with just a hint of caramel malt showing through. This beer is very hoppy as any good IPA should be, but it lacks complexity. Still, pretty good overall.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Pours bright pale copper with lasting flat white head.  Mild aroma of fresh hops.   Well balanced flavor starts malty, with some fruitiness, and finishes dry and clean with hoppy bitterness and without much bite.  The focus is on balance here.   Nice.

Copper with smaller head.  Piney, floral hop aroma with touches of barnyard grass and a quiet malt scent.  There was a nice taste of hops, with a floral spice, cirtus touch and lightly roasted malts, woody and grassy flavors.  Decent, but not outstanding.  Typical IPA
A decent IPA.  Aroma and Appearance are typical of an IPA.  Palate is medium; maybe a tad watery.  Overall very sessionable.

Beautiful orange/amber pour with a nice thin white head. Aroma isn’t much to write home about--some citrus hops, but faint. Flavor is exceptionally smooth, balanced, and mild. I was expecting more pronounced hops throughout. Malt is nice--but very simple. Finish is not as bitter as most IPAs. Overall, quite drinkable and smooth, but not an IPA exemplar.

Bottle.  Pours a light amber color with a thin soapy head.  Mild grapefruit hop aroma.  Palate not very lively.  Decent grapefruit hop kick to start with a little tingling hop finish.  The hop character overall could be cleaner, but not a bad brew at all.
Fairly typical but good IPA.  fruit and hops aroma.  roasted malt taste.  long dry bitter finish.  K - 5.5

how can something be a unique version of an ancient style when the style of IPA isnt ancient. thats what i want to know. good beer, bad commercial description. when i think of ancient i think of myans.

Clear orange-amber color with a small off-white head that recedes to a speckled, thin film.  Spotty lacing.  Moderate carbonation is apparent.  The aroma is a very nice blend of citrus and herbal hops.  Orange, grapefruit, and fresh cut grass come together well in the nose.  The flavor has a toffee malt base, with a fresh and crisp grassy hop kick.  There is also a little bit of a buttery flavor in the background, which is nice.  This beer is very smooth and drinkable, but the hops let you know that they are there.  Medium bodied with a that has just a hint of stickiness to it.  Very good session IPA.

Bottle. Pours a clear light copper with a one finger off-white head that lasts leaving good lacing. Aroma of citrus hops, pine hops, and fresh malt. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full mouthfeel and well balanced bitterness. A well balanced and tasty IPA.

43 different hops and 65 various malts?  Maybe this is a joke that I’m not getting, but this tastes like a pretty typical IPA to me - not that that’s a bad thing.  Pours a nice deep copper with a khaki head.  Very nice looking beer.  Aroma is piney/resiney hops.  Taste is a bit of malty sweetness, and then the piney and citrus hops.  Nice bitter finish.  Very drinkable beer.  I think I’ll pick up a few more bombers of this, since the price is right.

Draft, Baja Bean, Staunton VA. Medium orange with white head. Malt-forward aromas of toasted caramel and burnt sugar, with some citrus and pine hops in the background (way in the background). Flavor is again toasty malt with nice bitterness throughout, and some hoppiness coming through here and there. Pretty watery palate, disappointing. All in all an easy drinker, but a bit flat throughout. just not what I want in an IPA.

08.05.07. Bottle. Skunky hop nose, slight citrus but muted. Clear yellowish with no head. No body, not much to the beer at all. Watery hops with no backbone.5/2/5/1/7

Re-rate 09.25.09. Bottle Tangerine and grapefruit nose with some pine character. Great clarity, gold with a thin white head and heavy carbonation. Big bitterness with strong pine and a lingering astringency. Slight sweetness. Nice full bodied at the front of the sip into a dry bitter finish. 7/4/7/3/14
22 oz. bottle - pours clear, dark gold with slight white head; nice aromas mix of hops and fruit; typical IPA flavors with a little extra punch and mild bitter finish
This is what I call a prototypical IPA. Hoppy, but not overwhelming, and enough citrus tones to convey the necessary message. Very drinkable at 5.7%, too.
Pretty tasty.  Just a bit (and I mean just barely) on the watery side.  I guess I look for a little more punch in my india pale ales, but the flavor is right on with the style.

Orangeish amber pour with foamy offwhite head.  Slightly subdued subtly sweet caramel, malt smell with a bigger note of hops come together and give it almost a candy like smell.  Not quite the hop bomb in the nose I expected, but it’s different, and nice still.  Taste gives a candy like malt sweetness, and some hops, but not very aggressively so.  I’d say its a mild IPA bitterness wise, and this is unique, very drinkable and a great IPA that I’d have again.
ON tap at Lagunitas.  Slightly hazy deep yellow with no head.  Grapefruit aroma with hints of pine.  Bright palate.  Citrus and pine taste with a hint of bitterness to the finish.
Sort of an IPA light in my book.  Very refreshing beer that might be a good start to those making the transition from macrobrews.  A good bitterness that will not overwhelm, this is an easy drinker.

12 oz bottle.  The usual American IPA copper-orange in colour, with a nice head, which quickly recedes to a film.  Aroma is mostly of (stale?) hops - smells like the fridge at the homebrew supply store.  A bit of sweet malt at first, but mostly hops.  Seems to be lacking something, though.  A little flat in the middle.  A bit tinny at the end.  Lingering bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is a little slick.  Nicely carbonated.  Maybe I got a bad bottle.

Bottle. Light unclear medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate hoppy, pine, grass, grapefruit, light malty, caramel. Flavor is is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bomber from Corral Liquors in Granite City, IL. Pours a sparkling amber-orange with plenty of floaties and a frothy, off-white head. Fruity/citrus hops and caramel on the nose, with a nice creamy, medium-bodied mouthfeel, ending nice and bitter. Sweet caramel malts hide behind solid fruity, citrus, earthy and piny hop notes. A pleasant bitter end lingers briefly; a nice hoppy IPA.

Bright orange color with an amber inner glow. Small soapy head. Nose is dry and malty. Mouthfeel is somewhat acidic and tastes of sunflower seeds, hops, and malt. Reminds me of a mouthfull of Davids’ sunflower seeds.

.bomber. smells a little skunky, and like toast. pale amber body with big bubbled white head that fades with lacing. feels a little vague ni the mouth & leves the tongue dry. flavors of pine and citrus (wonder if the bottle i got is a littel old, as its been cleaner from the tap)
From a bottle at Old Chicago.  A very solid iPA with penty of hops, good bitterness and malt flavor.  A nice mix of fruitines and pine flavors.
Pretty solid IPA.  Not too hoppy, but still a fine brew.  Lagunitas...is really growing on my as a great all-around brewer.
Full nose of citrus fruit and caramel malts. Lightly sweet body with caramel notes evolving into light grapefruit and light hops. Not overwhelming, but the finish thins out a bit.
