don’t know how or why i’ve avoided this for so long.  lots of citrus aroma and a good amount of caramel maltiness. flavor is very reminiscent of indica ipa.  surprising sweetness but a healthy grapefruit hoppiness.  not the most bitter ipa, but propably one of the most tasty.  I kind of like the fact that it’s not a near 7% abv ipa.

I might be tempted to give this beer somewhat higher marks if I wasn’t so convinced that it’s basically a SNPA clone. While the hop profile is a bit different, of course, there’s a real similarity in the breadiness. I like the tart, dry qualities somewhat but there’s just not enough that’s distinctive about this one.
Enjoyed at AT@T park as a matter of fact.  That stand behind home plate.  7$.  Of course thats a rip off.  I know.  It was good though.  A little more characteristic than your standard.

Light amber beer with a nice frothy off-white head. Lemon and herbal hop aroma, actually a hint of lemon tea for a moment. Some orange and peach lingers in the background. Malty flavour with a bunch of bitterness coming very quickly, and again that strange tea-note.

Heavy hop flavor, kind of soapy mouthfeel, very citrusy with a pine tree  ambiance. nice drink, a little plain but well done. I think my glass did not get all the soap rinsed out as this is my least fav drink from this brewery to date - i will rerate with a clean glass when i get a new bottle.
Pours a nice amber color.  Aroma is sweet citrus hops with notes of honey and pineapple.  It a very clean and crisp and loaded with nice hop flavor.  It has a slightly bitter but fading finish.

Sweet, this is delicious. Orange look with a small fast disappearing head. Aroma is very fresh hobby with notes of oranges and pine from the cascade. The flavor has a broad bitterness, and a refined malty sweetness, which balance it out nicely. Classy.
Pours a crystal clear amber that forms decently into a foam head. Smell is good, can tell this is an IPA. Solid drinker.

12oz bottle.  Pours a medium copper that is just about opaque with a decent head and excellent lacing.  Decent aroma of hops.  The taste is nicely hoppy, if just slightly restrained.  I suppose you could call this a sessionable beer then.  A pretty decent IPA for a pretty decent price.

old rating:
6/3/7/3/14 - 3.3.

pours a semi-clear orange amber with a thin dirty-white head, and good lacing.

smells of light citrus, cherry wood, dry leaves, definite hops, and a little sugar.

tastes a crisp, bitter and sweet, some citrus, pine, and some caraeml, ends dry and nicely bitter.
Bottled. Very good IPA. Had it while in San Fran on a trip, and it was one of the many beers I had that stuck out in my memory as very enjoyable.
Really solid stuff! had this after the Wipeout IPA, so my tastebuds were numb but still could detect a good hop bite there. Nice piney smell as well
good stuff here bought a sixer in hudson, mn. was lit when i had it but it was tasty. nice and long finish on the ol’e palate smooth great ipa still got five left:)

Citrus and juicy malt aromas that are very faint for this style. The aroma gets a touch more floral as the beer warms up, but it’s still rather faint. Rich copper pour with a lasting 1/4" white head that leaves much lacing around the glass. Thick and smooth on the palate with a strong bitter hop bite, very nice. Flavor is considerably more bitter than I would have guessed based on the mild aromas. Hoppy and spicy, not too much citrus gets past the strong bitterness. Good malt profile, could be more prolific. Decent brew, not overly impressive but I found it to be enjoyable every time I’ve had it.
A very nice traditional IPA. Strong hoppy flavor with a very light body and thin texture. Beautiful amber color. A great drink to have at the bar.

Bottle. Pours a nice amber color with medium white head and a lot of carbonation too.  The aroma is very citrusy with hints of grass. Nice lacing on this one and a very sweet taste with a smooth finish. A great IPA.
as far as IPAs go, this was pretty above average. Not great, but definitely better than most. Quite hoppy, but didn’t have the malt backbone one would expect. tasty, though.

Clear, sparkling orange color with a small, fizzy-frothy, off-white head; a small layer sticks around an lacing is decent.  Nose is nice with notes of tangerine, grass, and biscuit with hints at cinnamon.  Flavor is simple; grass, tangerine, and light pine with pie crust malt tones backing.  Palate is supportive to this IPA being, lively, medium, and somewhat viscous.  Finishes with the more-than-moderate bitterness coming out fully, with lingering tangerine and a some herbal notes.  Not a bad IPA; straight forward with nice flavors and balance.  Lacks any "wow" qualities and somewhat simple without the extreme bitterness of certain IPA’s, but solid in every facet.

12 oz bottle.  Very minimal head.  Dusky, dull amber-orange.  Faintly sweet citrus and floral aroma.  Mild fruity-sweet taste, bitter and a bit dry on the back end.  Decent but neither outstanding or memorable.

POurs a hazy orange with a small white head.  Smells of some floral citrus and hops.  Not a huge hop presence, but its there.  Some grapefruit too.  The taste is semi-mild, kind of a sweet hoppiness to it.  Some cinnamon and other spices show up.  Some grapefruit citrus arrives from the hops.  Nicely balanced and fairly easy to drink.  Nice job on this beer.  Kind of a fruitier IPA.

The Dan Journal #18.  Tasted 5/30/07.  22oz bomber.  Hazy with a dark golden amber hue.  Minimal head.  Toasty caramel malt aromas.  Pine and maple aromas.  Toasty bready malts.  Dry and bitter.  Nice piney hop profile.  Good!

12 oz bottle. Is this bottle conditioned? I sure hope so because mine poured a clear orangey/amber color with a TON of floaties that resembled sour milk poured into hot tea, and a nice size frothy white head. Well I darnk it anyway despite the floaties, please let it have been yeast. Aroma started off with a nice big whiff of citrus hops and then turned over to sweet caramel  malt with the hops taking the back seat. Flavor was dominated by sweet malt with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Nothing special here, nice but not that memorable.

On tap at the Bocktown. Looks like the typical ubiquitous pale yellow American lager. Thin white head made of smaller creamy bubbles. Just a small amount of floral hop aroma. Again, just barely. Has an earthy hint to the taste and then the hops hit pretty hard. Decent carbonation.  Lets chew on some grapefruit rinds. Another sip causes the bitterness to build but it is not tremendously offensive. Finish is long lasting medicinal bitterness on the back of your throat, typical IPA finish. Somebody give me a Old Heathen to wash this down with.  I have yet to adjust to the IPA style.

Re-Rate - out of fairness this bottle is much fresher than the last I tasted. Orange/amber color - little hazy. Aroma - lots of grapefruit, floral and malty. The lots of hops are balanced with malt.  Decent palate. Good overall IPA.
orange IPA, a bit cloudy upon pouring but clear, a minimal head, very bitter, light sweetness, average carbonation,
good ipa, not great. smells like grapefruit, hops and grass. a little sweet, with a tart, hoppy finish.

Pours nice amber, aroma of grapefruits, light malts and hops, linge of grassey pines.  Formed medium foamy head.  My mouth is watering.  Initial impression is heaven.  Simply a wonderful IPA beer.  Easily sessionable.  Wish I had a kegger of it.

Nice orange-golden color and a nice. creamy head. The aroma has some spicy hops, grass and resin. The flavour is sweetish, fruity with notes of flower and caramel, grass, resin and a rather tart grapefruit, that continues in the finish. 2252

On tap at Palmer Place in LaGrange IL.  I thought this was a well done IPA.  But I’ve had better examples of this style, so I didn’t go crazy with the ratings.  I’d prefer a Bell’s Two Hearted or a Three Floyds Alpha King over this beer.

Bottle. Pours a golden brown with a white head that dissipates pretty quickly but leaves a nice lace on the glass. Aroma of hops and citrus. Nice flavor, somewhat in between a pale ale and IPA in hop strength. Probably one of my more favorite IPAs.

12-oz. Pours a crystal-clear rubied medium amber with towering white bubbles that fall to film and spotty lace within a minute or so. Smells pretty good--gentle citurs, kinda orangey. Light body and carb make for a pretty mild attack; it picks up some bitter resin and maybe even a dab of pine for the finish. I had myself worked up into expecting more of a sueprstar based on the Maximus, but this is a tasty little sessionable-ish IPA.
Solid IPA. More balance than many. Not as strongly hopped as some, so make of that what you will. Nice citrus tart flavor in there. Have had better, but this is very enjoyable,

Pours a nice red amber with a one finger head. Good retention and lacing. Aroma is mild citrus and floral hops. Taste is bitter floral hops with little of the citrus in the nose. Not too oily which helps mouthfeel. Good typical IPA, but nothing spectacular.

Like Duster said... Its very drinkable, so this one will be purchased again.
This right here is an above average IPA. Lagunitas knows what they’re doing. They give you what you expect and then some...

Bottle poured a clear copper with a small diminishing amber head. Aromas of carmel, pine, light earthiness and a hint of grapefruit. Palate was medium dodied and slightly dry. Flavors of pine, carmel, earthiness and a hint of citrus with a lingering bitter finish.

My first reaction was that this IPA seems clean and not unbalanced as it seems to capture the qualities I desire in an IPA: a grapefruit-pine presence with hoppy bitterness. What makes this one different is a relatively dry finish which seems to accentuate the grapefruit tones and a sense that this one is slightly unbalanced with a sense of cloves. For a second I felt like I was writing the same IPA-style review but this slight unbalance for an otherwise clean beer seems to set it apart. Maybe its a bit overloaded?

[b]12oz. bottle[/b] - pours a deep orange shade with a small white head that leaves sticky lacing in the glass. Lots of little floaters in the glass. Smells great - full of fresh citrusy and piney hops (43 of them?!) that blend together perfectly against a solid malt (65 of them?!) background. Flavour is equally excellent - lots of chewy, fruity hops balanced very well with the malt. Bitterness comes through at the end with more of the earthier hop notes coming forward. Aftertaste however, is citrusy (grapefruit) again. Mouthfeel is sticky and creamy. This is an excellent, very drinkable IPA. Were it available in these parts I’d pick this up all the time as a perfect session beer.

Strong yeast aroma with mild floral hop aroma. Clear orange color with small white head, good lacing. Fizzy with a small amount of sediment. Starts off melllow finishing with a moderate hop bitterness. Good carbonation.

Pours a nice red amber with a one finger head. Good retention and lacing. Aroma is mild citrus and floral hops. Taste is bitter floral hops with little of the citrus in the nose. Not too oily which helps mouthfeel. Good typical IPA, but nothing spectacular.

Beatuiful tangerine-red color and clear. Minimal head. Aroma of straw-colored, dry grass. Flour taste I don’t really dig but with nice bitterness. 
[tasted next to a Tyranena Stickin It To The Man]
Not really a good comparison. The Lagunitas is really nice but pretty one-dimensional next to the Tyranena. I like them both, guess it depends on what you’re looking for.
Clear amber color, off-white head, rather sweet with a punch of floral, bittering hops at the end.  Pretty good IPA - but, it doesn’t even come close to the good ones.
Hoppy flowery scent that you can about taste but no lingering bitter flavors. An easy to find favorite and a real pleasure on tap.
On tap. A very tasty beer with some industrial flavours...highly hopped, earthy and piney with sweet brown sugar notes and a great dry finish that’s not too bitter. A bit uneven but well-made.

Bottle... Poured an amber tone with big white head which dissipated into some nice lacing.  Malty and hoppy aroma, flavors of hops, barley malt, citrus fruits and sweet caramel like taste. Mild, crisp finish.
Pours a hazy copper color with a white head.  Aroma is malty with some citrus hops.  Flavor is malty caramel with a moderate bitter hop finish.

Deep clear copper body, topped by a creamy and dense off-white head. Looks inviting. Aroma: grapefruit/citrus, leafy. Flavor: some citrus presence, a little balancing sweetness, earthy bitterness and maybe something like pepper. Very traditional IPA.
Draft at an Irish pub in Berkeley, CA.  Pours orangish with a light white head.  The aroma is hoppy citrus.  The taste is big very big on the hops for a regular IPA.  Nice overall feel great IPA.
12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Centimeter or so of head.  Floral and citrus hoppy aroma.  Good IPA.  Would buy again if my favorites weren’t around.

Pour was a nice light copper color with a two-finger off-white head.  Head hung around for a bit and offered some lacing.  The aroma was of floral hops, some citrus and underlying sweetness.  Pretty one-dimensional flavor with hops dominating and not enough sweet malt to offer any balance.  Slightly metallic mouthfeel.
citrusy hop aroma, copper color. creamy mouthfeel, though a bit light. not exessively hoppy. nice smooth ipa. one of my favorites to drink regularly

12 oz bottle - pours clear rust with lots of suspended particles that aren’t going anywhere.  White head leaves very nice lace.  Fruity and floral hop aroma is quite beautiful.  Body nicely robust, though flavour is slightly one dimensional.  Fruity hops, but with a good amount of balancing malt.  This is a quality IPA, one I will definitely get again.  43 different hops? Wow - nothin’ like the good ole US of A for some old fashioned extremism.....

bottle at dicarlo’s tasting.  this is a pretty average to good IPA.  it was drank after several belgian samples and some other styles, and it was nice to be able to point out to my friends exactly what hops are since they shined so much in contrast to the previous beers we’d had.  i’ll have to rerate it someday, but this seemed pretty decent all around.  um, crisp and cascadish.

What a surprise I’m at JFK airport and i see this on tap.  I jumped on this one and i was pretty happy with my choice.  It’s not really special, it’s your normal american IPA with a big hop bite and aroma.  The label claims 43 hops...i’m not sure why you’d ever put that many varieties in a beer, and i’d be the first to call BS on that one.  It’s a good regular IPA.  I’d get it again.
Pours a dark orange with mall head.  Very dry taste at the end not much bite, as in citrusy or bitterness. Piney after taste big time.

Bottle: Orange body with a thin head.  Noted cake, pine, perfume, sugar cane, and some citrus.  This beer started out dry and bitter.  A slight hint of sweetness hit for a second before more dry hoppyness finishes off this IPA with a mission.  Does open up a little after a while, with some saltine cracker, sweet orange, and perfume qualities making this beer a little more interesting.  A solid session beer for when I just want hops.
Enjoyed this IPA very much. Dry with a full hop flavor. Doesn’t sneak up as fast on you as the Maximus. Love the bitterness combined with the dryness.
Bottle sampled. Pours deep copper/amber with a large off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, hops, citrus, pine. The flavor is caramel, citrus, and a piney bitterness through out.

Hoppy and rich, with a creamy mouthfeel. This beer is great to just sit and sip. More flavors come out as it warms (slightly). There seems to be a slight sodium taste though. And the finish is a touch too bitter for my tastes.
On tap at the brewery.  Crisp and hoppy.  Decent amount of grapefruit character.  Better than your average IPA but nothing extreme.

Had this a few days ago so I can’t provide a very detailed description. It was fresh tasting and pleasant for an IPA. Not overtly bitter or hoppy.. just about right. I really enjoyed this one. Another great session brew from Lagunitas... i’m beginning to really love this brewery.

THIRD TRIAL: This is a pretty good IPA overall.  I enjoy a lot of Lagunitas beers, and this fits right in there with most of their others.  It pours a hazy orange with a fair amount of sediment floating in it.  The head doesn’t stick around too long, but it leaves a nice bit of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is floral and very clean citrus hop.  The flavor is similar, with a bit of sweet maltiness in the finish.  For some reason, most of the Lagunitas beers I’ve had taste "clean".  That’s the best way I can put it... Not astringent, just very clean (almost like a cleaning product smells).  The aftertaste leaves a bit of hop bitterness on your tongue, but not as much as I would have liked.  Overall, this is a good IPA, not too special, but not average either.

Large offwhite head, excellent retention. Lacing is coating and webby. Clear copper color. Nose is a bit grassy, piney and a hint citrusy. Medium bodied, crisp on the palate. Dry maltiness, biscuity with inky, piney hop flavors balancing the malts out. Medium acidity and a touch resiny. Finish is dry, a touch fruity with a clean hop bite. An easy drinkin IPA. Solid. Props to jake65 for the bomber!
BOTTLE SAYS I BEST. WONDERFUL MALTY SWEETNESS, GENUINE, AND PACKED FULL OF FLAVOR. GREAT MOUTHFEEL NOT THICK OR THIN.  A MASSIVE HOP ASSAULT. ALL THE SPOILS OF A WONDERFUL BEER WAR. TREAT YOURSELF.

12 oz pour. Big white fluffy head, nice golden to orange color but...tons of sediment/hops floaters, even with a carefull pour. Not real attractive. As the beer judge would say, a moonscape on the bottom equals carelessness at the top. The 2.9 is from the 1 for "Appearance."

Slightly darker amber with a moderately large head, decent lacing and retention. Aroma is PNW hops, I got Amarillo here mostly, probably Cascade, and also the usual caramel. Flavor brings this and focuses heavily on bitterness instead of hop flavor, which I didn’t like. The aroma was about a 7.5/10 and the flavor was a 6.5/10 so I gave them each 7s. An enjoyable IPA, but there was nothing special here.
Dark Gold Color with White Skin.  Caramel Malt Aroma.  Sweet Creamy Mouthfeel... Initial Notes of Caramel, Light Citrus and Then Drying Hops....Finishing with a Clean Dry Notation.  Nice Balanced IPA

This beer poured amber with an creamy white head.  There were big hop aromas on the pour.  I could smell citrus, spices and orange.  The taste is big hops with a hint of malt.  Pretty good balance for an IPA.

Very good IPA because of its hop balance. Amber with off-whtie head. Large hop aroma of grapefruit, orange and flowers. Flavor is mostly bitter with a small sweet malt backbone — just enough to offset the bitterness. The bitterness carries through to the long finish. Medium body. Smmoth texture. Somewhat astringent.

By far Lagunitas most popular brew. Its very nice, pours smooth and dark brown with a nice thick head. Mouthfeel is excellent and prepares you for great flavoring based on good bitters and spices. Highly recommended.

12 ounce bottle.  This is not bad, but there is also nothing to recommend it.  On the pour it looks like a glass of apple juice.  It even smells somewhat like it.  The aroma is a combination of orange, apple, and grain.  It is less flavorful than many India Pale Ale’s.  The taste tends more toward orange than grapefruit, with a slight hint of apple and lightly roasted grains.  The disturbing part of the experience was the small bits of sediment floating everywhere.  I can’t say I have seen that in an IPA, to date.  Most of the bits didn’t settle, either.

This accompanied the wife’s dinner omelets.  It would have been a good match if the beer was only slightly better.

Clear orange color with a small head. Aroma of pine, citrus and caramel. Spare lacing. Taste is the same. Good malt backbone. Bitter finish. Light body. (Hop) oily texture. Certainly not as bad as I’ve heard. (from somewhere)
12oz bottle all over Sonoma County. decent west coast IPA but there are way better out there, Session ipa if there is such a thing. Nice golden orange color citrus & hop aroma. decent

Aroma of citrus, undertone of evergreen. Ripe apricot color with virtually no head. Starts with malt supported by piney hop. Arguably some citrus hop. Medium mouthfeel. Finish is rough malt balanced by hop bitter. Dry finish. It floats my boat.
Pours an orange amber with a nice white head. Aromas of Citrus and Pine. Flavors of a fair amount of hops. Good IPA.
bottle.  From memory so I don’t have any description.  It was a nice solid IPA though and i would try it again.  Citrusy and floral but pretty balanced I think.

Bottle. Thick, frothy, cream colored head with stunning lacing. Smells of citrus, oak and hoppy malties, not over the top, but pleasant none the less. Smokey, tart, malt, hops, pine combine well for flavor. The carbonation was strong, with a tart feel and a dry finish.

Orange-copper with good, creamy off-white head / Dry hop, citrus, and caramel nose / Medium body, sweet and somewhat malty, with very good, slightly biting finish / Flavors of burnt sugar, bread, pineapple, and pine / Very nice, in a fuller style.

orange/amber with a medium sized off-white sudsy head.  typical hoppy american ipa aroma.  flavor is nicely hopped.  finishes with a sweet bready malt.  relatively standard, but nice.  not overly bitter like some.

12 oz. bottle- color of bright amber, with a froth white head - nose of  tar , resin , hopps , malt balanced , and slightly perfumey floral – taste of  bright , tar , resin , hopps , grapefruit , and malt - body resiny harsh, and mildly carbonated– aftertaste of resin , tar , grapefruit , and hopps

a nice copper color....herbal piney aroma...nice smooth flavor, definitely like most west coast IPAs with its pine and citrus based hop flavors...however, not nearly as potent as many west coast IPAs...i guess you could call this a good session IPA.

Copper color, from a 12oz bottle, off white head. good citrus taste, however almost a malty mid taste as noticed by others, not really enough citrus puch for me, hence the lower rating, a good beer, but a little too much malt for a higher rating

Poured into a standard pint glass. Appearance is the usual IPA colour, with lots and lots o’ floaties in it. I should have been a little more careful with the pour, but no matter. Good offwhite head retention. Has that typical, but damn tasty west coast citrus/pine punch. I found the finish to be a little too astringent for my tastes. Good malts, medium body with oily hops helping it slide down the pipe. Overall a really solid west coast IPA. I bet this would be a damn fine session brew fresh on tap.
Copper color with a thin white head.  Aroma of pine and citrus.  Nice malty flavor in the middle for balance before a long bitter hop finish.  Very nice.

Ubiquitos... 22Oz 
Burnished gold with some orange highlights. with a medium off white head which settles to a thin film
Nose: Grapefruit, some floral notes, nice malt from light caramel to toasty notes... some soft fruits and a little alcohol as the beer warms up
Taste: Nicely opens top note of resiny hop bite followed by toasty and slightly honeyed malts with a nicely spicy firm hop flavor... to finish dry with layers of hop flavors
Overall: One of the original west coast IPAs. Still very well made has that somewhat elusive quality of being balanced yet hoppy... Seems like Lagunitas is on the wagon with bottle conditioning this IPA
(Bottle) Pours a copper color with a nice lasting head. Balanced IPA taste. Some pine and citrus can be tasted in here. Nice full mouthfeel. It’s a decent IPA, but nothing spectacular.
An evening of Superbowl Party and many IPAs! This one was a solid hit, big and bitter, decent malt as well. My pick over Brooklyn brewery, but just behind Winterfish.

Pale orange/amber with an originally good, yellowish head, slightly irregular. Very grapey, slightly resiny, typical USA-hops nose. I don’t know if it are really 43 kinds, but they’re good. (Quite) a bit of cakey malts, and some orangepeel-oils or mandarinepeel-oils, apart from the terpenes. Ends a bit soapy, in a good way. Dry bitterish taste, superposed on quite a lot of caramelly malts, sweet, but step by step the bitterness of the hopoils overwhelm. It halts just the right side of becoming metallic, but a kind of galvanic sour-e-rish taste is there. The balance is near 100% perfect. Slightly sharp, bit oily slickness, medium bodied. One of the best West Coast IPA’s I’ve ever had, and one of the, if not the best balanced. Big thanks to J. for this unexpected gift!

Orangy amber pour with a big foamy orange tan head. Lemony piney hop aroma with a hint of roasted malt. Decent citrusy bitterness, with a bit of peppery hop spice, some roasty malts, and a hint of caramel flavor. Palate is medium, dry, resiny, and lightly bitter. Nice and refreshing ipa, but a bit unfocused.

Amber in colour with medium carbonation. Well focused C-hop aromas of lemon, grapefruit, pine, and black pepper, along with an undercurrent of slightly sweet pale malt. Hoppy upfront in the mouth with more of the typical C-hop notes. There’s also some nice green grass and mint character too. A classy Maris Otter type malt element dries out with a long pine finish. Nothing too surprising here, but very well executed. Thanks to presario for the sample.
Wow.  This is an aweome beer.   Thanks to Piscator for the sample.  Wish we could get it here.

hazy orange with some sediment, nice amount of white foamy head, good hops nose, not overwhelming, but nice, very citrus, crisp body, with a nice balance of malts to combat the strong hop quality, nice session IPA

Hazy copper color with a thick, lasting head.  Sweet orange citrus and malt aroma.  Citrus hops nicely balanced with the malt.  Finishes with a hit of piney bitterness.  Nice medium body.  A pretty straightforward IPA but very good.

very grassy and resiny hops in this one. very flavorful and zesty on the tongue with a moderate but assertive bitter finish.  sweetness in the flavor but it compliments the rest very well, this is a very balanced IPA, bold and nice flavors while still being pretty easy drinking, having a smaller body than something like a SN torpedo.  in this case it’s a good thing.  as long as you can find it fresh this one is a definite winner

12-oz bottle. Copper color with a persistent thick head, white with orange lacing. You first notice the nicely hopped aroma as a promise of complexity that will be unfortunately not fulliflled. A very well balanced, very capable IPA. If i had to chose among many macro-brewed IPAs i would pick this one...
Pour is a orange with a white head.  Aroma is deffinatly hops.  Flavor is hoppy and malty with a bit of metal in there.  Pretty striaght forward IPA.

bottle . . pours deep amber with light head . . aroma is hope, citrus, sweet . . taste is sweet hoppy flavor like a normal IPA . . kind of a bitter finish . . good though . . but very much a standard ipa . . good one

Bottle.  Golden orange color, not particularly hazy, white head.  Aroma is of grassy hops, a hint of citrus.  Taste is pine hops, caramel malt, strong hop bitterness, again a hint of citrus at the finish.  They come a lot better than this.
The beer  crystal clear and orange w/ a a head  which dissapears fast. A lot of bitter flavor in the  fast finish. Not too hoppy andmid strong in flavor. A good IPA
This was a flavorful IPA with a nice hoppy flavor. Tried this one at Taco Mac.

Pours a hazy golden amber with small floaties and an average foamy off white head.  Aroma of iced tea, some citrus from the hops, caramel malt but really nothing too stand out. Not sure how old this bottle was. Picked it up at the local six pack shop...but I don’t have too much faith in how quickly they turn over products.  Onto flavor...pretty much the same iced tea, malt sweetness and some decent hop bitterness. Not much hop flavor.

Lagunitas event at the Brickskeller.  Clear orange appearance; off-white head with great retention and lacing.  Some citrus hops, plastic (?) in the aroma.  Slightly off.  Medium mouthfeel: floral and citrus hops, one-dimensional, but reasonably tasty and balanced.  Light, slightly dry finish, with hints of sugar.
A nice drinkable IPA.  Not to overbearing with anything.  Nice easy aroma of citrus, maybe some pine.  Nice and crisp, will drink again for sure.

In their 22-ounce bottle. Pours a very dense dark gold color with a foamy white head. Hoppy aroma and big hop bitterness. Medium-bodied, with a dominating hoppy flavor and underlying clean malty flavor. Slight, lasting  citrusy char. Visible sediment. Very drinkable.
Slight malt in the aroma.Pours ligh copper with a slight offwhite head.Get some slight hops in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a slight hop bitterness in the finish.

This beer starts with an aroma of grass clippings and pine.  It pours a clear amber, with a thick white head and good lacing.  The taste is of a strong malt beginning, with a pine and bitter finish.  It does have a fairly heavy palate for an IPA, but it fits well with the style.  One that just recently became available in my area, and a good recommendation for a session ale.
Bottle. Medium amber color. Quite good. Nice and hoppy - but not very flavorful hops. Fairly strong.
Hoppy aroma.  Clear copper colour with sweetish smell of hops.  Nicely bittered with full mouth.
Clear copper color with a thin white bubbly head.  Sweet smell of dried fruit and a slight hop nose.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.  A lot of hop bitterness, but not much hop flavor.
Bottle. Copper body, off-white head, PNW hop nose. Medium sweetness, hoppy, typical example of the style.
Bottle. Pours a clear amber colour with an off-white head. Malty hoppy aroma with hints of pine needles. Sweet malty hoppy bitter flavor. Dry hoppy bitter finish with a long bitter aftertaste.

Bottle.   Pour is a clear light copper color with a full and rocky off-white head, some lacing.   Aroma is orange, citrus, some malt.   Flavor is sweet hops, floral, malt, grapefruit.   Palate is light to medium, with medium cabonation and a bitter finish.   Average.

On tap all over san francisco. I don’t mean to be biased but we midwesterners and eastcoasters do much better with the ipa style.  This isn’t bad by any means, but its so forgettable.  I actually enjoyed the Freak Out more.  From what i remember it had  a nice smooth bitter and was definetly true to the style, but i can name about fifty better IPA’s.

12oz. brown bottle. Pours medium clear orange, lasting white cap, two fingers in height, leaves good lace. Grapefuit hops are present in the aroma, though light. Flavour starts with fruity malt, some sweetness, grapefruit and orange hop notes mid way through then finishes with medium grapefruit bitterness. Good session ale.

Metallic golden-orange body with faint pale suspended particles and a scattering white head. Very bright, fresh green hop aroma with notes of candied citrus, apricot, and a lightly sweet pale malt backing.  Sweet fruity hop flavor melds with fresh pale malts and a light toasty edge. Medium-high tongue-numbing bitterness.  Overall impression is a little too sweet, but still very solid.

Very good IPA. Golden with no head. Fresh citrus aroma. The taste was of piney and fresh citrus hops. Clean bitter hop finish. I thought this was gonna be weak and tired, but it proved me wrong. Solid brew.

Taken from the website: "Made with 43 different hops and 65 various malts"

There is nothing significant about this beer. And I am confused becuase Ive heard more impressive work from this brewer.

The color is an umimpressive weak copper with yellow hue.

It doesnt stand a chance among any other IPA, nor any other brew. 
The hops are apparent, gave it a slight pine citrus taste.

I actually suggest going to the website to read what the brewer says about the beer. Its just as confusing to me as the people who continue to buy it are.

pours a dark copper with a one finger white head and small sediment. head does not last to long though but has some small lacing. strong hop smell with some orange and grapefruit. smooth hop taste with some orange peel. not to bad, very nice and smooth all around session ipa.

12oz bottle.  Aroma:  Citrusy hops with a bit of lemon and orange, Medium malt sweetness with some light graininess and a bit of caramel.  A light touch of green apple.   Appearance:  Light copper in color and clear.  Off-white head was full and rocky with nice retention.  Fair lacing.   Flavor:  Semi-sweet malt up front with a touch of caramel.  Big grapefruit and some pine resin, followed by another hit of malt that leads into the finish.  Medium-high bitterness is well balanced and refreshing.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  A great IPA that I wish I could find closer to home.
Nice to see these brews make it Atlanta.  Pours a nice copper color.  Smells and tastes of big apple and grape.  Well balanced with a slight and pleasant bitter bite.

(07.23.06) 12 oz brown bottle from DiCarlo’s, Mundelein, IL. Hoppy aroma. Poured clear copper with small white head. Soft carbonation. Light-to-medium bodied ale that starts with light malt sweetness and hoppy flavor. Finished dry with light hop bitterness.  Well-balanced with edge toward hoppiness. A refreshing drinkable hoppy beer.
My hometown brewery, I work a 5minute walk from brewery where on Thursday afternoons at 4:20 they have parties open to the public w/$2 beers.One of my fav IPAs and beers overall.
GABF-on tap-pours an offwhite head with orange/gold color.  Taste is balanced hops with a bite and medium malt-sweet.

12oz bottle. Clear golden color with light red hue. Thin white head. Nice malt and pine hop aroma. Nearly balanced mix of malts and hops. Some mild caramel malts give way to piney hop bitterness that run up the flavor. This beer isn’t too hoppy but just about right for a standard IPA.

Pour was amber gold, lots of foamy off white head. Nose was hops, lemon citrus pine grapefruit. Lots of floral and pine meddles into some grounding malts, finish is hops, grapefruit, very juicy, Very nice IPA. Thanks to my new friend Mark from liqouroutletwine cellars.

Totally thought I had rated this....then went to check my ratings and shockingly saw I haden’t. One of my favorite IPAs. Wonderful flower and pine notes that folds into that great malty taste. End with grapefruit and other citrus. Very nice. I think I’ll have another sip.
Light in color, and aroma. On the palate lemon zest and hops. slightly bitter finish, but classic brew. would drink again!

Golden-pink, really...white lacing head, carbonated.  Floral and piney aromas.  Somewhat sweet malty and still a good floral hop presence.  A mellow IPA...taste like Freak Outs!  little bro.  Good, but nothing I’ll hoorah about.

From a 22 oz. bomber with a blurb along the right side of label, no freshness date.

Poured a cloudy orangey, golden hued amber with a foamy, fluffy off-white head that settled in a thin bubbly lacing.

Aromas of grain and caramel, a soft hoppiness, floral, citric, pine and a light leafiness.

Good carbonation and a crisp, dryish, smooth light-medium bodied mouthfeel.

Overall, a balanced taste, sweet caramel malts and a light graininess, mildly piney, citric hops with a little tobacco leafiness, the hops have a soft, rolling bitterness in the palate, a subtle taste of alcohol towards the end and a dry hoppy and caramel finish.

A tasty and balanced IPA, very quaffable on a Friday night, hoppy, but not a over hopped bomb, nice, easy drinkability.
Another great beer from Lagunitas. I am so glad that their beers are now available in GA. This one has a nice hop bitterness and a smooth finish. Well rounded and balanced.

It has been a while since I have come across a moderate alcohol IPA that has been this good.  Pours copper with a bubbly off-white head.  Aroma has lots of hops with pine being the prevalent aspect - there is also some woody traits.  Overall very floral as well.  Medium body with a good amount of soft carbonation.  Starts with some light malt that has pale and caramel traits and some spicy hops.  The finish has lots of spicy hops with some woody hops as well.  The malt is not as apparent in the finish.  Very will done IPA.

I was a little surprised by the numbers on this IPA, at 1.059 and 45 IBUs its undersized and underpowered, but I’ve been happy with Lagunitas beers I’ve had before.  It pours a medium tan, thin head.  Pleasing orange grapefruit aroma.  Average PA flavor.  A solid beer, but loses point for calling itself an "IPA"...this is a PA in every sense.  Although its kinda cool they make it with 43 hops, that’s like every hop you can get.  In fact, I’m calling BS.  Same with the 65 malts.
Bottle from Foodery in Philly. Pours orange amber with a very thick off white head. Citrus hop aroma. Flavor of caramel and toffee offset by grapefruity hop bitterness. Nice beer.

Sampled at Real Beer Expo (Rochester).  Bottle.  Orange-amber colour, sl. haze and no head.  Plenty of hops (citrus, floral) and a bit of caramelly hops.  Med. carbonation and a decent body.  Orange and citruy hops and some bitterness.
brewtopia 10/21/06  This was definitely a hop bomb.  Aroma is strong, fresh hops.  Taste is very hoppy and bitter with a faint amount of malt in the background.
bottle. golden color. large head. nice hoppy aroma. piny hoppy taste. quite nice. could be a bit stronger though.

Bottled.  Poured medium orange with a whole helluva lot of sediment floating around in there.  Aroma picked up orange zest, floral notes, and some extra-sweet caramel.  Flavor had sticky caramel, toffee, and grapefruit at the core... citrus and floral hoppage around it, and moderate bitterness through the finish.  Didn’t flow too well or impress me much on the finish.  Just OK.
hazy copper color, earthy hops with a background of pine and sweet malt.  good mouthfeel and finish.  decent ipa, but nothing special.
Bottled. Hazy brownish coloured with a medium sized head. A bit malty and sweet. Hoppy, piney and somewhat flowery. A bit too mild though.

Pretty red orange gold in color with a substantial big bubble head off white in color.  Hops dominate the nose with sweet malt in the background (apricot orange) slightly floral as well.  This beer is all about the hops everything else is second.  I like the way they hit the midpalate firmly then slowly drift back and intensify in bitterness.  There’s sweet malt again but very subtle, like plum syrup?  The more this beer warms the more it’s fragrance resembles a pine cone which is basically what you could call it, fermented pinecone juice with plum syrup and it’s pretty damn tasty too.

Bottle... Hazy amber ale with a large, rocky, off-white head. Good retention. The nose is more malty than hoppy with notes of caramel, biscuit and shortbread. Mildly bitter, black tea flavor. Medium-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Finishes tannic and dry. English IPA, I think.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark golden color with a nice size head that leaves a good amount of lacing on the glass. Aroma of hops, citrus and pine. Taste of hops with a slight hint of grapefruit and toffee. Finishes nicely with a bit of hop bitterness.

A light brown with maybe some reddish orange hints. Aroma was originally a little citrusy and then ended up florally by the end. The flavor was a little sweet and then just a lot of hoppiness. The bitterness on this was awesome too. I know this is in ipa but the body seemed a little thin. Good beer.

Bottled.
Muddy brown, floating yeast, huge beige cloudy head. Hoppy aroma with metal and berries. Liquerish-like palate, very fruity yeasty, nutty, slightly unfermented. Hops rise in the aftertaste, which is still a bit sweet.

On tap at Bottoms Up Pizza on 04/30/2011. Clear golden amber body with a small frothy white head. Sweet citrus and resiny hop aroma with floral notes. Big citrus and floral hop flavor with a sweet pale malt background. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 7/3/8/3/16 - 3.7

10/02/2006 - Hazy light amber body with a small tan head. Sweet floral hops aroma. Sweet raw floral hops flavor. 8/4/8/3/16 - 3.9

Bottled (thanks Stoutlover72). Hazy nutbrown colour, huge beige fluffy head. Aroma is yeast, American hops and lots of fruit. Flavour is nutty, hoppy and toffeeish. Finish and aftertaste is sweetish malts and hops with nuts in background. Pleasant!

Bottle: Poured a clear orangey color ale with a medium foamy head with average retention and lacing. Aroma of metallic hops with some caramel malt. Taste is a mix between sweet malt with some metallic hops and a bitter finish. Body is about average. Overall, this is an OK IPA but far from being great and lacking balance between malt and hops.
dark orange in color.  golden khaki colored foamy thin head.Hopped up aroma. of citrus, grapefruit.  Tasted a slight bitter malt.  Kinda cereal, then BAM!  The bitterness finishes off strong.

Bottle.  Pours with a slightly cloudy orange body with almost no head.  Aroma is hoppy and slightly sweet, with orange, grapefruit and hops.  Flavor is a bit sweet at the outset, followed by a decent hop bite.  Finish is rather mild.

Excellent hop aroma with some mild malt coming through. A nice clear copper colored beer with a light tan head. Very good hop flavor with a good biscut light toasted type malt flavor to balance. I like the malt balance as it isn’t so much crystal as it is like toasted malts grains that you would’ve toasted in the oven. A very good take on the IPA and I like the almost normal alcohol content, I can drink a 6 pack and not be too wasted!!!

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange hue with a nice white head on top. Aroma is hops, pine, citrus with a malt in the background.  Flavor is not really there. Not getting much of anything really. For the aroma to be pretty hoppy there isn’t really much hops in the taste. I am not very impressed with this beer.

A moderate hops aroma and only a slight pine and citrus present. 1/2" frothy head, off-white. Amber color. Nothing spectacular with respect to taste of mouthfeel. Nothing really stood out with beer. A decent IPA that could be a good session beer.
Inbetween IPA and APA. Touch above average.  43 different hops and 65 various malts hodgepodge  they claim creates slightly unique, bland, earthy  bitterness.

Bomber. Slightly hazy amber/orange with a frothy white head. Aroma of citrus and piney hops, some floral as well, with a trace of soapiness. Flavor of caramel malt, grapefruit hops with some woodiness.  Hoppy bitter finish, but not overpowering. Medium palate.  12 oz version seems more subdued and streamlined.
Perfect amber in color. Slightly hazy.   Filmy white long-lasting head.  Mild pine scent.  Nice IPA aftertaste - a pleasant hoppiness.  Not overly mild or bitter - well balanced.

Hazy amber with an enduring off white head, nice lace, and some floaties. Honey, toffee, and light citrus aromas. Medium body, faintly resinous, light carbonation. Light sweet malty base supports a refreshing piney and bitter orange hop character. Dry, lightly bitter finish of medium duration.

Clear orange/light amber color with floaties (looks like part of the yeast cake from the bottom).  Lingering white head.  Aroma is sweet grapefruit, floral, and crsip pine.  Flavor is very much like the aroma and finishes with a nice bitterness that isn’t overpowering.  Medium to full palate - mouthfeel has some weight to it, but isn’t too heavy at all.  This is a very good IPA in all aspects.

12 oz bottle, $1.35 from River’s Bend.

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Deep copper pour with a thick and foamy tan head. Aroma isn’t as hoppy as I expected it to be, but still had a decent mix of floral and bitterness. The flavor is very peppery and hoppy, but not too overpowering, with a smooth maltiness that takes over the middle of the beer and a slightly bitter hop finish. Aftertaste is quite bitter, floral, hoppy, and has some citrus even. Very nice and smooth IPA.

Bottle: Pours a light amber color with a very small head that neither stuck around, nor stuck to the glass. Smells very earthy in the nose... Maybe hints of an orange. The hops are not over the top, just bitter enough in the taste. The rest of the taste is of soft orange, or some other citrus. Very earthy feel to this one.

(Bottle at home) Pours a bit hazy light amber with a small white head. Oily, spicy hop aroma. Sweet barley. Ripe fruits and raisins. Taste: pretty sharp bitterness with a menthol-ish endig. Not as sweet as the smell. Pine/grapy hop flavor. Citrus peels. Special and wierd. Small to medium body.
A solid IPA, reddish amber colour, medium bitterness, flavor and aroma are strong of grapefruit, high carbonation, and fairly light body, overall has a sweet but still noticibly bitter finish.

Aromas of light citrus, almost metallic pine, floral notes with a bit of caramel malt and some cola like yeast notes.  Amber orange in color with a tall, white head that thins.  Flavor is a bit less than I was expecting.  It starts out with a metallic/mineral twang.  Then there is a bit of floral pine in the finish.  As it warms up, the malty caramel starts to grow.  Body is fairly light and carbonation is high.

Clear golden copper pour wiht a lasting white head.  Nice, fresh hop aroma.  Floral.  Taste is a little lighter than I prefer.  Hops are there, probably the 43 of them I guess, but nothing really *bam*. Very dry, moderately bitter finish.  Nice, slightly resinous and bitter finish.  Nothing extraordinary, but it’s an easy drinking and good tasting ipa.  I liked it.
( Thanks to realale420 ) for a awesome trade. Pours a medium clear amber with a nice fluffy head. The aroma is wonderful. Hoppy, grapefruit, pine. Taste was bitterish (not in a bad way).
very good...alot of carbonation...i like it. notes of pine and citrus aromas and flavors.  Not overpowered by bitterness as many IPAs can be. would def. buy again.

Wonderful golden color with a nice white frothy head that doesn’t last long.  Has a fruity, citrus, toffee aroma.  Not too bitter, has a unique clean fresh taste, probably from all the different hops.  Has a very nice palate, not too carbonated, but it tingles your tongue a little.  All of the flavors mix very well, but you can still pick them apart.  An overall very nice brew, but it does have a lot of crap floating around in it.

Pous dark golden-orange with a small white head.  Aroma is dominated by hops, but a bit of maltiness.  Hops are mostly citric.  Flavor is similar, bit of sweetness from the malt, but mostly citric hop flavor.  Finish is a bit overly bitter, and has a sort of metallic taste to it.
Bottle. Dark golden colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet fruity hop. Flavour is sweet fruity hop and citrus. Bitter finish.
excellent...slight floral aroma, and nice big hop flavor...Not too bitter, and you wont be tasting it too long after...Great ipa..

12oz bottle:  pours brownish orange with an off white head.  Light notes of cascade? hops and spice.  The flavor is well executed different hops with different spices and bitterness.  They cover the palate rather nicely.  It’s no IIPA so the hops aren’t intense but they are very well balanced with each other.

Bottled. Golden, almost clear, with an off-white head. Citrus, malt, sweetness and pine in the aroma. Malty, sweet flavor with citrus and pine. Full body, and a lot of bitterness in the finish. Bitter but pleasant. (060720)
Draught. Clear copper color with off white head. Pretty standard IPA. Big citrusy hop nose and flavor with assertive bitterness at the end.

22 oz bomber from local grocery. Reddish Amber. Hoppy citrus aroma. The taste is fair but more hoppy than I like. Way too much bitter astringant aftertaste.**************
6/28/2007 rerate-11 months after original rating which was 8/3/6/3/11=3.1******
22 oz bottle via Roth’s. Pours a  semi-clear amber with an average sized head. Nose is lemon, orange and floral hops. Taste the same with some grapefruit and pine in the finish/aftertaste. Body is medium. Carbonation average.  An above average IPA.

I like how IPAs rest in my mouth. Aroma is of heavy grapefruit, hops, and irish ale yeast. Flavor is a bit strong but grapefruit, lemon, and some tangerine can be tasted. It looks like any other IPA really. Pretty decent, but nothing amazing.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a nice red amber with a decent head with tons of lacing.  You can smell the strong hops aroma when you pour it into a glass.  There is a nice balance of carmel malt and hops, but I like my IPA’s with more of a bite.  Citrus and pine linger on the palate.  Overall: not bad, not great.

On tap at the Yardhouse in Pasadena, CA.  Amber with reddish highlites suporting a 2 finger off-white head.  Herbal, citrusy aroma with plenty of hops bouncing about.  More of the same in the flavor - the hop profile is quite high and slightly over the top in relation to the malt but still not particularly aggressive.  Mildly carbonated and short, bitter finish with a touch of grapefruit.  43 hop varieties??  Not so sure what that’s all about aside from marketing but the brew itself is a decent IPA.
12oz bottle poures amber/gold with thin white head and mostly aromas of carmel. Low hop bitterness with a citrus hop finish. Overall an alright beer, but more of a strong pale than an IPA.

Pours an amber color with thin white head.  Nice lacing.  Has a "earthy" hop aroma, not as clean and fresh as some IPAs.  Flavor is very citrusy and also has quite a malt (caramel) background.     Has a bitter finish.  Solid IPA but nowhere near Smuttynose or Tyranena.
Nose is hops with a little caramel malt note.Amber in color with a small orange-tinged head. Very nice hop flavor with medium bitterness and some citrsy notes; aftertaste is slighlty bitter.
Ontap at The Map Room.  Standard IPA hop notes with pine asserting itself over the citrus attributes.  Has a nice lingering bitterness that qualifies this for a nice session IPA.
On Tap. Pours out a nice amber with a Tall off white head. very nice aroma of hops.

Flowery hop aroma, would prefer a bit stronger though.  Nice flavor though, very complex, hits bitter,l then has a pine, flower, caramely finish.  A little overcarbonated for my tastes.  Poured a nice orangish amber, with a nice head, and good lacing.

Bottle at home, bought at Bibendum vinbutikken. Clear amber color, fluffy white head. Aroma: hoppy (garden flower, pine needle), a little sweet caramel. Taste: very aggressive hoppy bitterness (grass and pine), sweet malts.
Aftertaste:Hop, grass and citrus.

Pours and amber color.  Citrus, hops, and orange flavor.  Decent bitter finish.  I fairly good IPA, refreshing.

So I tried this a second time and I really didnt like it that much.
muted citrus hop fragerance. Lots of head and lace. Orange. Smooth if understated hoppy flavour, medium mouthfeel, creaminess,drying finish, and citrus aftertaste. Not bad at all

12 oz bottle poured a nice amber color with a descent off-white head.   Citrusy hop aroma with some floral notes.  Bitterness hits your tongue right away.  Great west coast IPA, on of my fav session IPA’s as it comes in 6-packs.
Bottle. Very solid single ipa. Balanced and crisply hopped. It’s very refreshing, and definetly easy to drink if your a hop head.  I’m on the look out for a Lagunitas double ipa.

Bottled. Pours a light orange amber with a minimal, lacy head. Aroma of citrus, flowers, toffee and fruit, with a taste that is much the same. Light to medium body with fizzy carbonation. Lingering finish with grapefruit and pine. Bitter resinous aftertaste.

Pours amber with a tanned head. Smells of caramel. Quite bitter. Hoppy aromas of pine and fruits. Medium to light bodied. Bitter + sweet finish. The 43 hops and 65 malts doesn´t change the fact that the main ingredient (too much) is water.
22oz bottle. Solid IPA if not spectacular.  Nice and hoppy boquet but not so much on the taste. Not overly bitter as would be expected given the 40 different hops in the brew.

12-oz. bottle from Naven.  Pours a slightly cloudy copper with a medium off-white foamy head that diminishes some to leave just enough for some good sticky lacing.  Aroma is sweet floral and fruity hops, pine notes however non-offensive, and a slight caramel toasted malt nose.  Medium bitterness, acidity and sweetness, all in all very well balanced hops and malts, some hint of yeast hanging out, nothing hits you too harsh, finish is quite clean, especially for an IPA.  Light bodied and smooth, clean palate.

1 pint draught, The Gingerman, NYC. Light amber. Rich malty nose. Mellow hoppy background. Full-bodied, but refreshing. Aftertaste is really hoppy. Nice IPA. Floral hoppiness in the finish. Straightforward and even through there is a plethora of hops used to make it.

Re-rate, 11/07, draft at Uptown Billiards, Flagstaff: One very fine and nice IPA that I chose on draft over my favorite Stone IPA, not disappointed. The appearance was amberish in color very nice initial head and great lacing, true to the style. The aroma was full of piney, floral, and citrus hops. The flavor was firstly hoppy yet also supported by a significant malty base, light caramel, perhaps an earthy or herbal note underneath it all. Full mouthfeel for the style, finishing with a firm gritty bitterness that was very enjoyable. Ratings bumped significantly from my original 3.2. Original rating: Maybe these IPA’s aren’t so good while cutting grass in the winter, as the temperature doesn’t get to where it needs to be. Either way, the pour was boring, amber-ish orange with no head at all and little lacing, The aroma was hoppy, but not offensively piney hoppy. The flavor was typical of an IPA, not much special, but smooth and lacking citrus and fruit accents. Mouthfeel was average, maybe a little thing for the style.

Orangey amber, creamy white head (3+). Nice hoppy aroma, moderate hops with light fruity notes. Similar flavour, lightly hoppy. Average palate. Quaffable but I was hoping for more from Lagunitas. Thanks Jon. 6-7/3+/6-7/3/14
Bottle: Strong flavours all over, very complex, fruity, licorice, woody, bitterness, earthy, hoppy. The 43 hops and 65 malts are there! Good IPA.

2015-04-07, bottle, 6.2% ABV, 8-4-7-4-15=38
Golden color, clean, with medium sized head. Wonderful aroma of toasty, bready malts, and delicate citrusy hops. Lean mouthfeel; mild caramel flavor with tones of toasty cereals; strong bitterness, with a bit of hop qualities too, mild citrus presence; it’s rather fresh.
It’s somehow old style, but it’s a very good IPA; I’m enjoying the sixpack.

2006-05-28, bottle, 5.7% ABV, 6-3-6-4-13=32
Copper color. The aroma is quite fruity (apricots). The mouthfees is quite thin; anyway there is some malt taste, dry; the hops have some aromas and fruitiness, but have been added without soul. Medium bitterness, not too much; some late hop resin.

Soft citrus peppery hop aroma, touch of grainey malt, orange amber color, suprisingly light floral citrus hop and malt combo, malt sweetness and hop bitterness vying for attention at the end with the bitterness winning out,but its a tepid scratchy fight. Seems like a nice hop dominated IPA ,just needs some cajones

Oh, Lagunitas... what were you thinking?  We already have Sierra Nevada.  There was no need to create another one, unless your goal was to sucker me into buying a 6 pack, in which case, good job.  Too bad I can’t give you a 5 for that.  Average.  Nothing special.  I generally dig their beers, but this one didn’t catch me.  I drank 2 and gave Naven the other 4.  Took him a month to finish those.  See?  It’s not just me.  Seriously.

12 oz. bottle from Morgan’s.  Drank on 5/14/2006.  Very clear light copper.  Fairly thick 1 cm. rocky off-white head.  Decent lacing, nice layer of foam.  Aroma - not terribly strong.  Piney hops, little bit of sweet malt, a little citrus.  Flavor - pretty well balanced with a nice crisp, almost dry finish.  Not a strong flavor of either hops or malts, but nice amt. of bitterness on the tongue and in the swallow.  Palate - light to medium.  Little on the light side for an IPA.  Overall - an OK IPA.  not a ton of in your face hops.  Not a ton of body, but it does taste good and is pretty easily drinkable.  Definitely doesn’t live up to the hype on the bottle "raging hop character.... imperial malt quality... mortal combat".

Golden orange with nice lacing. Aroma is strongly grapefruity, wafting out of the glass. Taste starts off with a smooth hazlenut kick and quickly fades into strong hoppiness, lots of pine-sol and soapiness, finishing slightly malty again.

Julios Spring Beer Festival. Aroma of distinctly Cascade hops (a trend I would continue to find at this festival). Pour of lightly hazed golden amber. Flavor follows with a swift kick of West Coast hopy fury, but reigned back and fairly balanced. The palate is a little thin for me, but smacks nicely of cranberries. Solid.
A light amber ale with a good foamy head that lasts a little while.  Very bitter tasting with a bit of malt. A very average beer in my opinion.
Robe blonde claire aux reflets orangés surmontée d’une mousse blanche épaisse en dentelle qui persiste. Arômes d’agrumes. Saveurs de malt caramélisé, d’agrumes et de houblon aromatique.

Bottle shared with and courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a clear, very bubbly, orange-amber with an average size lasting foamy off-white head. Decent lacing too, this is a good-looking IPA. Nice mild citrus hop aroma, a little bready and also some roasted malt. 
Flavour of sweet malt, a little bready, with some citrus and pine hops and a long dry bitter finish. Medium bodied. Doesn’t knock my socks off but it’s an enjoyable version of the style.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, my bottle.  Poured clear light amber with a decent lasting tight foamy straw-coloured head.  Nice fresh citrus juicy  hop aroma (orange and sweet grapefruit, some pineapple and apricot) with decent light roast malt - not overwhelming, but very pleasant.  Pretty standard IPA taste, a bit soapy, the hops are quite muted though - has a softly bitter finish.  This is pretty average all round on the palate - moderately carbonated, moderately astringent, relatively quick finishing with a bit of a orange peel aftertaste.  Not bad, there are many ahead of it from Cali.
Orange color.  Smell of grapefruit, pine and hops.  Tastes like a sour grapefruit mixed with pine, rye and very bitter.  My kind of a IPA.

bottle from cafe st. ex.  good balanced bitterness, but too full-bodied.  the malts are quite present and the finish isn’t as clean as i like.  also seemed to be a bit oxidized, possibly just old since it’s probably not that popular a beer at st. ex.  age might’ve also dulled the age on the hops.

12oz bottle: Initial floral hoppy aroma with the sweetness of the malt taking over. An orange copper pour with a minor head. Good medium body with mild carbonation. Flavor starts out with hop bitterness but quickly progresses to a malt sweetness. Mouth feel is slick and smooth. Solid IPA.

[Tap – Blooms & Brews, Silverton Oregon]

(Oregon Craft Brewfest at The Oregon Garden) 
Poured deep copper color with a frothy, creamy white head. Aroma was like a pine tree. Flavor was also piney with grapefruit.  The hop flavors were very present in the brew.  Slight bitterness comes through in the end. Medium bodied. Very smooth and drinkable. Very well balanced. This is a nice IPA.

Really good aromas of pine, grapefruit and grass over a copperish body with a bunch of floaties.  The only criticism I can come up with is that the malt is pretty light in this beer and there is a little bit of a weak spot as the palate develops.  Other than that, this is a finely crafted IPA with a nice balance.
Orange colour with a lasting head.  Distinct IPA hoppy aroma with some grassiness.  Sweet malty taste, but a little unbalanced with the bitterness.  Overall a pretty decent IPA.

Not too bad. Pours orange with a quick dissapating white head, and very minimal lacing. Aroma is bitter hops, piney. Flavor is more malty than I expected, but with a good amount of piney bitter hops in the finish to last, pretty nice.

In bottle: Hadn’t had this in a while and tried it tonight -- Pours a nice amber color, although the head was rather small and barely any lacing.  I expected to get a huge hop taste, instead I got a mild, somewhat malty flavor.  I gotta say, this beer is nothing special.   It tasted like Sierra Nevada Pale Ale to me.  I dont really know why they call this an IPA.  Lagunitas has an odd way of classifying their beers.  The Maximus is described as an "Imperial ale" yet, it seems like an IPA, while the IPA seems like a pale ale.  Not worth the price.

On Tap @ Fat Heads, Pgh, PA



Poured deep copper with a frothy, creamy white head.  Aroma was piney.  Flavor was piney with grapefruit, orange and caramel notes.  The hop flavors were very present, although mellow and now reading that there are 43 different ones in there that’s impressive.  Slight bitterness comes through in the end.  Medium bodied.  Very smooth and drinkable.  Very well balanced.  This is a nice IPA.

Bottle.  Pours nice golden orange color with a medium white head.  Initial aroma that hits me is of pine hops.  Upon closer inspection I get some grapefruit as well.  Taste is sweet and not as hoppy as I would’ve thought, somewhat flowery and grapefruity.  The hops seem a little muted from some candy like sweetness.  The finish has a little malt and a little bitterness.

Bottle.  A hazy copper pour with lots of little floaties and a smallish light-tan head that leaves rings of lace.  Typical IPA aroma profile with lots of oranges and some grapefruits.  Quite floral.  Medium body.  A good bit of sweet caramel and cream upfront keep this from being overly one-sided.  Pretty well-balanced actually.  A drying, bitter finish that lingers.  Pretty standard IPA.

From bottle.  Hearty orange amber pour with an even, medium off-white head.  Cleansing fresh aroma of grapfruit citrus and orchid blossoms, all balanced by a semi-sweet brown sugar and prune maltiness.  Smooth, slightly creamy texture that slides across the tongue delicately, rather than pierce it brutally with its hoppy talons.  The hops take hold of the palate at first, allowing a soft white grapefruit to scrub the tongue clean.  From there, this brew’s softer side takes over, allowing some flavors of wheat toast and raisin to enter the picture.  Final smack of delicate grapefruit rind.

12 oz Bottle: Quite good.  Almost exactly what I would describe an IPA as.  Not that it was outstanding or amazing, just a perfect model for what I expect and imagine when I hear the word IPA.  That knocks my overall score a little higher, but so what.  And to read 43 hops and 65 malts is impressive!

Citrus and hop aroma, copper in color, white head, flavor is of grass, hop, and barely any malt. Weird finish and aftertaste, almost like what i would imagine eating flour or baking soda would taste like. Odd texture left on my tongue. Thoroughly disappointing.

Pours a light reddish-orange color with a thick white head.  Aroma is of hops, citrus (mostly grapefruit), and some floral hints.  Flavor starts off with citrus, mostly orange and some grapefruit.  One of the most citrusy IPA’s I’ve had to date.  Finishes with a little hops but not too much.  The citrus almost overpowers the hops too much but is still a good IPA.

Pours and clear orange gold with a decent white head that dissapears quikly and leaves nice lacing. Bottle conditioned? Lots of sediment swimming throughout this brew. Aroma is hoppy and some citrus with oranges as well. Also some light spices picked up.  Flavor is much the same with a nice initial hoppy bite. Ends bitter. A solid IPA but nothing spectacular.

Clear copper. Modest, frothy, white head. Aroma of big resiny grapefruit hops with a bit pine, also. Same flavor with just enough malt. They could have made a brew that tasted identical with a lot less ingredients. Smooth, medium/light body is a little thin. Solid IPA.
Very tasty IPA.  Full of hop flavor, citrus, caramels, and a slight spiceness reminicent of nutmeg.  Nothing out of the ordinary here, just a solid IPA.

this is a great ipa.  had it several time on draft.  they used to serve it at the maritime music hall in san francisco being the only beer on draft.  nice copper brown hue with tanny brawn head.  nice cascadesque nose of pine and citrus.  flavors explode onto the tongue with tangy bitterness.  evenly balanced with maltiness. good!

Bottled.  Clear copper color with a small off-white head.  Citrusy and floral hop aroma.    Malty with a nice bitterness.  There’s a little orange, grass and pine notes from the hops but it’s rather subdued.  Dry and somewhat musty aftertaste.

Pours a hazy orange with a thin off white head. Has mild aroma not as hoppy as most IPA’s, but there is some along with fruit, citrus and cream soda. Flavor is very well balanced with a smooth and creamy palate and notes of
hops, malts, floral, fruit and pine.
 Over all an excellent IPA.

(12oz Bottles.  Draft.  03/2006)  A classic IPA.  Big hop aroma, citrus and a bit of fruitiness.  Hoppy, hoppy tastes.  Delicious.  Very nice.  Medium bodied.  Caramel notes and relatively spritzy.  Finishes somewhat sweet on the front with a lingering, citrus bitterness in back.  Should be a standard everywhere.

A fairly "nice" IPA.  Emphasis is of course on the hops, but it doesn’t come across too bitter.  The body is lighter, but just heavy enough.  I was expecting more kick, but found a pleasant drink instead.

It’s been awhile since I had an IPA, so I was rather suprised by this slightly above average IPA. The aroma was noticeable but it didn’t really have much in the way of making a big splash. It had some citrus notes but they were fairly muted. The appearance had a nice fluffy head and an orangish hue that was slightly hazy. Mouthfeel was full and round. Flavor was intriguing as I don’t think I’ve had an IPA this sweet. It wasn’t overly sweet for my liking and it had a nice balance of malt and hops. I was enjoying this because it wasn’t overly bitter so I might say this is even a pale ale and not an IPA but that’s just my opinion. An enjoyable IPA that I’d buy again if it’s on sale.

bottle. Hazy copper pour with a receding head. The aroma is nice. Very spicy with pine notes throughtout and some grapefruit, solid for the style. Obviously an IPA in the flavorAll of the characteristics present boldly scream india pale ale: pine, grapefruit, caramel. The problem is lack of balance. The hops come across as semi-chalky and the malts could stand to be more robust. Definitely a textbook ipa, but does not come across as anything that exceeds par for the course.


[September 18, 2012]


Pint from draft at Acoustic Coffeehouse. Sometimes I look at my very early ratings and wonder what my problem was. This is an outstanding IPA. I’m very excited to see it in my local market. The hop character is very dank and potent with lots of grassy and grapefruity notes. Body is great for the style: not too sticky, but not wimpy either. It doesn’t infringe on the hop flavor. This is an above average IPA which makes for a seriously delicious beer.
Solid IPA.  Aroma isn’t much, and the taste is fairly standard, but has a nice hoppy finish.
medium herbal, floral aroma.  white lasting head. golden hazy color. balanced well with bitterness and a touch of sweetness.
A surprising and unfortunately average offering from Lagunitas.  Looks and smells like an IPA, but the taste is flat.  Enjoyably hoppy, but flat.
Average for the style in my tasting so far.  Sometimes these IPA’s work in the sixer variety and this is one of those beers.  Enjoyable, but not slap your momma great lik the Hop Ottin.,
Pours dark amber with a large head.  Fresh citrus and hops are the predominate aroma.    Nice amount of hops, for an IPA.  Not too dominate but, a significant part of the flavor profile.
This is a nice hoppy beer. The aroma was floral. I like the crispness this beer had. I am going be enjoying this, this summer.

Draft at San Diego Brewing Company.  Dark amber color with a decent head.  Aromas were minimal, with some floralish hints.  Flavors were slightly better.  Hops were there, but not much in the way of a malt backbone.  OK, but not great.
Intense fruity aroma. semi fruity flavor but lacked fullness. Something just made it not feel like an ipa. But it was still pleasant. Nice summer beer.

Pours rich golden with good carbonation. Aroma is intense hops with fruity and floral bouquet. Initial flavor is very balanced, with the hops eventually overpowering the rich malt. Finishes with a lingering bitterness, but overall is VERY smooth for an IPA.

Bottle.  Typical IPA with nice nutty finish.  Leans towards the american but slightly more roasty, malty, dark, which is nice, but still not enough to elevate an IPA, which doesn’t need to be as solid and balanced as this one.  Perfectly fine beer but not my cup of tea.
Orange color, small off white head. Slight floral aroma, smells a little sweet. Not much carbonation, not much initial flavor either. Pleasant finish, a little fruity at the end. Not bad.

Bottled:
Cloudy orange appearance. Quite sweet for an IPA. Pleasant to drink and somewhat fruity in the end.
(on bottle) Hzy orange, white head. Abricot, toast in the nose. Soft mouthfeel, some vanilla and apple. a bit of a flat finish.
Pours deep amber into a shaker.  Nice head leaves lacing.  Grass, floral and spruce aromas.  Very strange -- almost slick with little flavor and then a big bitter finish.

Very piney.  Resinous and dry.  Strong bitterness.  Not extremely juicy, but there is a good bit of citrus from the hops.  A bit empty up front, but some nice biscuity malt.  Pretty full mouthfeel.  Good example of what hops taste like, with a nice balance.  Now if they just built up the front of it...

Pours honey colored w/ a medium sized, semi creamy froth. Aromas of citrus rind and pine w/ a slight maltiness. Medium  nectar w/ ample residual effers. Overall a very simple IPA. Very light yet w/ solid hops. Good yet not impressed.

Bottle RFD, Washington DC. I’ve been in the US for 4 days and I’ve crossed some line or other, I’m finding beers described as "homicidally hoppy" on the bottle, quite well balanced! Clear amber with a slim white head. Hoppy aroma with some fruit. Very hoppy taste but some balancing malt components. Full bodied; excellent.
Tap. Nice IPA that looks golden and amber with a nice head. This is a very hoppy IPA, flowery aroma and a bitter finish. It has a rich mouthfeel and is very pleasing on the palate.

I have never had anything from this brewer before but being that I am a bit of a hophead I was looking forward to trying it. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a slightly hazy bronze color with a large tan head. The aroma is strong grapefruit and fruit cocktail. The mouthfeel is nice and fairly thick. The malt presence surprised me in such a hoppy beer. The flavor is strong full bore grapefruit and fruit cocktail. The beer is marvelously hoppy and pleasantly sweet with a goodly amount of malt despite the dominance of the hyper aggressive hops. Wonderful.
Orange color with a big thick beige head.  Aroma of piney hops. Flavor also of piney hops with some sweet malt in the background. Even though this is all hops its not excessivly bitter.

Not often I can say this about a beer. But, this one will knock your sox off. Really delicious and what I have been long looking for in an IPA. The hops are pretty extreme. The body firm yet well balanced. A nice creamy sort of head and great aroma. If I had two suggestions it would be to include the IBU rating and ABW which are lacking on the label. In conclusion, I will be keeping my eyes open for more selections by Lagunitas and definitely be buying more of this truly great IPA.
Not a bad brew, smell was of mostly hops. Taste was a little more malt than I expected, but pleasant, and was followed by the hop explosion. Slightly bitter, but not bad.
Pours a nice deep amber color.  Aromas of hops/hops/citrus.  Strong hop flavors with malts and a dry finish.
There is a nice earthy aroma and the color is amber with a light tan head.  The taste starts of with a malty sweetness and quickly finishes with a strong hop flavor.

A "REAL" Winner! When someone tells me a particular beer is a regular award winner, I am instantly skeptical and unconsciously think I will already dislike it, as if to say - award winner hah! well we’ll see about that... But this multiple award-winning IPA is truly a winner in my book. On tap at the "Sweet Spot" bar in Santa Rosa, CA. pours a beautiful yellow gold with saffron highlights. its frothy beige head goes the distance kept company by the ubiquitous chunky lacing. the aroma can only be described as "berry delight" or "fruity tooty". rasberries, strawberries, grapefruit, cherries. there all there. pine hops and toasted malts hide out in the background and assuage the strong citrus bellowings. tastes of light hops, (corresponds to the slightly bitter taste), sweet malts, grapefruit, and dough. finishes crisp and more solidly bitter. light mouthfeel. Refreshing!

Poured a clear effervescent amber iwth a large creamy/frothy off-white head.  Aroma of pine hops and a touch of caramel.  Taste is fairly mild but clean pine and floral hops, some brown sugar sweetness and a dry finish backed by a bit of toffee.  Easy-drinking, straight-forward, run-of-the-mill IPA.
Pours copper with a white head and lots of floaties.  Smells of citrus, pine, yogurt, wildflowers.  Tastes of citrus with some mellow wildflower notes.

deep amber with a white head.  gamey flavor that is very nice, tastes fresh or homegrown, Earthy.  With this the beers palate is a little course and unrefined but the whole product is still fairly good.
This is a well balanced brew.  I prefer an IPA that’s a little more bitter, but this is an excellent choice for those that prefer a more malty beverage.
Orange beer with a small off white head. Light caramel malty aroma with a citric hoppy fruityness. Sharp hoppy bitterness along a low key malty sweetness.

Bottle. Clear copper color with an average rocky white head that was lasting and produced good lacing. Good hoppy citrus aroma. Medium body. Moderate hoppy bitter flavor with an average finish. Good brew.

12oz bottle - Pours amber with a short white head that stays pretty well but doesn’t lace much on the way down.. Aroma is light grapefruit and pine with a fair malt presence as well in the aroma.  Flavor is not as hoppy as other west coast IPAs I’ve had.  Fairly balanced a nice blend of caramel malts and citrus hops.  Palate is smooth and medium bodied.  Very drinkable would make a nice session.
Bottle. Off white creamy and lasting head. Golden unclear body. Aroma of oranges and malt. . Lovely and long lasting hops bitternes.

unlike some over the top american ipa, this is a well balanced brew.  hazy orange colored appearance with yellowish head.  floral aroma of grapefruit and citrus.  full bodied, hoppy as should be.  though i do think the 43 different hops and 65 various malt recipe is probably a commercial gimmick.

Bottle. Very hoppy aroma with lots of citrus and strawberry marmalade. Flavor is hoppy, but backed up by a good malt foundation. Spicy and peppery. Bitter finish. A very well balanced beer and very flavorful for its modest strength.

Pours orange-amber with a two-finger white head. Standard west coast IPA aroma--citrus- and pine-heavy, with very light malt backing. Very hoppy, with virtually no malt flavor. Dry, grassy, and citrusy finish. A bit one-sided, but very good.

Bottle and on draught at Palomino’s, San Francisco.  Very similar so I’ll rate together.  Light orange, big thick off white head.  Looks nice.  Fresh strong citrus hop aroma.  Very nice hop and sweet malt taste - very nice and balanced.  Strong orange citrus hops but good mix of tasty malt.  Falvourful bread like.  Very nice IPA, I’d say the bottle tasted better than the pint, only because the of the sub par restaurant’s handling of it - it didn’t taste as fresh.
Nice crisp and fruity IPA with a sweet floral nose and nice body.  A graprefruit citrus backing it against the malt and strong hopping.  Good stuff.
this was a great IPA - It was one of the best I smaple( at brewtopia in NYC - rgith up there with Stone and Smuttynose.

Pours a clear orange/pinkish color body with a clingy, white foam on top.  Aroma was sweet citrus and piney hops.  It seems that all of the hop flavors are balancing each other out.  You get about a half of a second of every flavor associated with hops.  Never enough of any to really make me jump but all around a very well/over balanced ipa.  Great session brew!

pretty good, piney aroma golden color with white frothy head.  Flavor was hoppy but not over bitter.  Its only draw back was that it seemed somewhat watered down it did not have a fullness on the tounge.
Bottle. Orange colour with a big off-white head. Sweet very floral hop, citrus aroma and a sweet dry grape, hop taste. Medium body and a dry hop finish.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a medium orange with little head.  Intense floral aroma with heavy doses of citrus fruit as well.  Nice malty backbone that finishes like I just ate a piece of grapefruit.  Terrific mouthfeel.  Good IPA.
(Bottle 35,5 cl) Beautiful, clear amber colour with a creamy, off-white head. Sweetish aroma of caramel and a shot of aroma hops. Sweet, malty flavour with a bitter finish. 171005

"Life is uncertain. Don’t sip" it says on the label. What a lovely philosophy! The beer itself is very similar to the other lagunitas that I’ve had. Not a lot of carbonation. It’s a pleasant, only slightly bitter IPA. No revolution.
[bottle] Pours great, smells great, and has a nice hop profile as well. I’d like to see some more sweetness to back the already present bitterness in the brew. It’s good, but I’ll take the Maximus.
hops hops and more hops come through in this awesomely good ale.  beautiful color and a fantastic fruity finish.

It looks like this was bottle conditioned but carefully poured, it’s crystal clear and glowing orange w/ a rapidly diminishing head of large bubbles. The nose is wonderful--incredibly floral w/ a pinch of citrus and some bready goodness underneath it all. The flavor doesn’t hold up, however--somewhat watery and lacking the sticky sweetness and intense bitterness that make a great IPA. There is an interesting ice tea thing going on though so it’s not a total wash.
An amber beer with an orange head. The aroma is nicely grassy and hoppy - Cascade clearly present. The flavor is sweet malty with an OK grassyness from Cascade hops, and a dry end.

Bottle (Pint). Aroma is nicely hoppy, not too strong or weak, and with some pleasant citrus/grapefruit tones mixed in. Pours a medium caramel, similar in color to bourbon. Head is a thick creamy white. Flavor is initially of hops, with some citrus/grapefruit-like hints included. Hoppiness is nicely done, being not to strong, but not too weak. This is a very well done IPA!

The body is dark orange with a frothy white head. There are planty of bubbles coming up here. The aroma is grapefruit and some caramel. There is also an earthy cherry smell.
