The taste is carmel and some piney hops with a littel burnt toast. This could use a little balance. There is the very bitter hopping, then some very sweet notes. Not much in between.

Bottled.
Clear amber coloured with a solid white head.
Aroma of hops, pine needles, grape fruit, grass and caramel.
Perfumed flavour of grass, pine needles, hops and caramel.

Fine white head, slightly hazy orange golden body. Dominating grassy and earthly aroma, not very bitter. Sweet fruity notes. Flavor is also fruity with bready notes and an underlying bitterness. Not the most interesting IPA, rather macroish and ordinary.

(From a trade with Dark Elf-thanks)  A high quality ipa.  The aroma starts with a powerful hint of brandy that faded in only a few seconds.  Ordinary appearance; short lived head, gold in color.  Different flavors all related to hops.  There is dry grass and some citrus, with a dry finish.

Bottled: Dark golden/amber coloured. Clear. Dark beige dense head. Lasting. Flowers, fruit, herbs and sweetness in the aroma. Flavour is malty and sweet with a herbal hoppyness. Is quite grassy. Well balanced and medium bodied. Is medium bitter in the end. Quite good one.

12 oz bottle. Pours out clear amber, with a fluffy, two finger tan head that lasts and lasts. When it finaly does start to recede, it leaves rings of sticky lace.

Aroma is sweet malt up front, with some grapefruit and orange oil as it warms.

Flavor is lightly malty, around some citrusy hops.

Finish is mildly bitter.


Nicely balanced, will definately buy again.
Hop aftertaste that tastes good at room temp, that’s what makes a good product. I highly recommend this brewery.
pours a beutiful orange colour, nice head i guess, good lacing though...has a awesome sweet hopped up smell, and a sweet taste, a good solid brew that has a good clean bitters

Poured a clear copper color with a small off-white head.  Aroma of citrus grapefruity hops and fuity sweet malt underneath.  Malt at front and back, before the moderate sized bitter finish, with grapefruit rind running down the center.  Medium bodied.  Didn’t expect this to be so good when I picked it up.
Pours light brown with a nice white head. Aroma is fruity hops. Taste is full of hops with a great malty back to it. Full mouthfeel. Somewhat piney. A great IPA.

This one is unique.  It’s not like it’s west coast brothers...this IPA has a different malt profile and hop character than your typical west coast style IPA.  Maybe this has more English IPA style to it...I need to try more of those.  The aroma is malty with a bit of alcohol coming through.  Taste is much the same...toasty malt and good hop flavor.  These hops are all flavor and no bittering or aroma...to bad so sad.  Still, this in an IPA that’s on my regular "BUY" rotation.

Deep copper color with a light head.  Bit fizzy on the mouth.  Nose has some prunes and lots and lots of hops.  Mouth also very hoppy, bit bitter.  Not very balanced, but as I’m a hop head, still quite good.

I do like this beer. I cannot say what makes it more appealing the more i drink it. Maybe they’re getting better all the time. Nice Hops... maybe just the right amount on some days. Wouldn’t do on a heavy flow day though. Viva le hop!

Nicely balanced but surprisingly small for a Lagunitas and surprisingly small for a west coast IPA.  The right flavors are all there, but it lacks the intense bitterness, intense citrus, intense pine I expected ... but it looks great, with a wonderful creamy mouth.  Enjoyable.
Pretty orange with a nice head.  Interesting flavors ranging form carmel to fruit.  Has a great hoppy finish.

Clear salmon tinted orange with a beautiful, full head of creamy foam.  Butter and caramel, with loads of hop resin in the aroma, spruce and medicine jar.  Malt is very lush and bold, creamy and full with a rich caramel, toffee and fruit flavor and I believe there may be some diecetyl, but in a desireable way.  The hops are spicy and piney and could stand to be kicked up a notch or two, to be honest.  I find it quite nice.

In the bottle at the Huber Haus IPA tasting. Orange with an off-white good sized head. Sweet malty aroma with bread-like undertones. Low carbonation. Decent lacing. Solid malty palate. Seems like a much higher IBU content than 46. Strong hoppy finish on the tongue. Good gypsum flavoring. Rich sweetness.

Color is hazy, ethereal orange, with a 3/4 inch diminishing off-white head, small bead and some lacing.  Aromas are orange citrus, white bread, and a walnut/almond nuttiness.  Upon tasting, a floral hop quality, sourdough, and some soapy alcohol notes make up the flavor profile.  Mouthfeel is thick and somewhat creamy, with a strong hop bite and a fading, effervescent hop/malt finish.  Overall, a decent, complex IPA.  Maybe not as assertive and hop-dense as the big boys, but a must-have on any comprehensive tasting to show off flavor and palate.
golden amber with a large head and lots of lacing.  heavy fruit flavors and aromas through-out with a special kick of hoppiness at the end of the beer.  Great for an IPA

Beautiful hazy and deep copper color with a creamy, sudsy and graying head.  Big fresh hops jump out of the glass accompanied later by grass, papaya and grapefruit.  A very inundating hops accentuated aroma.  Flavor proceeds as lighter than expected.  Caramel, nectarines, honey and sugar basking grapefruit.  A little thin on the palate.  Reserved but balanced.  Finishes like honey soaked diluted hops.

Pours with a big but short lived head. Light yellow with a slight haze. Sweet aroma, fresh hops of a NW variety. Refined candied malt flavor, balanced with big floral, estery hops. Finish is drying, crisp. Round earthiness. Very good.

Dark orange-bronze color with a thin head.  Light fruity maly aroma with some citrus hops.  Very fruity flavor--almost a hint of peach tea--with a very subdued hops edge and some nice creeping hops bitterness in the finish.  Fairly full-bodied and well-balanced but lacks real crispness.
Six pack on vacation out West.  Dark, aggressive, american style IPA - more bittering hops and less aromatic - maybe close to a Hop Devil?

Clear, amber body with a fluffy off-white head.  Moderately hoppy aroma of pine, grapefruit, caramel, grains, and a touch of residual sweetness.  The body is pretty damn good for an IPA.  Not too thick, but not lacking in any qualities either.  The flavor is good and certainly tasty.  The malt is sweet and robust, with a bitter, piney flavor that makes things interesting.  I could drink this with some regularity, methinks.

Beautifully crafted hop nose is balanced nicely with undertones of caramel malts.  Fizzy carbonation leads to surprisingly little bitterness and a somewhat watery start.  The caramel malts I was looking foward too are rather diminished, even as the IPA warms.  The hops are much more pronounced in the finish though, leaving a lasting bitter impression.  A good start, but needs more "oomph" for the lack of a better descriptor.

Bottle from Pailhead.  Lightly hazy and amber colored.  Decent off-white head leaves good lacing.  Aroma is piney, a touch earthy.  Medium to light bodied.  Caramel malt flavor balanced by piney hop flavor.  Nothing exceptional.

Reminds me of a watered-down Bells Two Hearted Ale. Somewhat of a floral aroma, but could use more. Lots of complex hop flavor that runs from biting to dry to floral. Well-balanced malts. I’d never heard of this beer until I saw a sixer on sale at Safeway. Would buy again.

Not too bitter for an IPA.  It tastes like it has been blended nicely with the malt.  The aroma isn’t overpowering, but smells like pine needles with a little lemon mixed in.  Not the smoothest beers, but personally I favor this to Stone IPA which has a higher rating.

22 oz capped bottle: clear apricot bronze with a thin film of a head that leaves thick, starched white lacing all around the glass.  Fresh, grapefruity and piney aroma that isn’t as over powering as I may have thought, and offers some fresh strawberry and apple esters as well.  Sticky, slightly sour and moderate hop bitterness throughout the palate.  Grainy mouth feel.  Caramel flavours are an after thought and are missing the normal sweetness.  Not one of my favourite IPAs, but pretty decent anyway.

On tap at the Maple Leaf Grill in Seattle.

Pours a clear but saturated golden with an adequate head.

Palate is somewhat unsatisfying; aroma is fruity, as is the taste; fruit notes overwhelm the bitterness and the malts are are very scantly represented. This one is not as full as many of the better IPA competitors, though certainly pleasent enough to drink.

Pours a nice golden color with a quickly disappearing head. Nice citrusy smell, classic IPA-ish. Taste is smooth with just a touch of hop bitter. It’s a decent IPA that’s worth a try. Not my favorite IPA, but not bad either.

Very fruity aroma, almost candy-like. Hops are very up-front. Pours a lovely golden color, hints of red throughout. Small head. Flavor is also very fruit heavy, with hops to back it up. Very little malt presence, making it a bit unbalanced. This is a bit harsh on the mouth, not like Stone Ruination, but the lack of balance makes it a little rough. Still, a quality IPA. USA v. Honduras! Let’s go BLUE!!!

Courtesy of Pailhead. Pours light copper with film for head. Aroma is very muted floral/citrus hops. Flavor, also muted, is mostly caramel with a little hop presence in finish. Decent, but lacks in aroma and flavor.

Lightly beige head on a saffron colored body.  Smells is of hops, duh, tons of citrus and rosemary, lovely.  Tastes, well like an IPA, nice caramel finish on this one though.  the finish is extraordinarily clean, it just seems to disappear down your throat, but a mild bitterness lingers.   Very easy drinking I must say.  Probably the most satisfied I have been with an IPA.

Bottle: Vibrant orange, soft haze, thick foamy white head, beautiful lacing, very low carbonation.   Soft hop nose, noticable sweat (wet grains).   Very pale hop profile, soft, subtle, nice, but not as sturdy as I would have liked.   Somewhat fleeting, mixed with a touch of tobacco leaf.   Moderate to full body and mouthfeel.   Clean finish, fairly light overall but decent.

Copper upon pouring.  Thick, off-white head.  Aromas of big hops, tons of citrus (grapefruit and pineapple) and some pepper.  Tastes full bodied with tons of lupulin and a finishing burst of hops and citrus plus a final black pepper hit on the tonsils.  Marvelous.

Pours to a thick creamy, rocky white head that quickly thins to a patch head with a ring around the glass.  Pretty good lacing.  The body is a copper kettle color.  The aroma is huge grapefruit and oranges.  Aroma faded a touch, but is still fairly potent.  The flavor is rich and caramely with a good bit of oranges and a light grapefruit.  Appealing, but nothing spectacular.  The palate is pretty good.  Could be crisper.  Overall, this is a good beer, but the brewer has some room for improvement.  43 hops?  65 malts?  Shouldn’t this be off the hook?!?!?!

On Tap at Kahootz:  With a light copper color, this IPA showed like it is supposed to - grapefruit tastes in the hops with average carbonation.  The only word that I could think of after trying this one was: yummy.
Amber with a nice hoppy aroma. Flavour has some decent malty flavours with a medium bitterness and hopping. The first bit didn’t seem that hoppy but it built up after a while.

Bottle:  Courtesy of beerguy101 via trade.  Aroma is citrusy, but not citrus hoppy, with light caramel.  Pours a transparent orange with a white head that lasts a minute or so.  Light caramel up front with a slightly watery piney hop finish.  Decently balanced but flavor just aren’t that strong.

Smell is faint for an IPA, but the body is beautiful.  The head just blends ianto the flavor, which is mildly hoppy as far as IPAs go.  Truly, though, this beer is best described as delicious.  A must try, especially since this is the type of IPA that can be enjoyed numerous times in one sitting. Thanks parents!
Citric, slightly herbal leafy hop aromas, solid maltiness, tannic tea-like bitterness.  Dryish, but big mouthfeel.  Very nice!

On tap.  Poured a slightly murky copperish color, with a lacing, thin white head.  Smelled of grassy hops, and watered down malts.  Tasted rather sweet and malty, with grassy hop notes, and a slightly hidden citrusy hop flavor.  A rather watered down flavor in my opinion, but an easy drinker.  Was not impressed by the brew!
Another CA IPA, less aggressive hops than expected.A sweeter IPA than others, Pine resin, oakiness, easy drinking. Would be a good sesion brew!

Bottle.  Pours a golden copper with nice white head.  Decent grapefruity hop aroma with malts present, tho it didn’t seem as assertive as I would have liked.  Medium to light bodied mouthfeel, and a hoppy flavor and medium bitter bite.  Finishes fairly crisp.  Good drinkable IPA.

A particularly well-done IPA that lives up to this IPA Hound’s standards.  Satisfies more than any IPA I’ve had besides Stone’s.  Heavy pine aroma.  Great head retention.  Flavor very nicely parallels the aroma.  Rich, crisp, comes off very fresh.  Missing a certain balance I can’t quite place that is met by the Stone IPA, my personal standard.  Still, it’s some top-notch stuff, well above the 4/5 IPA mainstream.

Bottle. Slightly murky light copper color with good head and lacing. Good earthy and citrus hop aroma. Earth and citrus with a little pine and some piny notes. There is a nice lingering bitterness. Smooth and refreshing. Nice beer.

Strong hop aroma with mild citrus notes. pours honey orange. My bottle was swamped with yeast residue. Appropriate mouthfeel for the style. Well managed hops at 45.6 IBU, but I think my bottle was too old cause it just tasted unfresh.

Couleur orangée pale allant vers le cuivrée, bonne formation de mousse initiale disparaissant rapidement.  Arômes de malt biscuit, de beurre, de faible caramel et de timide houblon entre le floral et l’agrume.  Faible présence de diacety, s’amplifiant avec le temps et devenant légèrement inapproprié pour le style dans cette proportion.  Court en bouche, malt biscuit suivi d’une faible attaque de houblon faisant vaguement allusion au citron et aux concombres verts.  Corps semi mince, fine carbonatation présente.  Le manque de complexité en d’intensité du houblon en fait un breuvage relativement simple et unidimensionnel.

Bottle. 
Dark charneol colour. Mandarin, hoppy nose. Big body. Thorough hop dryness. Very well balanced. Fresh hops cover the palate.

12oz. Hazy golden with an orange tinge. Thick white head. Fair amount of hops in the aroma, citrus, orange, some bread aromas. Body is medium and crisp. Bitterness in back of throat. Medium hop flavor. Well balanced.
Pretty good IPA.  Good Citrus and Graitfruit hops however the beer is one dimensional throughout.
pours an orange copper color with a fairly lasting head.  Not nearly as aggressive a hop character as the bottle proclaims.  Hop flavor is slightly piney crisp.   Mildly bitter.

Fairly mild and non-aggressive of an IPA, this ale pours an orange-copper body with a sudsy, well retained head.  The aroma is hops, predominantly pine with some grassiness and a smattering of orange.  It’s well balanced, the malt half of the equation being mild and caramelly.  Mildly bitter finish.  More of a session APA than an IPA, really.

Sam’s Wine & Spirits, Downers Grove, IL

Hazy and reddish/orange like dark honey, some clumpy deposits, and patchy lace.  The hop nose is piney and somewhat grassy.  Creamy malt character, the hop finish feels prickly on the back of my tongue, which is pretty enjoyable.  Low carbonation.  A very decent IPA, certainly not the best I’ve ever had, but I wouldn’t refuse another.

Not really hoppy enough for me to call an IPA.  A decent pale ale with light amber cloudy color and plenty of lacing.  Alcohol is upfront and lingering.  43 diffewrent hops? Maybe thats the problem. Use every color in your waterpaint tray and you end up with brown. Not too exciting.

Floral piney, tea nose.  Very lovely honey amber, with particles in suspension.  Small whitish head dalmost completely disappears, yet leaves nice lacing.  Earthy, fainttly caramel malts, woody, medium body, great mouthfeel, more earthen dusty hops, with a resinous finish.  A darn nice brew I must say.  Well balanced I must say.
Dark amber body with off white frothy head. Glass had lots of lacing though out the beer. Had a citrus aroma and had a good alcohol kick at the end like most IPA’s I’ve had do. Good beer, liked it,
Average IPA, Light to moderate hops,  NIce color and head but not as bitter as i like ’em. all around, it was good but didn’t stand out among the many IPA’s out there

Pale golden color with yellow accents.  Fruity hop aroma, not overly resinous.  Smooth mouthfeel with medium body, nice maltiness balanced by very floral and citrusy hop flavor.  Residual resin and spiciness sometimes evident in hop-dominant beers is not present.  Excellent example of an American IPA.  Not as full flavored as I tend to enjoy, but very drinkable.

Nice fluffy creamy head. Some citrus mixed with flowery hops but not over the top on the hops. More like a pale ale than an IPA. A bit of malty flavor too. Some spice is revealed as it warms. Good but there are others on the shelf I’d reach for first. One & done.
I really like this IPA.  Nice hop flavor...nothing overboard.  Nice white head and crisp flavor.
Not an IPA I would buy.  Signature off, Lagunitas nose. Boring and oxidized finish very bland pale ale, not an IPA.

March 1, 2005: Just sampled a couple of these on tap at JFK Int’l while waiting to board a delayed flight.  Overall, I found this IPA to be very tasty and satisfying -- a NICE effort! 



Tried this again on tap at the Blue Tusk in Syracuse, NY -- excellent IPA! 



12 oz. bottle on Nov. 15, 2006: This is a VERY tasty and well-balanced IPA.  A bit more subdued (i.e., not over-the-top hoppy) like some of the other West Coast varieties, but this is definitely a winner.

This beer poured an orange/brown w/ golden highlights w/ thin head and lacing.  The aroma was citrusy and flowery w/ hints of pine.  The flavor was all oranges and pine.  The mouthfeel was light and carbonated.

Bottle Pours a clear amber with a very small off white head.   Spotty lacing. Aroma is mainly hops.  Flowery and piney mostly.  Flavor is a nice sharp bitter hopiness, with some full malty flavors imediatley following.  Feel is not as thick or full bodied as my favs of the style.  After taste is a quite bitter lingering burn.  A bit much.

On Tap @ Dutch Goose: nice floral and evergreen hop nose; rich,  earthy, malty, background well supported by modest hopping; creamy, moderately full bodied mouthfeel; quite drinkable and complex; this would be a great summer fishing day brew, and is my new favorite everyday IPA.

Pours amber with a thin white head and little lacing.  Smells really neat like bitter cherries and some hops to the smell as well.  Tastes a littler bitter and hoppy moderately bitter/long aftertaste but a fairly unimpressive flavor, lagunitas maximus is better.  Palate fairly unimpressive but not bad.  Decent IPA but nothing special.

Bottle poured dark amber with a smallish head and spotty lacing.
Aroma was malty with very small aroma of hops.
Flavor is more citrus than hops, I could use a bit more hops in this beer but it is good and easy drinking.
bottle, floral hop aroma orange /bronze color small  white head.  lil hoppy flavor, not overpowering good maltny balance. decent IPA

Taken from notes made during a business trip to San Francisco: Pours reddish golden with initially frothy and quickly diminishing head. Aroma is flowery/herbal but also sweet malt. Flavor is all malt with a solid hop presence. MIldly bitter finish but has a lingering taste. Not the best IPA but good overall. Needs more hops! 

Well, I wish I had made better notes but I was kind of unprepared. I do not recall it being remarkable in the least.
Poured an orange color with little head..  Citrus hoppy aroma.  Flavor is of citrusy hops with a little malt.. This one would be better with more hops. Not bad but not great..

Very tasty IPA, very well done, deep copper color with a slight orange tint, decent sized off-white head, sticky lacing around the glass, lots of earthy hops in the nose, medium body, very drinkable, great session beer, very well balanced, good malt profile to back up the hops, some notes of pine & earth in the flavors, very dry & bitter, especially in the finish and aftertaste, very good IPA

Pours a golden orange, white bubbly head.  Aroma is citrus fruits, hops. Flavor is "easy" and balanced, a piney hop flavor with mint, and lemon.  Palate is somewhat smooth and malty.  Thanks to Mitch for this Brew, my 300th on RateBeer.

Hop nose, spicy flavor and medium body.   Scores good on the standard India Pale Ale "checklist".    With "43 different hops and 65 various malts" I think the brewer worked too hard on an above average IPA.

copper/orange color, head is white, foamy, and somewhat lasting. aroma has notes of citrus, bitter perspiration, sweet toffee malts. flavor has light citrus bitter, light to moderate malts. light to medium-bodied.  would be an excellent session IPA. Thanks Mitch!
A nice dry IPA with a very bitter finish.  I can’t wait for this brewer to start distribution in Florida.

2004 bottle purchased at Julio’s in Westboro, MA.  For good old pasteurised, heavily filtered Lagunitas, I will have to give some credit here.  First of all, they knew what they wanted.  They wanted to expand the market and send a good beer from west to east coast.  That’s cool, and is impressive that they distribute out here in the weak Boston market.  Anyways, they pay the price.  It’s just a plain filtered golden ale.  Hops in the nose recommend that you smell deeper, but it’s nothing heavy.  Just some moderate hops, no dry hopping it seems.  Anyways, it has  good flavor, which is probably its best character.  Medium body, good malt presence.  Spicy, but not really bitter.  Light caramel.
Rerate.
2006 bottle.  ended up dumping it.  Just blandly boring.  Cheaply sweet, filtered maltiness is extremely uncomplex.  Loose, forced carbonation and a boring c-hop aroma and flavor.  Not attenuated enough either.  Slight acid on the end.
More simple, bland crap for the palate-lacking from Lagunitas.
A very good IPA. A little malty. Gold colour and good head. Hops are present in the aroma and the flavour in respectable amounts.

The label describes this beer as an assault of hops.  I didn’t find this description to be accurate.  Yes there are hops but I’m dropping the assault charges.  First, it pours a clear copper color with a decent sized white head.  The aroma is hard to come by, with faint scents of citrus (mostly grapefruit) and some pine.  Medium bodied with creamy malt flavors.  This creamy smoothness is overwhelmed by a moderate hop presence in the finish.  There’s a gentle lingering presence of hops after each sip.
I enjoyed the smoothness of this beer but I was expecting a better hit of hops out of this one.

bottle. strange aroma, there is some floral hopping but there are also notes of butter. hazy orange body with lots of "floaties". good hop character. good balance. dry bitter finish. It’s a little off, but still it’s a decent IPA.

Bottle.  Very clean citrus/pine hop aroma.  Transparent copper color with big frothy pale tan head.  Start is watery.  Finish is pretty weak and thin.  There are some perfumey floral tasting hops in the middle, but they fail to capture my attention.  A fair amount of malts, but they do not add too much either.  Too benign for me.
Pours somewhat orange in color. Lots of sediment floating about. Aroma is hoppy and sweet. Flavor is hoppy and somewhat malty. Bitter hoppy finish.

Had this alongside the Avery IPA and prefered this one.  Much fuller flavor and profile, but the Avery did have a nicery and more noticeable citrus nose.  Very drinkeable and not as knock you over hoppy as most IPAs.  Very well balanced, just like their imperial stout.  This brewery is impressive... glad it’s made its way to the east coast.

Pours golden yellow with a nice, frothy head that doesn’t wear out its welcome.  First taste is slightly viscous palate-wise, and the hops immediately jump upon the taste buds.  Hints of orange and grapefruit are followed by a bitter lemon taste.  The malt adds a nice sweet aftertaste in the finish.  Good brew.

yum yum!! 43 hops and 65 malts and still subtle. starts sweet, ending in a persistent fresh hop flavor in the back of the throat. Mild carbonation, nice foamy head, cumulus like. Good balance for an IPA, reminds me of Anchor Liberty.
Orange shiny pour.  Litle to no head. Very smooth mouthfeel.  No sharp hop bite on the tongue which is a nice plus for me.  Slight bitter aftertaste.  Nice and a little bit different.

Pours out hazy orange/yellow color with a head.  This is kinda like weaker version of IPA.  Light flavor, not too hoppy.  Nice citrus flavor.  Abit soapy taste.  Don’t hardly taste the alcohol.   But very expensive; $7.49 per 6 pack.  Alright brew.  Had better IPA than this.

This one pours a slightly hazy amber orange color with a decent sized white head. Not much retention or lacing going on here the head is only visible for the opening act. There are also plenty of yeasty morsels swimming around the brew. The smell is citrus hoppiness but not much else to be detected, a little under whelming. Taste is very hoppy with nice citrus grapefruit bitterness to it. Slightly sweet finish from the weak malt character here, the taste defiantly stands out more than the smell. Mouthfeel is near perfect its like a velvet hop carpet is rolled out over your palette. This is a very drinkable and sessionable brew. Overall better than average IPA with a good hop kick to it.

a good lappy head lives comfortably and prospers atop this beer, foam the color of raw sugar, and the sagging dots of lace make endless exclamation points that cannot help but excite the taster.  the beer itself is like dried corn or the bright but aged tiger-teak orange of a violin top. a nice aroma dances about, being loquacious about  toffee and lumber and orange blossom. the hops are delicate, like eau de hop-bud in a perfumatic spritz for the refined lady’s bath, a smell of spring greenery, and a gob of caramel sizzling in butter. nice floral hops in the flavor have both a fruity tang and a bitterness that lingers like sucking on a trumpet valve, vying with lightly sweet doughnut malts.

Amber with a small white head. 
Odd metallic nose with some orange notes. Thin flavored, tangy, musty, dominated by bitter hops. Little to no sweetness, and some diacetyl notes.

(12 oz bottle: Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA) This beer features a fairly malty, somewhat bready nose for an IPA, with only a mild hoppiness.  In the flavor, the hops bitterness is also pretty mild for an IPA, and the bready, mildly sweet malt is strong enough to throw the balance slightly toward the malty side initially, with the hops eventually becoming a bit more assertive for a balanced finish.  Medium bodied, and the palate is balanced but average in viscosity.  Chunky particles are suspended in the cloudy, light amber colored beer anc are swirled around by the very active carbonation bubbles.  Off-white head pours to average size and settles to a thin layer, leaving a fair amount of lacing spread around the glass.  Overall, this beer is pleasant and flavorful, but probably about average to me for an IPA.  I’m not much of a hophead, but even I think this IPA needs more presence from the hops to deserve a higher rating.
Poured amber-bronze, cloudy with suspended particles. Spare head. Piney aroma, citrus hop flavor. Finished quickly with slight bitterness.

Poured a light copper color with a small off white head with sticky lacing on the glass.  Light citrus hop, earth, majorly sweet, malty aroma.  Sweet citrus hop taste, coconut, other fruits, finishing with a light bitterness.  Nicely balanced, quaffable IPA.

My 3rd Lagunitas variety, hoping for the best after 2 average brews.

Hops are not very prominent, maybe a bit stale for the "cute" label they put on this one.  Very bitter going down, finish is weak bitter hops, no balance.  Poured half a bottle.

This has an excellent initial taste, but the aftertaste ... not a great ending.  The smell and apperance were promising, overall the IPA was good, not great.  Aftertaste lacked the transtiion that could have provided an excellent experience.

Bottle. Aroma of caramel, spicy hops.  Hazy, burnt orange with suspended particulate matter. Thin white head with some lacing. Fruity and full of hop flavor with body to match. Good combination of citrus and resins. Just enough rough bitterness to remind you to think about what you are drinking. A bit of tin can in the finish. Maybe some oxidation. A dependably good IPA though it is consistantly inconsistant.

Tap @ The Yardhouse Pasadena,CA - fresh keg
Neutral nose.
Cloudy orange amber, low creamy head.
Pine bitterhops blanket tastebuds.
Medium body, smooth mouthfeel. Pine bitterhop aftertaste.
A very excellent IPA.  I have consummed vast quantities of it while in the SF Bay Area and in San Diego. I used to think this was the best IPA I has tasted until I ran into Stone IPA.

Orange/copper coloured body with a thin white head. Aroma of pacific northwest hops, caster sugar, some malt & some grapefruit. Flat hop flavour showing no bitterness at all. Aftertaste clean with no wheat or hop character. A few months old-but kept in a fridge. This one should hold up! Overall, try a different IPA from the west than this one! I sampled this 12 ounce bottle purchased at Norm’s in Vienna, Virginia on 09-October-2004 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia with my good friend Jon[R888710].

The head was creamy with excellent lacing.  The head did dissapate over time.  There were particles floating and suspended in the beverage.  For some beer drinkers that would be a negative.  The particles did settle on the bottom. Flavors were of grapefruit  hops and citrus.  The Overall taste was superb.   I am big fan of IPA’s.  I have two more IPA’s to compare this on to.  I enjoyed another on 11/20.  It is getting difficult to find IPAs that I have not had. Another was consumed in 2009 purchased at Whole Foods.  It was good but not 3.5  I will try another.

Bottled. Amber color with a small white head. Nice hop aroma with a lot of citrus.
Somewhat bitter hop flavor that is balanced fairly well with the malt. Dry
finish.

Sampled on tap.  I found this to be mediocre for a west coast IPA.  Although I do like other offerings from Lagunitas.
Dark amber in color, thin head and no lacing.  Smell is very malty with only a hint of hops here.  Flavor is fairly blanaced with a moderate bitterness and spicy hop note.  Light to medium bodied.  I’ll pass on this one in the future, there are so many other better options for the style.
this one is very bitter.(not saying its a bad thing)but it is bitter.overall not a bad i.p.a. at a very good price.

Bottle:  Good west coast IPA.  Lots of bitter citrus and grapefruit hops in the aroma.  Cascade hops dominate the taste, nice and citrus/grapefruity yet crisp taste.  The caramel malt provides a consistent base to the high levels of hops.  Not amazing, but a very solid example of this style.
I had this at the Great Arizona Beer Festival in Phoenix. Very nicely hopped and likely one of the better beers I had that day.

Bottle. Dark amber beer with a big off-white head. Citrus hop aroma with a few other fruits thrown in. Malt/caramel backbone with a grapefruity flavor. Bitterness tingles at the end. Medium body. Dry finish.

from the bottle into the duvel tulip glass / thanks kevin! / this is weird. a little bit soapy, floral, big biscuity sweetness with a little lemon twang. a great sample, but nothing more. better than stone ipa, i think it is. i wish had a bar with just a bunch of IPAs on tap. yum!
Poured amber with a thin white head...smelled very sweet and floral, almost soapy too...tasted very sweet with strong aggressive hops on the back end...mouthfeel was thin...not bad, but not good...

This poured a dark orange into the PBR sniffer glass. The smell is off, it smells like wet laundry hosed down with Orange Clean.  It tastes flat with only a slight amount of bitterness. Its mostly sour and has a sort of chalky aftertaste. The palate is a bit thin on this. Not too impressed. Original rate was on a 2004 trip to San Diego. Not sure if the beer changed or I did. I'll sum it up now. I really like this all the citrus and pine you want in an old school IPA. Maybe a bad bottle I don't know? Going from a 2.8 to a 3.8. Cheers!

bottle. pours an amber witha light tan head.  very sweet malty aroma that has hints of hops. this is a nice pale ale, but the hops are understated. leaves a sweeter malt flavor. finish is also sweet with just a hint of hop flavor. if this was labeled as a pale ale it would be great, but as an IPA it is mediocre at best.
(draught) Amber with off white head. Mild hops aroma. Bitter. Hops flavor in the finish. As it warmed the finish became a bit sweeter with more citrus.

Tap at BT.  Pours a nice deep orange bright and has a great sticky white head.  Aroma is nice fresh sharp orange and citrus with almost a grassy or herbal bite to it that is maybe a dusty metal twang going on in the aroma and flavor.  Flavor tries hard to cover this up with tons of citrus and mango-like hops which are nice, very light crackery malt backbone  Just a slight twang going on, but otherwise it is nice.
i´ll have to try this on tap some time as it was a little uneven bottled. floral pine aroma was a little tamer than expected. quite bitter, a little lemony

I’m a IPA lover and this beer made me realize that.  Its not as strong as the other IPA’s I’ve had but thats okay cuz with this one I had a few and did’nt  get sick of it.  I’m a weirdo so you can call me that when i say the burps from this beer tasted yummy and licking the resin of this beer off my lips was good too.   Not a easy beer to find in my areas

Medium orange body. Sweet aroma, and quite malty for an IPA.  The flavor, though is the expected hoppy, and it is also toasty and roasty.  It is a little bit thin for an IPA, though, and it doesn’t really pack a punch like a prefer with my IPA’s.  Overall, quite average, but I imagine this would be a lot better on draught.

This is quite a fruity IPA, from the aroma of citrus and berries, to the strawberry color, to the abundant flavors of strawberries, cherries (do I detect a hint of raspberry?) - quite unique and odd - moderate hops and a strong, biscuit-like malt backbone for the fruit flavors to play off of - a unique experience - expect a malty ESB rather than an IPA, though.

Flowery hops, light toasted malt, candi sugar and grassines sin the noise.  I should have poured this more carefully - lots of floaties.  Flavor is toasted malt at first, sharp bitterness follows on the the back of my tounge, but its got a sweet, grassy finish.

12oz Bottle:  Slight hoppy aroma, but not too much to speak of.  Dark copper/brown color.  Lots of floaters!  Nice light colored head that lasted.  Good lacing.  Flavor much like an English IPA (true to style).  Started off hoppy, but was also a bit sweet.  Easy to drink.  Overall, a pretty good IPA, but I prefer more of an APA style with more bitterness.
Hoppy flavor, kinda sweet, not a bad IPA, not the best, but its worth a try.
Draft @ The Cannery, San Francisco, CA.  Amber. Good hop nose and flavor. Quite drinkable. A bit too one dimensional.

This one is truly disgusting, I have never tasted anything more metallic. I felt like I was drinking a bottle of my own cold blood. Needless to say, I let this stuff sit in my fridge and gave it to people who came over. I’d take Pabst, Olympia.... well, I’d pretty much take ANYTHING over this... except for Rainier Ale, which gets the award as the most horrifically disgusting thing I’ve ever had to drink.
Sweet and toasty malt aroma with a citric hop undertone. Sweet and malty with some caramel upfrotn. Some fruit and hops in the finish.  Too heavy on the malts for an IPA
A middle upper tier west coast IPA. A bit sweet for me. Hoppiness is dominate from nose to finish. Nothing bad here, but there’s better to be had out there. Best when chilled.
This is a really decent IPA that I was surprised with.  Nice bite and lots of hops.  Will drink again
(Draft) Typical West Coast soappy, sweet, piney IPA. This sample maybe suffering from age.

Poured a medium to dar amber with a large off white head. Fair amount of particles. Hoppy smelling with aromas of pineapples, pine, citris and oranges. Starts off sightly sweet and ends in a nice hoppy bitterness. Orange tastes. Very good IPA.

Pours golden orange with  white head and some haze. Sharp hoppy nose. As expected, a nice sharp bite of floral hops flavor, however one mixed with what appears to be unsweetened grapefruit juice. Good bitter taste in a decent IPA.

pours out a reddish orange color with lots of hoppy peices floating in the bottom of it.  not near like laconner dh, but still, a good amount.  poured into my newly acquired st bernardus glass :)  little to no head on this beer.  smell is hoppy, grapefruity and piney like most ipas.  taste is sweet and hoppy.  this is a pretty good ipa and a typical of a CA ipa.  not bad at all, i like it.  very smooth and easy drinking.

This had a creamy eggshell white head that rode on an amber beer that was hazy and showed some yeast sediment from the disturbance of it’s bottle conditioned yeast cake.
Caramel aroma sets the stage for the big grapefruit hop that is up front. 
Creamy sticky smoothness with a long bitter finish.
Nice.

Bottle. Two finger off white head capping a cloudy light brown/dark gold body. Strong hop nose. Typical IPA flavors-bitter hops, some citrus, a heavy dose of lemon, and a little salty taste (!!!). The salt taste fits in really well with the overall taste. Finish is quick and crisp, like lemonade. This is a very smooth drinkable IPA. I Would gladly have 10 or 12 more.
Light amber brown with lots of stuff floatin around in the glass.. Lemon hop aroma. Pretty big lemon grapefruit hop presence. This is a pretty good IPA, but nothing too spectacular.

I got this in a 22 oz bottle.  It is hard not to compare this to Lagunitas Maximus as it is very similar.  Head is not as  white and intense, but still attractive. The color is a unique red/gold/orange amber.  Good hoppy flavor and nice finish.  This to me is what an IPA is supposed be like.   Great balance, and simply a very well crafted brew.

Pours a nice amber color with a silky white head that leaves moderate lacing. Nice fresh hopped aroma. The hops carry through in the taste nicely with a good bitterness towards the end. Nice crisp taste. Slightly acidic taste afterward, but still a nice brew.

(12oz bottle) Pours near headless and a highly-carbonated, orange body. Nose of a rather musky-cascade and goldings hops. The initial milky, tart flavour gets walloped by a tart hoppy-world. Very good. Thanks to Lubiere for picking me up this during his recent trip to San Fran.

Man this brewery rocks! Everything they make is quality and very drinkable. Not necessarily knocking me out or anything like that but just in general good. This brew is no exception. In the glass: Lovely copper color just like the color behind the bottle in the picture to the upper left. Nice frothy head that lingers and lingers. Smell is excellently floral with a nice hint of the malt coming through all vanilla like and woody. On the palate. The floralness comes through much more intensely than the bitterness. This IPA does two things other IPAs don’t which are: 
1.the aromatic hop boil is emphasized rather than the bittering boil.
2.the malt is excellently present and not overshadowed by the hoppy flavors.
Great brew go get it
Grat

Golden ambe rusty in colour with a thin quickly discipating white head. Nose is hoppy and grapefruity , taste is pretty good too. Hops with some grapefruity. Remember when you get hair spray in your mouth? Well, this is it, only in a good way.

Caramel and cookie malt; grapefruit and grassy hops.  Lightly sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately bitter, lightly acidic finish.  Medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation.  The bottom line is: there’s an odd (and strong) leafy taste that’s really bugging me.
Poured a cloudy copper with a fast disappearing white head.  Nose was hoppy, grapefruit.  Pine.  Medium body with a smooth texture.  Flavor was citric, a tad buttery.  Not a bad beer.

A very nice golden appearance, with a big frothy head.  Toasted malts, in the aroma, and strange unplaceable hop aroma.  Very crisp, but full of toasted malt and it is just hard to get around.  Slightly inconsistent from taste to taste.  The hops are very present but then disappear in the next sip.  So that was kind of irritating.  Other than that a solid example of a west coast style IPA.
There is an exceeding freshness in this bottle that comes thru in the aroma and flavor.  Otherwise, this is your typical, west-caost IPA.  The only flaw is that the ingredients seem to hit in waves.
not my favorittet style but a darn good version of an IPA west coast style. Nice bitter taste with a clean finish.
Damn good IPA. Loaded with hops- not much of a flavor outside of the hops- and sometimes it works, somethines it doesn’t- this time it does.
On tap.  Poured a dark golden with a white head.  The flavor was nice and bitter with some fruitiness, but I was hoping for a little more maltiness to make it more interesting.  I’ve had way worse.

Bottle  Amberish w/ off-white head, doesn’t hold, some lace.  Sharp hop nose, piney.  Light bodied quick to finish w/ lingering bitterness.  Flavor is dominated by the piney, piney citric aftertaste.  I don’t get much else, a fairly thin beer it seems. Kinda boring hop juice, I’d like some malt please! I enjoyed the Pils(didn’t rate it), and really liked the Decimator, this one I find one-dimensional, let down, and yeah I know an IPA is supposed to scream hops, but I like it when it mutters other things as well.
Has a cloudy copper appearance and is a nice standard IPA that is bitter throughout, nothing exceptional though.
absolutely the best IPA i’ve ever had. the hops here are probably overdone for most palates but i can’t seem to get enough, i guess its an addiction

Pours clear orange with a thick cream colored head. Moderately hoppy aroma with some maltiness poking through. Taste is fairly light but decent. Some earthiness, mild citrus. Overall, good but a little thin compared to some of my favorite IPA’s.
Bottle. Typical American hoppyness, only this feels a bit tinny and a little short, lychee and pine, a bit rough around the edges.

Pours a hazy amber with little floaties and an off-white head. Aroma is very floral and hoppy. Taste is very nicely balanced with a strong hop presence, with good malt backing. Very floral with pine and grapefruit/citrus. Taste needs to be a little sweeter IMO. Mouthfeel is full but could use more body. Has a very bitter aftertaste. Nice lacing on the glass. A quality IPA.

It’s aw-aiight.  Dark golden, decent white head.  Yeast chunks thrown throughout.  Typical, yet not that typical left coast IPA.  I expect more from the west, gettin less though.  Same piney, grapefruit, apricot, and light caramel up the nose canal.  Flavor mirrors, but really just plain boring. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry finish. Like I said...it’s aw-aiigt and worth a try at least once.

Pours a dark golden color, with  a nice head and minimal lacing as it goes down.  Mostly hops, but certainly not as overpowering as their label claims things to be.  A decent, but unspectacular, West Coast IPA.  Still, I think Lagunitas provides some of the best value out there--very high quality beers at a reasonable price.

Clear, bright coppery/amber color, with a large, frothy whiteness above. Good lace-leavin, too.
Aroma is spot on for a good IPA, fresh and full of pine, fruit, citrus, sharp and lively, hoppy as all-get-out! I keep wanting to return to the smell of it, and each time it refreshes with this particular aromatic profile.
Taste: juuust right, with blasts of hops, under a solid malt foundation, flooding the tongue and dominating the senses in every way, without going overboard.
Just delicious, and exactly the way an IPA should act, if it’s worth it’s mustard, I say. Long, hoppy finish, sticks in the mouth and like it there. Mmmmm, I keep thinking, while this flavor never quits,...Mmmmmmm.

Bottle, no expiration date.  Pours light amber with slight chill haze.  Smell is light floral hops.  In the taste you get piney-citrus with apparent bitterness but little malt.  Warms up stays hoppy and malt is still hidden.  Made with 65 malts and 43 hops?  Di-hydrogen oxide?  The marketing people were smoking weed when they came up with that one.  
Redo 2018 Newark airport ( running on a 20-hour delay). Tastes Mosaic and other poopy hops (citra?). I don’t like Mosaic. Maybe I’m the one on weed now, but the hops don’t work for me.
A Good IPA, nothing special, but good for the price. A good brew, inticing aroma, thick color, lacey head. Good to the last drop.

12 oz bottle.  Medium amber, smallish head, fat lacing in the glass.  Light aroma of grass, honey, mild herbs.  Sweet beginning (peaches n honey), acerbic hops make their presence known quickly...the bite lasts throughout, but on the whole this doesn't have enough distinction to put it in the upper echelons of the IPA, IMHO.  Pleasant, biting, ok.
Golden hur, thin white head, faint straw aroma, grassy flavor, mild hops, thin body, but refreshing, finishes strong, this is a good brew, its very different than most other IPAs.
Bottled. Great long lasting slightly off-white head, lasting until the end of the glass.  Good level of carbonation.  Lots of hops flavor however, I could only detect 42 different hops :-)

A copper/amber color out of the bottle with a thin, lasting off-white head.  Subtle floral hop nose.  My first impression is that the body seems a little thin.  There are lots of hops in this, with a grapefruit rind bitter finish, but needs more malt support.  Tastey and easy to drink.

Bottled.  Average head, pretty white.  Nice, thick lacing and well lasting head.  Almost clear honey body with some small particals.  Smells of apricots and wet straw.  Taste is apricots, almost imperceptibly sweet; finish is dry and rather bitter, some grapefruit rind.  Mouthfeel is nice; wet, soft creamy carbonation...makes your mouth water; very nice medium body.  Overall: there's no sweet(I think apricots, I want sweet), lots of bitter, very dry and really interesting flavor with sugarless apricot.

The color is a clear medium copper. Not a whole lot of head. There's a low, herbal hop aroma. It's sweet and malty with only medium bitterness. Nicely balanced but surprisingly reserved for the style.

Orange copper medium thick body with a one inch thick head that left nice lace as it dissipated.  Medium carbonation is just right for the style.  Aroma is piney hops and alcohol.  Taste lacks a lot of sweetness, and is unbalanced towards snappy hop bitterness with some astringency reminiscent of orange peel.  The malts are biscuit like with a bit of a sour twang in the aftertaste.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin but gets better as the beer warms. A good IPA for a hophead.  Thanks 123456green for this opportunity to taste some west coast goodness.

Sampled October, 2004

RatingPours an almost brilliantly clear copper color and is topped by a cream colored head.  The aroma is sharply hoppy with a nose that is redolent of pine, the nose is quite nice.  Ah, yes this beer has actually been fermented, what a relief, this beer is nothing like the last one I had.  This beer is sharp and crisp up front.  It leads to a beer that is piney, a bit citrusy, and has a solid bitter bite in the finish.  This beer has a solid malt presence as well, it is lightly sweet with notes of caramel and biscuits.  The malt definitely is faint behind the solid hoppiness though, but it is there and helps to keep the hops from being overwhelming.  As this beer warms up a bit I get notes of apricot, and grapefruit.  Overall, this is quite a nice IPA.



March, 2004 Rating

Wow this beer smells like it has not yet been fermented.  A sweet wort smell, that is heavy on the crystal malt.  A bit of spicy hop notes under the main smell, but not much.  Pours a hazy copper color with a prodigious tan head that fades fairly quickly.  Again there is a sweet malt flavor, that is reminiscent of sweet wort.  The beer ends with a bit of bitterness.  I must admit, this is quite a stretch to be labeled as an IPA, a pale ale perhaps but not an IPA.  A light hop flavor and not enough bitterness, this is a bit of a disappointment.  It is halfway interesting, just not close to what I was expecting.  There is way too much residual sweetness and body in this beer, it just makes it too unbalanced.  I will tell you one thing, the rest of this 6-pack will be used for making Brats. (6/4/6/3/13/3.2)

Cloudy, golden-amber body.  Huge off-white, vanilla colored head.  1st bottle blew up in my lap after sitting level for days. Massive carbonation, smells of apple cider, pine, citrus and something grainy like uncooked corn.  Taste is big and sweet with apples, pineapple, pine cones and needles, and some grapefruit.  Palate suffers from some wateriness.  Thin mouthfeel is much different than a more syrupy IPA like stone.

Pours, nice deep amber color. Perfect head, and later, a nice lace all the way down the glass. Nose is subdued a bit, compared to other IPA's, this I can not explain because it really opens up on the palate. A tinge malty at first, tastes of lemons and grapefruit, nice sharp hop finish, a flicker of salt and black tea. Actually very light-bodied, clean but sharp. A nice IPA, with a killer drinkability factor. No ABV% listing, but I'm guessing more in the 6-6.5% range. Tends to steer away from the floral characters, lending more to the citrus genre. A nice solid brew

Poured gold in a tall Magic Hat #9 glass with a nice head. Soapy, floral aroma. Taste is good, but a little dull. If it had the same taste kicked up, they'd have something. Well balanced with a nice dry and sweet finish.

On tap at a pizza place. Cloudy amber color. Creamy lasting head. Nose of some hops, nothing too pronounced. Surprisingly very malty, was disappointed with the hops in this one, might of been a slight hint of skunk. Didn't pick up any complexities, I'll try this one in a bottle again to be fair and give it a more accurate rating. Surpised some gave this one outstanding marks.

Fat nose of fresh west coast hops, amber color, tall tan and sticky head. Light malt body gets quickyl overpowered by a high resolution, bright hop bitterness that stays around forever. The bitterness actually seems to INCREASE after the swallow. Great effect. Smooth, crisp, excellent IPA.

Nice balance of caramel sweetness and citrusy hops, tinted with innocuous mango fruitiness…Once dropped in, the yeast impinges on the spicy oranges and a lasting, astringent bitterness prevails…A very good hop rush for hopheads, while being a bit lackluster...
nice rocky head, light tan.  strong hoppy notes with light citrus fruit.  good golden/amber color.  mild carbonation, strong hop start and finish.  can also taste the pine others are talking about.

Bottle-conditioned, Clear deep golden hue with a sticky white head. Aroma is rather mild and could use more intensity. A solid malt base shows in the form of honey, caramel, butter. Hop profile is shy, citrusy, grassy and piney. Taste is more honey melted with pine. It's very bitter finally with resiny grapefruit aftertaste. Creamy medium body. When pouring the yeast depot, there's more orange character and it's far drier. Thanks Rodolito!
Big hop bite up front with a smooth, fruity finish. Went down smooth, a very refreshing brew.

Pleasant but subdued hoppy aroma, resinous and earthy, with tinges of cedar, pine, herbs, citrus fruit and a small amount of faintly grainy, sweet maltiness.  Light-medium copper color, tiny suspended particles throughout, with a finely beaded head.  Flavor profile is composed almost entirely of hops.  Flowery, citric and piney, the hoppiness is accented lightly with touches of malt sweetness in the middle while finishing bitter and dry.  Palate is fittingly mellow, effervescent, smooth and mouth-watering, medium body.  Exceedingly drinkable and tasty, if a tad unbalanced.

Oh yes - what a nice one. Light red-pink colored brew like a Rhabarber-Schorle. Little layer of a head, leaving laces on the glass. Soft carbonation. Hoppy and alos fruity nose. Intense hoppy kick first, nice long lasting aftertaste. Scratches on the roof of the mouth.
Has a really nice bitter bite to it, and a nice about of hops.  Citrus aroma.  Overall pretty nice.
Golden orange color, dissipating white head. Has a citrus hop kick right where the throat starts at the back of the mouth. Full and creamy mouthfeel, bitter, but not crazy bitter. fly rocks!

I *really* like Lagunitas, but not this one. And I’m a hop-head.

Pours a beautiful amber with a very nice white head that left some great lacing. Classic appearance.

Smells *really* hoppy like an IPA should.

Tastes, well, Cascade grapefruit. Aaaaand, that’s it. Nothing to balance it at all. As much as I like hops, if you’re going to hop it this much, please add some malt as well. This is way too unbalanced for my tastes.

Mouthfeel is average and drinkability suffers from the lack of balance.

If you like the hops, the whole hops, and nothing but the hops, this beer is for you. While I thought I was in that catagory, I realize that a good IPA needs more than that.

Bright orange body with a slight chill haze. Fine white head that clings to the glass in sheets of beautiful lacing. The aroma is grapefruit and pine with a slight bit of bready malt. The flavor is a nice balance of citrus hops and sweet malt. The body is medium with a dry texture. The finish is bitter with some slight astringency. Overall a very nice IPA.

After checking out the West Coast Micro selection, I finally found one I do not like at all.  The beer boasts having 43 types of hops, all of which gag you.  I have had my fair share of Cali IPAs but this one failed to taste pleasant, like say Sierra Nevada, and did not test as refined as Stones beers.  I always enjoy variety, and I think I can no reflect more positively on other breweries.  Maybe a fluke review but definitely overrated in my book.

Pretty hazy orange color, decent head.  Aroma of fresh blood oranges.  Excellent orange hop flavors with a bit of pineapple.  Balancing but clearly secondary malt flavor, a hop bitter finish.  Very good, to say the least.
OK, so I went to the worst nastiest bar in SD to have this for the first time.. Dick's yuck!!! Beer was not cold, so my rating may be off. Drinkable at such a lame bar!!!!
Nice golden color with a generous white frothy head. Strong citrus hops aroma. Strong citrus hops flavor with a very bitter hops finish. An excelllent IPA.

Very hazy orange/yellow with a very light sticky head & lots of lacing. The aroma is slightly citrusy at first but fades into bland. The flavor is not very hoppy but the ending bitterness is definately apparent. This is more light & balanced than most IPAs I'm used to.

Initially weak, but the aftertaste grows on me.  Typical West Coast IPA, a good amount of hopping.  A little unrefined, but I enjoy it nevertheless.  Possibly a little too sweet.  Pretty good buy @ $5.89 for a 6-pack.
Slightly murky amber color. Thin head. Complex citrusy sweet hoppy aroma engulfs the nostrils. Sharp hoppy flavor bites into the tongue.  Actually a bit addicting, time for another bottle.

Draft: Pours a clear golden with a decent lightly lacing white head.  Freah hoppy and sugary aroma.  Body has a candy sweetness, without much caramel malt presence.  The finish is bitter and dry.  This could definitely use more balance.
(Bottle)  Pours a cooper, slightly hazy, color with a medium-sized white head.  Has your typical IPA hoppy  and grapefruit flavor.

12 oz bottle-im going to keep this review simple.  basically, what you have here is a typical left coast ipa-lots of hops and not much malt.  If you added more malt, you would have SNCA.  45 ibu’s?  Im thinking more around 65 on this one.  solid beer!
rerate-i lowered my rating on this due to the body of this beer being too cloying sweet.  the hops are not that strong and the aroma is fairly faint.

Bought in the 22 oz brown bomber..with "Unlimited Release" on the label :-). OG 1.059..IBU 45.6
Pours a beautiful orangy amber colour, small head but it lingers..slightly hazy..all in all good IPA appearance.
Mmmmm the aroma of this "IPA" is different from most of this style I have had.I smell hops alright but also there is a strong sweet malt aroma..almost even a honey/flowery sweetness aroma.
The taste is pleasant..but its definatlly light on the hops for an IPA..theresmore of a malt palate than is usual..but its pleasant.
Good creamy , smooth feel on the tongue
This beer is probably closer to an American Pale Ale than an IPA, because of its light hoppiness..but its a certainlly a tasty brew and well worth a try!

Orange-amber in color. The head is thin yet creamy, and lasts to the bottom of the glass. Resiny, piney hop aroma along with buttery crackers(?) Flavor at first is huge sharp/grassy/spicy hops, followed imediately by barely sweet chewy malt and an exquisite juicy fruit component, peaches and pears maybe. Holding the glass to a light reveals constellations of the tiniest bubbles swirling lazily upwards. Bittersweet hops dominate the long mouthwatering finish. Excellent!

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting.
Body is medium yellow.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, grapefruit, grass).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation.

A solid, non-abrasive, non-resinous version. Not a lot going on in the nose, but it’s an easy quaffer with good balance and a nice mouthfeel.
Smelled hoppy and malty. Poured a nice honey yellow. Subtle start to the flavor that quickly strikes with a sharp, bitterness.  Nice!
Re-rate: nice look to it. fluffy off-white head on a pale ale body. This IPA has more roasted malt character then I am used to, but it is smooth and well-rounded. I'll drink this again.
dark brown colour, but that might just be because i was in a dark area. the smell is mild and the taste was very good at the beginning but a little overpowering as i got more into the beer.

The head is thin and collapses quickly, but you are assaulted by wonderful hops, and grapefruits on the nose. Orangy hazy light brown. Beautiful rich body, with the hops and citrus cutting thorugh the malt in harmony...Hops heaven...excellent beer!

Superior hop aroma - pine, citrus, whole flower goodness. Nose is not without a wonderful nutty, caramelly malt presence.  Perfectly balanced, strong chewy malts, Bitter flavorful hops.  Not overly bitter, smooth and lasting flavor. Quality is apparent at first sip. Awesome.
Nutty, hoppy with hints of malt.  Slightly lemon and citrus flavors come out as it warms.  Very decent and well worth the drink.
Awesome orange color with a nice balance of hops and spices.  The hops really comes out towards the end of the glass.

A great Triumph. I am a Hop-Head if there ever was one. An IPA at only 45 IBUs?... Proposterous! Except it's a beautiful ale. Very high in hop aroma. So they didn't throw the hops in at the first mention of a boil?... So what! A greatly aromatic IPA witha wonderful malt presence and great aromas. I love it whether you call it an American Pale Ale, an English IPA or,... I don't giva a shit. This is a well thought out recipe for a wonderful beer style!

A bright orange colr with a small white head.  This looks like it is thick as it pours.  Dry pine, bread, and grapefruit aroma.  Initially this was very good for about 3/4 of the 22oz bottle, the last 1/4 has turned very watery.  A nice pine/grapefruit taste at first that is very easy to drink.  Still a quality IPA that is very easy to make into a session beer.

Rerate Much better on tap a few miles from the brewer in Sonoma, California. Good citrusy hoppiness. Original 3.3 Interesting hard to place aroma - slightly fruity. Very light amber appearance with a decent size white head. Tongue-numbing grapefruity flavor - sticks with you for a while. Fruity aftertaste. Overall a decent IPA - nothing really separates it from the rest of the pack though - had better from this brewer.
Very hoppy, citrus, woody. Very long trailing bitter palate. Orange brew, good pup, clean label.  Ding for the screwoff.

Nice amber color,small head with a decent staying power.Good aroma of hops citrus and some what spicy.The flavor was malty hoppy and grapefruit with an after taste being much the same a the aroma with a nice hop bitterness.Could stand to be a little more hoppy but then i'm not a hophead so this brew really hits the spot.
Pours a nice amber, good head and some nice lacing.  Aroma is all hops, and so is the flavor.  Nice west coast IPA.

One of my fav. california beers.  great ipa characteristics, hoppy with a lot of grapefruit.   
Clean finish with a somewhat astringent aftertaste.  Good overall everyday beer.

Pours reddish/copper. Small sudsy head, dissipates quickly.  Slight carbonation. Aroma of Cascade hops and something sweet. Flavor is hops then immediate and long bitter finish that lasts forever. Some grapefruit in there.  I didn’t rate this as highly the first time, but now it has become one of my favorite daily drinkers.  (And, yes, I’m an IPA fan). It’s not over the top like some, but I keep coming back to it repeatedly.
Gorgeous orange-amber color with thick white head and nice lacing.  Nice sweet malts and balancing hops.  Full bodied and lightly carbonated.  Good IPA

Pours a nice light amber-red with good head. Floral aroma with citrus and hops. Nice fruity taste with hints of pine, and a pleasant hop finish. Silky palate. A very decent IPA, not enough hops for me though.

On tap in Houston: Could not rate appearance since the lights were turned down for frickin low, good head though. The aroma was that of grapefruit, melons, toasted malts, and piney hops. Crisp piney taste, but well balanced IMO. Medium-bodied with a lively mouthfeel. A sure fired winner this beer is.
nice head, great color, nice and well balanced ipa, goes down nice and easy, the best part of it is that it was free at the brewery

Pours clear and golden, with a small frothy white head.  Aroma of citrus, pear & hops.  I find the flavor a bit lacking in character - it needs a little more colour in the taste.  Palate is mildly bitter, pretty smooth going down - alcohol is hidden very well.  This one gives you an aftertaste to last the rest of the night.
I love this hoppy IPA. Their Pale Ale is also nice, not as hoppy...I serve the IPA to the real hopheads and to the unititated, I serve the Pale Ale

I headed to Saratoga to visit Big Basin Bistro after I left Stoddard's brewpub in Sunnyvale last Thursday.  Thanks again to the peeps in Ratebeer forum to steering me to such a killer Brewpub as BBB was my favorite establishment whilst I stayed in the San Jose area.  The brew pours from the tap a clear copper orange.  The thin white head is mostly diminishing, but has good lacing.  The nose is pine and spice, perfume and citrus.  The taste is rosy and piney and finishes with a sharp bitter bite.  Some alcohol sweetness in the middle, and a hint of dried fruit in the rear.  The palate is full, dry, and lively.  Very nice.

Lagunitas certainly found a winner in their blending. With as many different kinds of hops and malts, I would be concerned with their ability to keep the brew consistent. But I would say this one's a winner though. Their bottle says it best... "Life Is Uncertain, Don't Sip!"

Medium clear orange with a large light tan head.  Nose is consumed by the Lagunitas yeast, which smells like brown sugar, cinnamon and cedar.  Combine that with a nutty, old spiced fruit hop scent.  Lacks depth.  Only a small amount of fruit noticed in the finish after a rather coarse nuts and unsweet brown sugar.
reading the label I was concerned after finding this beer had 43 different hops and 65 various malts.  But it's great.  top 10 IPA's from the U.S.
Poured out very nice. Good white head. Nice aroma and very VERY smooth taste. One of my more favorite IPA's.
I give this beer an extra mark or two for the "43 different hops and 65 various malts".  Very dark IPA. Floral aroma, flavor and aftertaste.  "Hop burps" galore.  A top 50 IPA in my book.
Insanely hopped ale with a decent malt backbone.  Darkish golden color with a sour finish. A lot of bite.
Big white foamy head on a hazy orange body.  Huge hops attack that leaves a bracingly bitter aftertaste.   Nice malts to back it up.

Wow!  wicked hoppy aroma on this one.  golden color that's a little cloudy.  oops, maybe the glass is dirty.  a super complex malty and hoppy taste with a bitter aftertaste.  a great beer.  i wish i stuffed more of bottles when i came back from my vacation in California.
Bottle.  A slightly hazy medium golden color with a laced white head.  Citrus and hop aroma with a bitter vinous flavor.  A fine west coast IPA but nothing stands out.

Not gonna get too descriptive here, save to say that that this is picture-perfect IPA-definitely hop accented, but still balanced and drinkable in quantity on a good night. On that note, I'm outa here, good NIGHT!
Nice aroma, burnt amber color. A bite of hops at first taste. This beer will float a few boats with all the hops. Still a nice sweet malt flavor. Full bitter ahead, and damn the other ales mate.
Solid IPA. More balance than many. Not as strongly hopped as some, so make of that what you will. Nice citrus tart flavor in there. Have had better, but this is very enjoyable,
Solid India pale ale.  Not as hoppy as other west coast IPA's, but a great example of the style.
over ripe flavor with hints of rotting fruit.  Way over hopped to the point of abhorance.  Redeeming quality, colour. Sorry.

From the bottle. 
Good nose,citrusy sweet. Orange brown color. Burnt & bitter,Hoppy with enough malt to stand up. Creamy clean finish.  Tasted better at the Big Basin Bistro on draft 03/29/03. I'd be happy with them anytime
Cloudy deep yellow pour with a thick head and good lacing.  Good floral and citrus in the nose.  Decent bite, but still an average IPA.
Orangish red in color with a nice thick head. Lots of sediment. Smells hoppy. Tastes perfumey and bitter.

Poured a dark burnt orange color with a lot of yeasty sediment and a very frothy head that lasted the whole beer. A slight citrus aroma with hops over-riding. A bitter hop flavor and some malts. A good full mouthfeel. Great amount of carbonation. Nice overall.

Pours a slightly hazy copper color with particles floating throughout. The head is small, lingering, and white colored. It has a nice floral hop aroma with a touch of citrus and pine. Full body with moderate carbonation, the flavor is mostly hops with a bit of malt backbone. The finish is lingering and bitter. Nice IPA from Lagunitas.

From Hollingshead Deli in Orange, CA. Not a bad IPA at all. Pours a murky golden amber color with a thick off-white head. The foamy head lasted quite a while. Nice lacing as well. Floral hops aroma. Flavor is very citrusy, and the hops are really not as bold as the glass progresses. Nicely bitter finish. Doesn't have the "snap you with a wet towel" hops that the great IPAs have but otherwise this beer is just fine.
Good aroma, and good appearance.  Great taste, very smooth and refreshing.  Great after taste.  Just makes you want to take another drink.

hazy golden with a big frothy white head.  looks like a classic west coast IPA.  Intensely bitter grapefruit nose.  Clean and full in the mouth, taste cleans up like a pilsner only really bitter and woody.
Nice clean top shelf ipa.  Not as good or hoppy as the maximus but can hold its own. Citrusy & resfreshing, another great wake-up in the morning beer.
Orange color with bubbly white head.  Aroma is slightly hoppy.  Fairly well carbonated.  Flavor is dminated by green vegetable flavor and citrus.  Fairly thin and refreshing.

Light, shiny amber orange beer with a big ol’ poofy head.  The aroma is full of essence, malty yet citricly inviting.  Very nicely pronounced grapefruit hop tones with a resiny feel and a sweet finish over the tongue.  Very, very good.

Big fluffy head and thick sheets of lace topped off this glorious golden nectar.  First the malt - yep, there's some in here, showing up in the thin stream of sweetness down the center of my tongue.  The citrus/fruit aroma carries thru to the resiny hops full of thick grapefruit juice - I was surprised at how hoppy it seemed when the bottle lists 44 IBU.  This would be perfect for a  summertime picnic
Medium gold with slight cloudiness, pleasant citrus, hoppy nose. Alhough balanced a bit on the hops side, this not a problem at all - the interesting malt flavors are there to enjoy. A very good IPA.

Classic citrusy American hop aroma.  Clear golden color with an impressive white head.  Hops dominate the flavor, with the balance on the bitter side.  I would have liked a little more supporting malt, it seemed a little thin.  Quite good, but if you have the choice, go for the Maximus instead.

Clear,golden,a milky,lacey,bone-white,head. Aroma is bold,citrus,toasted grain. Mouthfeel is soft(carbonation)and not as bitter as I was expecting. Extremely bready/grainy flavors lead up to a grassy(hop),citric,slightly sweet finish. I totally disagree with some of the past ratings. This just isn't hops,maybe cold,it is but it doesn't even have a bitter finish.More hop,flavor.I dig it! I love these grassy,toasty,grainy Ipa's.Thanks M!
Reminded me of a Free State beer I enjoy, except for not as unique or tasty. Too citrusy, tastes as though someone squeezed in half a lemon.

Fresh hops smell and character. Very citrusy; heavy on the "C" hops. There is some talk of a battle between the hops and the malt on the bottle; make no mistake, this beer exists to display the hops. Warm, dry finish. Enjoyable bitterness.
Fresh and crisp hops throuout the taste spectrum.  Mildly complexed with a mix of light fruit to pine flavor.  Lightly malted taste subsides with a clean refreshed pallet.

Bitter, floral aroma.  Taste about the same.  Golden amber coloer, darker than most IPAs.  Small but rich head.  One of the better IPAs I've had.  Slightly cloudy, with a lighter bitterness than expected.

Very very flowery IPA. The blinding bitterness was surprisingly tasty, but there wasn't enough to back it up. After the hop tsunami subsided, there was almost no trace of malt at all, just the lingering bitterness left after the storm. A definite palate thrasher.
Pale copper color; good head; resiny nose. Lots of oily hops in this one. predictable citrus tones. about what one would expect form a west coast ipa.

(24Jan2003--12oz.bottle)
Well, this is about as "California-ee" as a beer gets.
Thick, inviting head, lacy, fine bubbles, persistent.
Deep reddish-yellow color.
Aroma: Strong cascades hops, malty, fruity (peach).
Flavor: Sprucy, incredibly fresh hops.  Rarely have I felt as if I was tasting fresh hops.  Here I was.
Good creamy mouthfeel, perfect malt level, some fruity flavors, not intensely citric (peach).
Intensely bitter finish.  Distractingly so.  The level of
bitterness in the middle is great; perfectly in balance with the malt.  Why is the back of my 
tongue tingling 15 minutes after finishing?  I wasn't rewarded with enough
"oomph" in the beer to deserve bitter beer face.
Golden hazy in color, pours in with white head with medium head retention. Nice hoppy flavor but could be more. Malts are not well balanced against the hops.

Minimal head, orange color.  Not wild about the flavor of the hopping, somehow, but it's not objectionable and has a nice, crisp better.  Pleasant sweetish malty aftertaste lingers in the mouth.  Not bad.
Clean, crisp, smooth, and not overly hoppy.  Nice little head.  Very piney aroma.
Transluminate honey color.  Maintains a 1/4" head.  Citrus bite and finish.  Oily mouthfeel.  Pretty standard IPA.
Nice hop aroma and flavor. Well rounded flavors,not as bitter as expected.  Very crisp and clean.

Eh.. Not fantastic but not bad. I had expected this to be another west coast hop monster and it just didn't show up. Sort of reminds me of Quail Springs IPA. Sure the hops are there but at a subdued level. A thoroughly enjoyable brew but not an "In your face IPA". I still have to try Stone Ruination and Dogfish 90 minute both in my fridge.
Opaque amber,thick off white head.Citrus light cat piss nose .Medium citrus hop profile,medium lasting bitter end.Perfumey nose and palate

New:  No, no, no.  This is really wonderful and not at all overdone. Complex, but more comforting rather than confrontational.  Swell stuff. 

Old: 12/29/02Nose is like a pine forest.  Flavor is impressively complex hops and little else.  Great sticky lacing on the glass.  This is the poster child of overhopped West Coast beer.  Unecessarily bitter.  Does have its moments, however.
Nice woodsy hop aroma.  The first sip smacks you in the face with hops, but then fades away into nothing.  Leaves you wondering if you missed something...enjoyable all the same.
Nice hop to it, nothing over the top.  Just enough to know the brewer cares about you.  Good copper color with a very active head.  Nice citrus up front with a nice little bite to it.

12oz bottle: Crystal clear light copper color with medium sized fluffy white head. Aroma has fair amount of subtle citrusy hops, bit of light caramel. Flavor is bit malty, fair amount of hops, with balanced finish. A nice, simple IPA, nothing fancy, but solid.
They weren''t lying when they said "heavily hopped", as it is dominant in this drink.  Of course, I didn''t mind and continued to sip the sixer.  Reminds me of Celebration Ale "light."
good flavor. an excellent IPA in a world of crappy one''s. good beer to drink.

I found this refreshing. Yes, it could have been a little more balanced, but I enjoyed the hops. I like this better than the Maximus. Lots of Columbus and others in there, really refreshing. My favorite IPA.

golden amber with a huge, no make that really huge head with big dents and craters like the surface of the moon...the mango aroma hinted of tartness and subtle alcohol, lightly carbonated? I think not, heavily carbinated, well yes, not a bad thing though IMO...hops were pretty mellowed out and balanced until the finish came around where they popped out like a little birdie in a coo-coo clock... super hoppy finish and slightly fruity with bitter mangoness

Smelled very strongly of American hops, and poured a light amber with a decent head.  The flavor is very nicely balanced.  Good bitterness from the hops without being medicinal, and then a crisp malt finish that isn't too sweet.  The hops aftertaste sticks around for a while.
Not bad, but nothing great either. With so many great IPA's out there, im afraid i probably wont be buying this one again.
A standard west coast IPA.  Typical citrus aroma and flavor.  A well-made beer though, and well-balanced.  A good representation of a U.S. IPA.

“Oh yeah baby”, lots of “Little Fernies” a floatin’ in this beer, a hazy amber color the head modest, the texture frothy, the color and off white with a nice covering of lace. Sweet malt, light hop floral tone also noticed, quite sniffable, sweet malt start, the top moderate in feel. Finish has a definite acidic bite, the hops potent in their spicy bite, dry and long lasting aftertaste. A great beer from a great brewery got a couple of its bigger brother aging away, and that would be “Maximus”!
classic cascade aroma, hops the whole way through that just keep building...

The summer smell of freshly cut lawns and big piles of grass clippings blend brilliantly with a musky hint of lime and avocados. The presentation is nice, a deep gold wit a bright white razor thin cap. I really like the start of this, a smooth refreshing lemon-lime bittersweet tounge. The end however, is kind of strange. Although I enjoy the smell of freshly cut grass, I don't particularly enjoy tasting it. A bit of a grassy exit, after a good bitter up swell.
Dark Amber color, small head. Fully hopped, medium malts. A nice hoppy full-bodied IPA. Hoppy without being too bitter. Good flavor. Aftertaste is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is hoppy, mostly bitter

Another one I had only out of the bottle so I cannot rate the appearence properly, but it smells and tastes like your standard IPA.  Nothing new so I would rather get the Harpoon if I had the choise...
Wonderful bitterness clean finish great on Hot California Days with BarBQue. Not Excellent but Very Good.
I recall this having a great flavor, nice strength, great appearance.    This is a good one for a summer evening over the grill

Beautiful hazy orange color. Great grapefruit/apple/bitter flavor/aroma. I was a little afraid of this beer from the reviews and the fact that I do not usually like IPA's, but I found this drink very enjoyable.
A shockingly bitter IPA that wallops you with hops from the first sip.  After I recovered, I discovered other more subtle malt tones that made for a very pleasant, woody finish.
Pours golden amber with a huge frothy head. Hoppy aroma. Sweet malt start, hoppy middle and a grapefruit bitter finish. Not my favorite, but a damn good IPA in it’s own right.

Perfect hoppy/citrusy aroma, flavors are juicy and extravagant, with hop oil throughout.  Eye-wateringly bitter all the way through, but a terrific malt backbone evens her out and makes for a superbly balanced beer.  Its unfiltered, which seems to add to its flavor.  A bit drying on the palate.  Sensational!

Aroma is light and citrusy/hoppy. Color is a fine hazy orange-gold with a billowy off-white head--good spotted lace...Flavor is dominated by a refreshing grapefruit-hop kick that attacks up-front, then again in the rind-dry finish. Moderate carbonation adds its own boost to the dry assault.  This is most invigorating to the palate--the intensity of the flavor compensates somewhat for lack of a malty counterweight, but upon repeated tasting one wishes for a bit more balance...Still, this is bracing refreshment.

Nice aroma, hops very evident, but the huge head put me off a bit, really too much carbonation in my bottle.  Fairly smooth palate, but not as complex as some of the Northwest IPA's I've been having lately.  When i want an IPA, I want mega-hops, and this falls just a bit short.  Still, i think most people will like it.

I split a large bottle of this with my mother-in-law, and since she is a pretty cool mother-in-law, she really liked this.  Without being too careful in pouring, it produced a huge head.  The aroma was interesting--I thought it had a martini or Gin & Tonic-like aroma, plus something fruity--someone else has said mango, and that may be right.  The flavor is well...IPA...you know...hoppy, somewhat (but not overpoweringly) bitter.  Not complex, but nice.
A good solid IPA, but not the cream of the crop.  Cascade hops, and quite a bit of em.

the six pack i had was very well carbonated.  the head from a very slow easy pour down the side of the glass was stronger than the head of a root beer float, pretty damn strong!  intense fruity hop aroma and intense hop bitterness in the finish.  a hint of malt sneaks through but does not do much.  what i will remember about this beer was the huge head, not the flavor.

Definitely not my favorite West Coast IPA, and I generally prefer English IPAs to West Coast ones anyway. The English ones generally have a better balance of malt and hops, in contrast to the West Coast approach of overdoing the hops and using the most intensely bitter hops available.

Nice golden IPA. Hops are dominating with a very nice malt balance. IPA"s used to be a favorite but it"s hard to find one that really stands out. I agree with DaSilky1 about the appearance though, poured a huge white head that just looked refreshing.
Kid sister to Maximus.  Light amber color with a medium head.  Citric, to light floral hops.  A bit thin in body.  Hops everywere.
Fresh almost young and filled with intense but tasty green hops. Body medium, color slightly cloudy. A great IPA!
A big West Coast IPA, walloping hops and substantial malt with inctricate herbal flavors -- citric acid, lemon, light juniper. Long lasting finish that opens up more doors of hop flavor.
Opaque burnt orange color. Nice up front hoppy taste w/ a clean finish. Not much aroma.

The aroma is good pine hoppy, but it's got an additional smell that's a bit off.  The flavor is pretty hoppy, but then there's some buttery taste up front and a sour lemony flavor later.  Based on the other ratings, I wouldn't be surprised if we got a skunked bottle -- i sure hope so.

The bottle is amusing.  The aroma is wonderful.  Very hoppy sweet.  The flavor is disappointing.  It's not bitter, it's sour and really unfamiliar.  The finish is a sour lemon flavor and the aftertaste is sweet, like lemon candy.  It would belong nicely in a hefeweizen, but this is not a hefeweizen.

Outstanding! Not the most bitter IPA (45 IBU's) but great character and complexity (65 malts/43 hops). Crisp refreshing citric bitterness noticeable throughout forcing its way through in a long lingering finish. Malts are sensational without being overwhelming. Mild biscuity pale ale character turns into a fruit juice cocktail of pineappple, peach nectar and orange juice. Citric grapefruit in the finish although not strong for the style. Touch of spice briefly finishes things off before relaxing into the mellow malts and citric aftertaste. Proof that IPA's can be great without bringing tears to your eyes.
Nice spicy aroma, unbelieveably excessive and prominent cascade hops.  .....
